organizers: GEW: German Education Union; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Greenpeace; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Teachers (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 31 January 2025, at the call of Grannies Against the Right, between 20,000 and 25,000 people, including Mayor Peter Tschentscher (SPD), The Greens, The Left, GEW, and Greenpeace gathered near the city hall in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg) to protest against the CDU and AfD after their joint vote in the Parliament to tighten migration policies by forming a human chain. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 30 January 2025, several hundred people, including politicians and Deputy Minister President Petra Kopping (SPD) gathered in Dresden (Sachsen) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2025, around 2,500 people, including the SPD, Grannies Against the Right, MLPD, leftist groups and 'Dusseldorf stands against it' (Dusseldorf-stellt-sich-quer) gathered in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: GEW: German Education Union; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Teachers (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2025, at the call of the SPD and the Greens, the GEW, and the 'Workers' Welfare Association' (Arbeiterwohlfahrt), around 7,000 people, including Lower Saxony's Minister-President Stephan Weil (SPD) and Minister for Education Julia Willie Hamburg (The Greens) gathered in Hannover (Niedersachsen) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2025, in the evening, at the call of The Left, under the motto 'Against Fascism, Racism, and Hatred of People', between 300 and 400 people gathered in Koblenz (Rheinland-Pfalz) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2025, in the evening, at the call of 'Lubeck Refugee Forum' (Fluchtlingsforum Lubeck), Grannies Against the Right, the SPD, the Greens and The Left, people gathered in Lubeck (Schleswig-Holstein), to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Volt Europa
description: On 30 January 2025, at the call of Volt Europa, GJ, and Jusos, around 4,000 people gathered in front of the CDU's headquarters in Mainz (Rheinland-Pfalz) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2025, at the call of The Greens, around a dozen people gathered at the train station in Moosburg (Bayern) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: Former Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 30 January 2025, in the evening, at the call of the alliance 'Munchen is Colorful' (Munchen ist bunt), over 7,000 people, including figures like former mayor Christian Ude (SPD), gathered in front of the CSU headquarters in Munchen (Bayern) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2025, at the call of The Greens, and groups like 'Parents for Future' and Grannies Against the Right, several dozen people gathered near an AfD information stand in front of the Humboldt-Gymnasium in Potsdam (Brandenburg) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Sea-Eye; Seebruecke; Students (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2025, in the evening, at the call of GJ, Jusos, 'Refugee Council' (Fluchtlingsrat), Sea-Eye, Seebruecke and FFF, several hundred people gathered in Stuttgart (Baden-Wurttemberg) to protest against the CDU's proposed migration policy and its cooperation with the AfD. The protest was marked by chants like 'Nazis raus!' and calls to defend democracy.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Evangelical Christian Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 29 January 2025, at the call of a broad alliance of 24 organizations, including Alliance Against the Right Falkensee, DGB Havelland, The Greens, The Left, SPD, the 'Welcome Initiative Falkensee' (Willkommensinitiative Falkensee), the Youth Council (Jugendbeirat), theYouth Council Falkensee (Jugendforum Falkensee), Local Agenda 21 (Lokale Agenda 21), and the District Youth Convention (Kreisjugendkonvent) of the Evangelical Church, hundreds of people gathered in Falkensee (Brandenburg) to protest against a proposal by the AfD to ban the rainbow flag from public buildings.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 29 January 2025, on the occasion of the Economic Warning Day, at the call of 140 business associations, including the Initiative 'New Social Market Economy' (Neue Soziale Marktwirtschaft (INSM)), between 450 and 1,000 business owners and employees staged a protest at the Brandenburger Tor in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) demanding tax cuts and reforms. FDP MP Christian Lindner and CDU parliamentary group vice-chairman Jens Spahn were present.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 28 January 2025, in the evening, at the call of a coalition including Jusos, the GJ, '#wirsinddiebrandmauer', 'Together Against the Right' (Zusammen gegen rechts) and other organizations and civil society groups, between 240 and 800 people gathered at the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far right-ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Standup Against Racism; Women (Germany)
description: On 27 January 2025, at the call of local groups, including Grannies Against the Right and Standup Against Racism, people, including the SPD, the 'Cultural Forum Tarmstedt' and 'FAST association', which works on refugee integration in the region, gathered at the KSG school in Tarmstedt (Niedersachsen) to protest against the AfD during a panel discussion featuring Marie-Therese Kaiser (AfD), who was convicted for incitement to hatred.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 26 January 2025, under the motto 'Karnevalists Against Fascists', nearly 300 people, including political figures and community members, such as the Seven Mountains Prince and Otto Neuhoff (CDU), the Mayor of Bad Honnef staged a protest in Bad Honnef (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against far-right politics. The event aimed to promote tolerance and diversity, with participants singing and celebrating for peace and unity.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 26 January 2025, in the afternoon, at the call of The Left and various groups, under the motto 'Left Before Right', around 200 people gathered in Eichstatt (Berlin) to protest the far-right shift in society for democratic values.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 25 January 2025, at the call of local citizens' groups, around 3,000 people, including the local mayor from the CDU gathered in Mainburg (Bayern) to protest the downsizing of the Mainburg Hospital. The event aimed to preserve the emergency services, intensive care unit, and inpatient care, as the district council had decided to downgrade the hospital in June 2024.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 25 January 2025, at the call of over 20 civil society groups, around 700 to 1,500 people gathered in Luneburg (Niedersachsen) to demonstrate during an AfD campaign event. Mayors Claudia Kalisch (The Greens) and Christel John (CDU) were also there.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 25 January 2025, at the call of the alliance 'Moers is colorful, not brown' (Moers ist Bunt, nicht Braun), between 400 and 650 people, including The Left, The Greens and the SPD members, gathered in Moers (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest against Friedrich Merz's (CDU) proposed migration plan and far-right ideologies. The event was part of a wider protest movement against far-right politics in response to the CDU's migration plan, which was supported by the AfD.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 22 January 2025, at the call of the 'Leonberg Stays Colorful' initiative (Leonberg bleibt bunt) around 800 people, including local politician Angie Weber-Streibl (The Greens) gathered in Leonberg (Baden-Wurttemberg) to protest against an AfD election campaign event featuring Deputy Federal Chairman Tino Chrupalla (AfD). The event aimed to send a clear message against hate and extremism, emphasizing the commitment to peaceful activism and human rights.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 20 January 2025, workers of Thyssenkrupp Steel staged a protest in Duisburg (Nordrhein-Westfalen) demanding the preservation of jobs and the future of the steel industry. The event emphasized the importance of securing a sustainable and competitive future for the company amid industry challenges. Federal Labor Minister Hubertus Heil (SPD) visited the vigil alongside various Duisburg SPD politicians and Mayor Soren Link (SPD) to demonstrate political support for the workers' demands.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 19 January 2025, around 150 people, including members from various political parties, including SPD, The Greens, The Left, along with DGB members, Grannies Against the Right, staged a protest in Pfeffelbach (Rheinland-Pfalz) against the AfD, expressing concern over the party's influence in the region and its policies.

organizers: Antifa; FFF: Fridays for Future; LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Standup Against Racism; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 19 January 2025, at the call of the Antifascist Alliance, Fridays for Future, Standup Against Racism, the 'Peace initiative Traunstein' (Friedensinitiative Traunstein), 'Queer Traunstein', 'Nature Friends Trostberg' (Naturfreunde Trostberg), the 'Initiative for Refugee Rights', under the motto 'Bergen stays colorful! We set a sign against right-wing hate' and members of the Greens Party and SPD, the Left, under the motto 'No space for the AfD!' people gathered in Bergen (Niedersachsen) to protest against an event held by the AfD.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 19 January 2025, in the morning, around 30 AfD supporters staged a protest with placards outside the Greens Party's New Year's reception in Weilheim in Oberbayern (Bayern). Meanwhile, AfD opponents demonstrated nearby, carrying banners.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 17 January 2025, at the call of the 'Colorful instead of brown' alliance (bunt statt braun), people, including, among others, trade unions, churches, and regional associations of the Greens, SPD, and the Left Party, around 1,400 people staged a protest in Hannover (Niedersachsen) against the AfD. The event featured signs reading 'No vote for the enemies of democracy.'

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 15 January 2025, six mayors from Nordsachsen and the Elbe-Elster district, alongside around 200 to 300 participants, among them CDU affiliates, held a protest and press conference at Falkenberg/Elster (Brandenburg) train station, against the planned cancellation of the city train line S4 between Torgau and Falkenberg. The ZVNL, the Special-purpose association for the Leipzig local transport region, cited financial reasons for reducing the service, which led to protesters emphasizing the negative impact on local infrastructure and the rural area's economy.

organizers: Antifa; Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 13 January 2025, at the call of various leftist groups, including the 'Initiative against AfD and Racism' (Initiative gegen die AfD und Rassismus) and the 'Antifascist Initiative' (Antifaschistische Initiative), around 150 people, including Jusos, gathered in Saarbrucken (Saarland) to commemorate the 'Day of Shame' and demand a ban on the AfD party. The participants formed a '90' using red candles to symbolize the 90th anniversary of the 'Saarabstimmung' (Saar Plebiscite), where nearly 91% voted for Hitler-Germany.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 11 January 2025, in the evening, at the call of the the youth wing of the MLPD, people gathered in Gelsenkirchen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest in solidarity with the Palestinian population. The event highlighted their stance against imperialism and drew attention to international solidarity movements.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 11 January 2025, people, including The Greens members and politicians from other parties gathered in Neuperlach district in Munchen (Bayern) in response to an attack on the Greens campaign stand. The event served as both a protest and a show of support for Andre Herrmann's (The Greens) campaign. Participants expressed their determination to continue democratic engagement despite the earlier aggression.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 11 January 2025, over 200 people, including Mayor Olaf Kuhl ('WiR fur Danischenhagen') and second deputy mayor Katrin Ameskamp (The Greens) gathered in Danischenhagen (Schleswig-Holstein) to protest for democracy and diversity and called to resist extremism and protect democratic principles.

organizers: Antifa; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FFF: Fridays for Future; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); Students (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 11 January 2025, at the call of a broad democratic coalition, including groups like Grannies Against the Right, Fridays for Future, DGB, the 'Unemployed Initiative' (Arbeitsloseninitiative), The Left, and the Antifa, over 300 people gathered in Zetel (Niedersachsen) to protest the AfD's right-wing populist policies. Demonstrators aimed to express their rejection of hate, discrimination, and xenophobia, sending a message for tolerance and democratic values.

organizers: Former Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 10 January 2025, at the call of the 'Peace Initiative Holzkirchen' (Friedensinitiative Holzkirchen) and Wolfgang Huber, a former long-time SPD municipal councilor, under the motto 'For Peace, for Life', over 100 people gathered in Holzkirchen (Bayern) to participate in a peace vigil. Protesters lit a fire in a brazier next to the war memorial to honor victims of wars. The focus was on reflection and interaction, with songs like the protest anthem 'We Shall Overcome'.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany
description: On 6 January 2025, people, including CDU District Chairman and Bundestag candidate Steffen Roschek, gathered for a protest organized by the 'Vigil Bautzen' in Bautzen (Sachsen), focusing on issues such as coronavirus, energy policies, and the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

organizers: Alevi Muslim Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Turkish Group (Germany)
description: On 4 January 2025, around 50 to 70 people gathered for a protest organized by various political groups, including FEDA - Federation of Democratic Alevis e.V. and MLPD Rhein-Neckar, at Paradeplatz in Mannheim (Baden-Wurttemberg), raising awareness about the attacks on Christian and Alevi communities in Syria, and expressing solidarity with the people of Rojava.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 30 December 2024, several hundred people gathered for a protest in Cottbus (Brandenburg), organized by Jean-Pascal Hohm, a local AfD member of the state parliament, and supported by Hans-Christoph Berndt, the AfD faction leader in Brandenburg, against Germany's migration policy, demanding the halt of 'mass immigration,' 'improved border security', as well as increased deportation. At the same time, a few dozen people demonstrated nearby against the AfD.

organizers: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 28 December 2024, around 400 people gathered for a protest organized by the Kurdish Association and supported by, among others, youth from the autonomous movement, the Left and MLPD affiliates and feminist activists, in Bonn (Nordrhein-Westfalen), in solidarity with the democratic self-governance in Syria and Kurdish liberation efforts as well as against the Turkish military actions.

organizers: Alevi Muslim Group (Germany); Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Turkish Group (Germany); VVN-BdA: Association of Persecutees of the Nazi Regime/Federation of Antifascists
description: On 28 December 2024, around 100 people gathered for a protest, organized by the MLPD Velbert, in cooperation with the Kurdish Association and supported by groups such as the VVN-BdA, 'the Unyielding' ('Die Unbeugsamen - Linke Sammlungsbewegung'), the Alevitic Association, and others, in Velbert (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against the ongoing attacks on Rojava, condemning the Turkish government's actions and the German government's silence, while also expressing solidarity with the Syrian people's struggle for liberation.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 23 December 2024, at the call of the AfD, people gathered in Friedrichshafen (Baden-Wurttemberg) for a 'memorial vigil' at the local Christmas market in response to the Magdeburg attack, where a car drove into a crowd at the Magdeburg Christmas market, killing five people and injuring 200 others. The protesters demanded changes in migration policy. Meanwhile, at the call of Antifa, a counter-demonstration with around 50 people took place. Antifa accused the AfD of exploiting the tragedy for political purposes.

organizers: Journalists (Germany); Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 23 December 2024, at the call of Kurdish writers and journalists' associations, around 90 people, including the MLPD and members of the Kurdish community, including many children and youths, staged a protest in Essen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against Turkish army attacks on Rojava in Northern Syria, particularly Kobane. The protesters demanded an end to 'genocide' in northern Syria and called on the German government to pressure Turkey.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 21 December 2024, hundreds of people, including representatives from SPD, The Greens, CDU, FDP, The Left, and Grannies Against the Right gathered at Lichterfelde Ost station in Berlin - Steglitz-Zehlendorf (Berlin) to protest against right-wing ideologies following a neo-Nazi attack, where 15 suspected neo-Nazis assaulted four SPD campaign workers. The protesters emphasized the need for unity, democracy, and resistance against hate and violence, chanting slogans like 'We are more'.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 20 December 2024, at the call of the Botersen mayor Cord Trefke (CDU) people gathered in front of the town hall in Sottrum (Niedersachsen) to protest against Tennet's decision to build a new substation at the Sottrum 2 location. The protest involved tractors and banners highlighting dissatisfaction with the site selection process, amidst debates on environmental impacts and land use conflicts with wind energy projects.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); Evangelical Christian Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 19 December 2024, around 40 people, including Catholic and Evangelical Churches members, The Left politicians, and refugee aid volunteers, gathered outside the Town Hall in Juterbog (Brandenburg) to protest against AfD Mayor Arne Raue, criticizing his alignment with a party under scrutiny for extremism and to protest for openness and diversity.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 19 December 2024, at the call of the mayor of Angermunde (SPD), along with the Ver.di and the Marburger Bund doctors' association, over 1,200 people staged a protest in Angermunde (Brandenburg) against the planned closure of the hospital's Internal Medicine department. Participants gathered to show solidarity for the hospital, amidst plans by the GLG municipal hospital company to restructure it into a purely psychiatric facility.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 December 2024, around 800 employees of Rasselstein gathered for a protest vigil in Andernach (Rheinland-Pfalz) to raise awareness about the potential job cuts at their parent company, Thyssenkrupp, while demanding better participation in decision-making. The protest was organized by Rasselstein employees and supported by local politicians, including Rheinland-Pfalz Minister-President Alexander Schweitzer, Health Minister Clemens Hoch, and Sabine Batzing-Lichtenthaler, all from the SPD.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 14 December 2024, around 1,000 people gathered in the city center of Frankfurt am Main (Hessen) for a protest under the theme 'Solidarity with the Syrian Revolution,' , organized by various activist groups and supported by MLPD Rhein-Main along with other leftist organizations.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Seebruecke; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Volt Europa
description: On 9 December 2024, at the call of Volt Europa, with support from various societal initiatives and political parties, including the SPD, CSU, The Greens, FDP, FW, 'Nafo' (North Atlantic Fella Organization), and Seebruecke Dachau, around 200 people gathered in Dachau (Bayern) to protest in support of Ukraine.

organizers: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 9 December 2024, at the call of the MLPD and Kurdish activists, under the motto 'Stop the attacks on Rojava - For the immediate stop of the Turkish state's invasion of Rojava!', around 120 people, including members of the Kurdish community, leftist youth, and members of The Left and MLPD Rhein-Neckar staged a protest in front of the main train station in Mannheim (Baden-Wurttemberg) condemning Turkey's military actions and criticizing the German government's cooperation with Turkey.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 2 December 2024, people affiliated with several political organizations, among them mayor Stafan Kattari (SPD), and further alliances, including the newly formed Standing Up Against Racism (AGR), organized a protest against an election campaign event held by the Rosenheimer AfD in Grassau (Bayern), raising awareness and expressing opposition to the AfD's policies and values, with the organizers advocating for unity against racism.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 30 November 2024, more than 100 people, including men and women, gathered at Grosflecken in Neumunster (Schleswig-Holstein) for a protest advocating for a non-violent understanding of masculinity. Organized by a coalition of political and social groups, including the SPD, the Zonta Club Neumunster, and the local equality office, the event highlighted the need to address violence, particularly against women, predominantly committed by men.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 30 November 2024, around 600 people, organized by the Jusos and the Green Youth, staged a protest on the Rathausplatz in Ludwigsburg (Baden-Wurttemberg) against a planned meeting of the far-right group Reconquista 21.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 28 November 2024, at the call of the alliance Democracy Lives! (Demokratie leben!), Grannies Against the Right and the Youth Parliament, around 100 people, including Mayor Heiner Pahlmann (SPD), participated in a light demonstration in Bramsche (Niedersachsen) to raise awareness against far-right ideology, racism, and queerphobia while promoting diversity and democracy. Participants carried candles, lanterns, and light chains as they marched through the city, with speeches emphasizing the importance of tolerance and community.

organizers: IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 27 November 2024, people, including MLPD and IGM affiliates, joined a protest vigil in Bonn (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against TKSE layoffs.

organizers: DKP: German Communist Party; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; The Left (Germany); VVN-BdA: Association of Persecutees of the Nazi Regime/Federation of Antifascists
description: On 26 November 2024, at the call of local groups, including the 'Gelsenkirchen Peace Forum' (Friedensforum Gelsenkirchen), The Left, DKP, VVN-BdA, 'AUF Gelsenkirchen', MLPD, and REBELL, around 50 people gathered in Gelsenkirchen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest against the 'Zeitenwende on Tour' event organized by the Munich Security Conference. The demonstrators condemned militarism, reactionary policies, and the normalization of imperialist and monopolistic agendas. They called for unity against war, fascism, and the threat of a Third World War.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Women (Germany)
description: On 25 November 2024, on the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, at the call of the Social Sevice of Catholic Women (SkF), the municipal Women's office, and the Soroptimists, around 30 women and a few men, including Mayor Dag Wehner (CDU), gathered in Fulda (Hessen) to protest against violence against women, including domestic violence, cyberbullying, and call for more women's shelter spaces in the region.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Students (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 25 November 2024, at the call of several entities, including FFF, GJ, Jusos, and Grannies Against the Right, around 700 people protested in Potsdam (Brandenburg) against right-wing extremism and racist migration policies, marking the one-year anniversary of a meeting between right-wing politicians and Identitarian Movement leader Martin Sellner, where the concept of 'Remigration'-the forced expulsion of foreign nationals-was discussed.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Former Government of Germany (2021-); FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 24 November 2024, around 170 to 180 people, including local councilors Anton Huber (BLD, a local citizens' group), Thomas Bachmeier (CSU), and Bernhard Fuchs (FW), along with former mayor Leni Grobmaier (FW), gathered in Bairawies, a district of Dietramszel (Bayern), to protest against plans to build a container settlement for approximately 130 asylum seekers in their village. Demonstrators expressed concerns about the strain on the small village of 280 residents, stating they were not against asylum seekers but opposed to what they viewed as the unsustainable scale of the planned accommodation.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Iran)
description: On 23 November 2024, at the call of 'Iranian Revolutionaries from the Council of Socialists and Freethinkers' (Iranische Revolutionare vom Rat der Sozialisten und Freidenker) Hamburg and Fedaian-Minderheit, people, including MLPD and ICOR - International Coordination of Revolutionary Parties and Organizations affiliates, gathered at the Sternschanze station in Hamburg - Altona (Hamburg) to oppose executions in Iran, highlighting the sharp rise in execution numbers, including many political prisoners. Protesters expressed solidarity with political prisoners, particularly those resisting within Iranian prisons, and called for freedom and socialism, emphasizing that the fight against executions is part of a global struggle against capitalism and fascism.

organizers: EU: European Union; Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 23 November 2024, at the call of the group 'Cut Off Tesla's Supply' (Tesla den Hahn abdrehen), people, including The Left MEP Carola Rackete, gathered near the Tesla factory in Grunheide (Mark) (Brandenburg) to protest against the factory's expansion, citing concerns about groundwater risks and deforestation, following the recent police clearing of a protest camp. Nine people were issued with removal orders for violating a ban on entering the area, and their details were recorded by the authorities.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; Labor Group (Germany); Police Forces of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 21 November 2024, around 40 people, including the SPD, The Greens and AWO members, gathered in Uetze (Niedersachsen), to protest against violence against women and girls on the Hindenburgplatz by blowing whistles. The event coincided with the weekly market and included informational stands by police, local organizations, and advocacy groups to raise awareness and provide resources for victims.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 21 November 2024, under the motto 'Together for peace', over 30 people, including members of the DGB, The Left and UtopiAA, gathered at the Aalener Marktbrunnen in Aalen (Baden-Wurttemberg), to protest for peace in the Middle East and Ukraine and for disarmament, including calls for an immediate ceasefire, as well as promoting a respectful and peaceful coexistence.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 21 November 2024, members of the SPD and The Greens gathered in Wiesenbach (Baden-Wurttemberg), to protest against an AfD information stand. Demonstrators were ordered to disperse by the police.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 19 November 2024, around 500 people, including members of the Ukrainian community, attended a protest in Koln (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to mark the 1000th day of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Organized by the German-Ukrainian association 'Blue-Yellow-Cross,' the protest called for increased weapons deliveries to Ukraine. The event featured speeches by Cologne Mayor Andreas Wolter (Greens), NRW Deputy Prime Minister Mona Neubaur (Greens), and Julia Chenusha (CEO of Blue-Yellow-Cross). A symbolic procession included a destroyed Ukrainian ambulance on a trailer, highlighting the devastation caused by Russian aggression.

organizers: Human Environment Animal Protection Party; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; OEDP: Ecological Democratic Party; The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 17 November 2024, various groups, including the Environmental Union Stuttgart, Women's Association Courage, the IAC, an International Automotive Workers' Conference, the OEDP, MLPD, Animal Protection Party, Left Party members, and the anti-S21 movement, held a climate protest at the Schlossplatz in Stuttgart (Baden-Wurttemberg). The event featured music and cultural performances, highlighting the environmental crisis, its disproportionate impact on women, and rising police violence against activists. Participants criticized capitalism for driving ecological destruction and called for solidarity and socialism as solutions.

organizers: BSW: Sahra Wagenknecht Alliance - Reason and Justice; Free Saxony
description: On 17 November 2024, around 250 people gathered in Gorlitz (Sachsen), at the call of the BSW and the far-right Free Saxony, to oppose the relocation of defense production to the Alstom factory. The march began at the Alstom plant and ended at Marienplatz, passing a counter-protest of 35 participants organized by the Youth organization of The Left (Germany), who opposed the far-right influence. One participant from the BSW-Freie Sachsen protest verbally insulted a counterdemonstrator. Police got involved, but then reported a calm overall situation.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 16 November 2024, about 500 people joined a pro-Palestine protest in Berlin - Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf (Berlin), organized by pro-Palestinian groups with support from Mera25 and the Youth Organization of the Left (Germany) Berlin-Wedding, under the slogan 'Solidarity with Palestine. Stop the Gaza Genocide.' Demonstrators used fireworks, flares, and banned slogans. Police arrested 111 people for offenses, including incitement. A small pro-Israel counterprotest also occurred.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 16 November 2024, around 1,300 people, including a delegation from the MLPD, participated in protests, marching from Ketsch's market square to the Rheinhalle, against the AfD state party congress in Ketsch (Baden-Wurttemberg), organized by the Alliance for Democracy and Diversity Kurpfalz and the Federation of Anti-Fascists District Association Heidelberg. The event highlighted antifascist unity and democratic participation, alongside discussions about fascism, environmental issues, and global conflicts, including the situation in Gaza.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 15 November 2024, around 50 people, including CSU Member of Parliament Alexander Dietrich and CSU City Councillor Hans Theiss, gathered in the district of Feldmoching in Munchen (Bayern), to protest against the planned construction of a refugee accommodation on a greenfield site at Schrederwiese and to oppose the project citing lack of integration opportunities, infrastructure, and environmental concerns.

organizers: Labor Group (Germany); Teachers (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 14 November 2024, employees of kindergartens, supported by the trade union Ver.di, continued their protest against difficult working conditions in local daycare centers, staff shortages and overwork at the Dreiringstrasse/Bochumer Strasse intersection in the district of Steele in Essen (Nordrhein-Westfalen). The protest included a speech by Silas Haake Tthe Greens), a member of the Essen city council.

organizers: Farmers (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 14 November 2024, several hundred people, including over 50 tractors from local farmers, protested in Herford (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against the planned ICE route between Bielefeld and Hannover. Organized by the agricultural district association OWL, the protest outside the Marta Museum highlighted concerns over land loss, farm viability, and environmental issues. Local politicians, such as County Commissioner Jurgen Muller (SPD) and Vlotho Mayor Rocco Wilken (SPD) supported the event and also called for changes to the current route.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 9 November 2024, at the call of the group 'Wismar for everyone' (Wismar fur alle), under the motto 'For a Wismar without hate and incitement - for an AfD ban now,' around 330 people, including Wismar's mayor Thomas Beyer (SPD), gathered in Wismar (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern), to protest for a ban on the AfD marking the anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and the Pogrom Night.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 9 November 2024, at the call of 'Friends' Circle Hannover' (Freundeskreis Hannover) and the initiative 'Colorful instead of brown' (bunt statt braun), under the motto 'Strengthen Democracy', around 1,000 people, including local politicians and community leaders, including Mayor Belit Onay (The Greens) gathered in front of the state parliament in Hannover (Niedersachsen), to protest against exclusion, antisemitism, and right-wing ideologies.

organizers: Anarchist Group (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); Students (Germany); The Left.SDS; Women (Germany)
description: On 5 November 2024, around 60 people gathered to disrupt a lecture at the University of Leipzig (Sachsen) about prostitution. The protest was organized by various groups, including the Queerfeminist Group Leipzig, the Open Anarchist Network Leipzig, and the Left.SDS, in response to transphobic statements made by the speaker, Inge Kleine, associated with the Sisters E.V. organization. The protest led to a large police presence, which, after being called by the university, detained and identified the participants for several hours before issuing charges for trespassing. The student body criticized the police's actions, describing the measures as overly repressive.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 4 November 2024, around 1,500 people gathered in Rostock (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) for a protest against queerphobia, following an arson attack on the queer bar 'B7.' The protesters, marching through the city center, showed solidarity with the LGBTQ+ community. The protest was organized by the CSD Rostock, with support from various local politicians, including Mayor Eva-Maria Kroger (Left Party), who raised the rainbow flag over the city hall.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Women (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 3 November 2024, around 20 members of Grannies for Future along with supporters, including Friedrich Lange and Lisa Pazzini from the local Green Party, gathered in Germering (Bayern) for a protest to raise awareness about climate change and the planned gas drilling in Reichling near Lake Ammersee. The protest ended with the symbolic marking of a yellow 'X' on the sidewalk, representing opposition to gas drilling.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 3 November 2024, around 300 residents and activists, supported by the Alliance for Affordable Housing, held a protest in the Golzheim neighborhood in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to oppose property owners' tactics to evict tenants and transform the area for more profitable rental opportunities. They marched past multiple buildings where tenants fear displacement due to luxury renovations. A group of activists occupied vacant apartments on Bankstrase. SPD Bundestag member Zanda Martens attended the protest, calling on local authorities to enforce existing regulations more rigorously to protect residents from displacement.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 1 November 2024, an unreported number of people gathered for a protest, organized by 'Let Women Speak' in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) against the recently passed Self-Determination Act, which aims to grant more rights to non-binary and trans* people. The demonstration featured Helen Joyce, a feminist known for promoting transphobia and antisemitic conspiracy theories, as one of the key speakers. Joyce, along with other protesters, argued that the law posed a danger to women and children, particularly in terms of altering gender markers for minors and allowing trans women access to women-only spaces. The protest was supported by far-right groups, including the AfD, and other conservative factions, who oppose the Self-Determination Act.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 26 October 2024, over 100 people, including members of the MLPD, participated in a pro-Palestinian demonstration in Schwerin (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern), condemning Israel's actions and calling for solidarity with both the Palestinian and Israeli working classes, emphasizing the need for an end to the war. The protesters marched through the city chanting slogans like 'Free, free Palestine!'.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 25 October 2024, around 90 people, including the MLPD gathered at the Pfaffenteich in Schwerin (Mescklenburg-Vorpommern) for a Pro-Palestine demonstration, calling for an end to the war and highlighting 75 years of Palestinian oppression.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 25 October 2024, people, including local district mayor Bastian Stein (AfD) staged a protest in Jena (Thuringen) to denounce the spraying of pain on the 'Fraternity Arminia' (Burschenschaft Arminia) headquarters.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 22 October 2024, around 70 people gathered for a protest on the fringes of the 'Bodensee Business Forum' (BBF) organized by Schwabisch Media in Friedrichshafen (Baden-Wurttemberg), to oppose military support for Ukraine. The protest was primarily organized by the local chapter of the AfD, with participants criticizing calls for increased weaponry. Simultaneously, a counter-protest organized by 'Youth Fights,' with 'Antifascist Action' affiliates, consisting of around 25 participants, took place nearby, advocating for 'global disarmament' and opposing imperialism on both sides of the conflict, and opposing right-wing peace-mongering.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 21 October 2024, hundreds of people, including mayors and local officials, gathered in Stuttgart to protest the planned closure of emergency medical practices in Baden-Wurttemberg. Organized in response to an announcement by the KVBW (Association of Statutory Health Insurance Physicians), the protest took place outside its headquarters. The KVBW plans to shut down 18 emergency practices across the region due to a medical staff shortage, redirecting resources to bolster remaining facilities. A nine-member delegation from Mullheim, led by Mayor Martin Loffler (SPD), participated, as the closure will require residents to travel to Freiburg or Lorrach for emergency care.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; PEGIDA: Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamisation of the Occident
description: On 20 October 2024, around 500 supporters of the far-right PEGIDA movement gathered at the Neumarkt in Dresden (Sachsen) for the group's final demonstration, marking the end of a decade of anti-Islam and anti-immigration protests led by PEGIDA's founder, Lutz Bachmann. Meanwhile there was a similarly sized counter-protest of around more than 500 participants organized nearby, including groups like 'Heart Instead of Hate.' The police launched investigations into some PEGIDA supporters for using prohibited symbols and counter-protesters for masking their identities. Lutz Bachmann, addressing supporters from a truck, announced PEGIDA's plans to pursue 'new formats' and continue influencing Germany's 'patriotic movement.' The event concluded with speeches from AfD politicians Hans-Christoph Berndt and Christina Baum.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 18 October 2024, people, including a representative of the Left Party, gathered for a protest in HafenCity, in front of the HVV headquarters on Brooktorkai, in Hamburg (Hamburg), opposing a recent ban on begging in Hamburg's metro and city train stations.

organizers: Antifa; Former Government of Germany (2021-); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 October 2024, around 80 people, including Antifa members from Flensburg and SPD politicians, including Kirsten Eickhoff-Weber (former Vice President of the Schleswig-Holstein state parliament) and Thorsten Klimm (local council member), gathered for a protest in front of the Hotel 'Seeblick' in Muhbrook (Schleswig-Holstein) against an event featuring former AfD state chairwoman Doris von Sayn-Wittgenstein, who was speaking on 'law and order in the party,' denouncing her presence and expressing their stance against the far-right ideologies of the AfD. Protesters were peacefully relocated by the police across the street from the hotel.

organizers: DBB: German Civil Service Federation; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Judges (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 October 2024, around 250 employees from labor and social courts, including many judges and representatives from social organizations, gathered for a protest organized by the DGB in front of the Landeshaus in Kiel (Schleswig-Holstein). They opposed a proposed court reform put forth by Schleswig-Holstein's Justice Minister, Kerstin von der Decken (CDU). Among the speakers and supporters from various political parties and social organizations were Kiel's Mayor Ulf Kampfer (SPD), FDP affiliates, members of the Social Welfare Organizations, the Judges' Association, and the DBB Civil Service Union. When Kerstin von der Decken addressed the crowd, she was met with boos, whistles, and groans, prompting her to leave the stage.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 7 October 2024, 20 members of the local Greens among them also Green Youth affiliates, gathered for a protest outside the Kirchseeon (Bayern) town hall to advocate for increased tree protection in the municipality, especially in light of the ongoing climate crisis. This protest occurred prior to a council meeting where previous discussions on the matter had been cut short when the CSU-affiliated mayor, Jan Paeplow, muted the Green Party spokesperson, Natalie Katholing.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); DIG: German-Israeli Society; Government of Germany (2021-); Israeli Group (Germany); Jewish Group (Germany); Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 6 October 2024, around 1,000 people gathered for a protest titled 'March of Life' against antisemitism and to commemorate the 7 October 2023 and its victims at Graf-Adolf-Platz in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen). The event, as part of the initiative 'Run for their lives,' was organized by the Jewish Community of Dusseldorf in collaboration with various local organizations, such as the Jewish Student Union NRW, Society for Christian-Jewish Cooperation in Dusseldorf, the DIG in Dusseldorf, and Kehila NRW. The Deputy Minister of Nordrhein-Westfalen (Coalition 90/the Greens), and a City Councilor (the Greens) were present.

organizers: Lebanese Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Palestinian Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 6 October 2024, around 150 people, including members of the Palestinian and Lebanese communities, members of the MLPD and The Left, gathered at the town hall square in Salzgitter (Niedersachsen) to protest in solidarity with Palestine and Lebanon. The protesters criticized the German government and the Israeli government and called for an end to Israeli military operations.

organizers: Antifa; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FFF: Fridays for Future; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Greenpeace; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Students (Germany); Teachers (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 5 October 2024, around 2,000 people gathered for a protest against the meeting of the AfD state association, to start drawing up the list for the Bundestag election, in Ulm (Baden-Wurttemberg). The event, organized by a coalition of various groups, including 'Clear edge against the right Ulm', Greenpeace Ulm, and the Left Ulm, Grannies Against the Right, parents4future, REBELL, and Antifa members united front against far-right politics. Actors and actresses from the theater, teachers, representatives of unions, such as DGB Youth and the Youth section of the Federation of Democratic Workers Association (DIDF), and representatives of political parties, such the MLPD, were present. Ernst-Wilhelm Gohl, Protestant regional bishop and former dean of Ulm Minster, also gave a speech.

organizers: BSW: Sahra Wagenknecht Alliance - Reason and Justice; Government of Germany (2021-); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 3 October 2024, at least 10,000 people gathered for a protest organized by the alliance 'War Never Again' in Berlin - Mitte(Berlin). The protest aimed at opposing the deployment of US missiles in Germany, the war in Ukraine and the Middle East, and Germany's arms supplies to Ukraine and Israel. Key speakers included Sahra Wagenknecht (BSW), Ralf Stegner (SPD), and Gesine Lotzsch (Linke). A variety of groups joined the protest, including a protest bloc of pro-Palestine protesters. In contrast, several counter-protests occurred nearby, such as one organized by the German Peace Community (DFG-VK), with a smaller group of activists dressed in black and wearing skull masks, who protested in front of the Russian embassy earlier in the day. They criticized the main protest for including far-rights elements, with messages like 'Russia is waging a war of aggression.' Additionally, several hundred participants, including members of the SPD and the group 'Vitsche - Activists Empowering Ukraine,' advocated for support of Ukraine and condemned Russia's actions. These counter-protests emphasized their stance against what they labeled 'pseudo pacifism' of the main protest.

organizers: DIG: German-Israeli Society; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Government of Israel (2022-); Israeli Group (Germany); Protesters (Israel)
description: On 2 October 2024, around 200 people gathered for a pro-Israel solidarity rally in front of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin). The Israeli ambassador to Germany, Ron Prosor, criticized Germany's recent abstention in the UN General Assembly and called for stronger backing of Israel's right to self-defense. Federal Justice Minister Marco Buschmann (FDP) also emphasized that standing on the side of justice means standing with Israel, and the German-Israeli Society urged the approval of all Israeli arms export requests.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Former Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 30 September 2024, around 500 people, including the former mayor Matthias Ruhdorfer (CSU), and members of The Greens and SPD, gathered in Schaftlarn (Bayern), to protest for the construction of a safe bicycle path between Ebenhausen and Icking.

organizers: Seebruecke; The Left (Germany)
description: On 28 September 2024, at the call of the Seebruecke initiative, The Left, and the Working Group 'Hamburg Asylum' (Hamburgasyl), between 300 and 400 people gathered at Hansa Square in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg), to protest in support of asylum rights and against the German government's refugee policies. The protesters condemned border closures, the tightening of asylum laws, and the recently proposed security package.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 28 September 2024, around 250 The Greens members gathered in Wilhelmsburg in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg), to protest unity ahead of the upcoming state elections on 2 March, amidst dissatisfaction with the party's direction and recent policy decisions.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 28 September 2024, at the call of The Greens and 'Alboffensive', around 90 people gathered in Balingen (Baden-Wurttemberg), to protest against an AfD event, highlighting the importance of compassion and critical engagement with history.

organizers: FVC: Women Association Courage; Last Generation (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Women (Germany)
description: On 21 September 2024, as part of the city's Sustainability Day and at the call of HN4Future, Last Generation, FVC, MLPD, and REBELL, around 60 environmental activists took to the streets of Heilbronn (Baden-Wurttemberg) to demand more climate action.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 19 September 2024, around 200 people participated in a protest, organized by several groups, including the Working Group Asylum (Arbeitskreis Asyl), the Green Alternative List, the SPD Markgroningen, and the Alliance Against the Right Ludwigsburg, against an AfD event, a citizens' dialogue in the city hall, in Markgroningen (Baden-Wurttemberg).

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 14 September 2024, at the call of the AfD, several hundred people gathered in Prenzlau (Brandenburg), to protest against Chancellor Olaf Scholz (CDU) during his visit as part of his 'summer tour' through Brandenburg. The event included chants like 'Scholz must go'.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 11 September 2024, at the call of the IGM, under the motto 'Future or Resistance!', around 1,000 ZF Wabco employees and supporters, including mayor Belit Onay (The Greens), and 'Volkswagen Commercial Vehicles' (Volkswagen Nutzfahrzeuge), gathered outside the company's facility in Hannover (Niedersachsen), to protest against ZF's plan to cut up to 14,000 jobs nationwide, which they view as a severe attack on workers and a result of poor management decisions.

organizers: IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 10 September 2024, at the call of ZF's WABCO employees, IGM, and SPD, around 170 vehicles participated in a protest convoy in Mannheim (Baden-Wurttemberg) against a restructuring plan and the possible closure of multiple plants.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 9 September 2024, at the call of AfD, 22 people gathered on Alte Poststrasse in Bassum (Niedersachsen) for 'peace, freedom, and self-determination'. Around 200 people gathered for a counter-protest, including locals and activists opposing far-right ideologies, against the AfD, in support of democracy, and against the far-right.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Former Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 8 September 2024, more than 100 people, among them former city councilor Maria Rohl (CSU), gathered for a protest against the construction of 51 new wind turbines in Kottgeisering near Furstenfeldbruck (Bayern). The protesters expressed concerns over environmental impacts, including the destruction of local forests and harm to biodiversity. They displayed banners with slogans such as 'No to 51 wind turbines within a 15-kilometer radius' and criticized the alleged inefficiency and unsustainability of the project.

organizers: Antifa; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); The Left (Germany); VVN-BdA: Association of Persecutees of the Nazi Regime/Federation of Antifascists; Women (Germany)
description: On 8 September 2024, around 200 people protested in Prenzlau (Brandenburg) as part of the 'Hinterland means resistance' protest against racism, organized by the Autonomous Prenzlau Gang (Autonome Bande Prenzlau), Antifa Uckermark, and VVN-BdA Uckermark. The protest included a variety of antifascist groups, members of antifascist youth groups, of the 'Stand up Against Racism' (Aufstehen gegen Rassismus), of 'Solidarity Alliance against the Right' (Solidarischen Bundnis gegen Rechts), and of Grannies Against the Right. It was reported that a party flag of The Left could be seen. The protest was a response to the significant support for the AfD in local elections and the anticipated rise in far-right influence, emphasizing the need for continued resistance. A small group of neo-Nazis gathered for a counter-protest.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 7 September 2024, about 100 participants from the left spectrum joined a protest in Frankfurt (Oder) (Brandenburg), organized by the alliance 'Frankfurt stays colorful,' to support democracy and oppose far-right ideology and activity. The event, themed 'Stay Stable - Together for Democracy,' included a march through the city, included organizers urging all democratic parties to maintain a coalition barrier against the party, and was followed by a Democracy Festival featuring music and discussions. SPD member of parliament Mathias Papendieck took part, as did city councillor Jan Augustyniak from the Left Party, Matthias Steinfurth, SPD city councillor, and direct candidate in constituency 35/Frankfurt (Oder) in the state elections. Four neo-Nazis gathered to counter-demonstrate and eventually pushed security. But no detail regarding the intensity of the pushing or physical interaction was given. The neo-Nazis stayed the rest of the evening close to the police.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); Seebruecke; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 6 September 2024, around 300 people gathered in Husum (Schleswig-Holstein) for a protest organized by a broad coalition of local parties and organizations, including the Greens, SPD, SSW, Seebrucke, DGB Schleswig-Holstein Nordwest, Diakonisches Werk Husum, Aidshilfe Nordfriesland, and various regional groups, to expressed their commitment to democracy and opposition to the AfD's policies, using the event to emphasize their stance against far-right politics and support for democratic values. The protest took place on the Husumer Marktplatz and aimed to provide an alternative citizen dialogue in response to an AfD event scheduled later in Sonnebull.

organizers: Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; LGBTQ+ (Germany)
description: On 6 September 2024, around 400 people participated in a protest for diversity and acceptance at the Burgerturmplatz in Albstadt (Baden-Wurttemberg). Organized by Jusos Zollernalb and the youth initiative 'Immerwaslos,' the event marked the first Christopher Street Day (CSD) in the area. Concurrently, a counter-protest, led by far-right groups such as 'Young Nationalists' and 'Zollern-Youth Active,' was staged, with around 70 participants marching through nearby streets.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 5 September 2024, around 800 people gathered in the city center of Freising (Bayern) for a protest against the rise of far-right politics. The protest, organized by the Jusos Freising, the Green Youth, and the Alliance Solidarity Freising, was aimed at expressing opposition to the increasing influence of the AfD and far-right ideology and activity in Germany. The event highlighted concerns about recent election results in Thuringia and Saxony.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany)
description: On 4 September 2024, over 2,000 students from various secondary schools participated in a star march, finally gathering on a stadium parking lot on Bahnhofstrase, in Castrop-Rauxel (Nordrhein-Westfalen). The protest promoted values of democracy, diversity, tolerance, and unity in society. A concluding rally featured speeches from student representatives, the deputy mayor and SPD member Katrin Lasser-Moryson, and Frank Ronge from the local youth council, advocating for the importance of these principles in Germany and Europe.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; Students (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 2 September 2024, under the motto 'Together Against the Right-Wing Normalization', over 1,000 people, including FFF and The Left politicians gathered in Leipzig (Sachsen), to protest against the rise of the AfD following the local elections. The demonstration was in response to the AfD becoming the second strongest party in Sachsen.

organizers: BSW: Sahra Wagenknecht Alliance - Reason and Justice
description: On 1 September 2024, on occasion of the World Peace Day, under the motto 'Capable of Peace, not of War', at the call of BSW, around 50 people, including former pastor Brigitte Neumeister, gathered in Halle (Saale) (Sachsen-Anhalt), to protest for peace over militarization.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 31 August 2024, around 300 people, including Mayor Ralf Kopke (independent), the Greens politicians, and Ibrahim Yetim, President of AWO in the Wesel District, participated in the third Christopher Street Day (CSD) parade in Neukirchen-Vluyn (Nordrhein-Westfalen), to protest for LGBTQ+ rights, marching through the city for equality and tolerance.

organizers: Anarchist Group (Germany); DKP: German Communist Party; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 31 August 2024, hundreds of people, including dockworkers, Ver.di, DKP, MLPD, and Anarchists gathered in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg), to protest against the partial sale of the HHLA port logistics company to MSC. The protest began at the Landungsbrucken and marched to the HHLA headquarters, featuring various leftist and anarchist flags and slogans.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 31 August 2024, at the call of the 'Allgau Pride Association' (Verein Allgau Pride), hundreds of people, including Grannies Against the Right, Mayor Stefan Bosse (CDU), The Greens members, gathered in Kaufbeuren (Bayern), to protest for LGBTQ+ rights on Christopher Street Day (CSD), while promoting tolerance and social unity, celebrating diversity and opposing intolerance in their community.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 29 August 2024, under the motto 'It's too much for us! Lichtenberg is full!', around 200 people attended an AfD rally in Berlin - Lichtenberg (Berlin), to protest against new refugee accommodations. The rally featured speeches from Berlin AfD leader Kristin Brinker and Bundestag member Gottfried Curio, and was accompanied by counter-protests by antifascist groups, members of the Left Party, SPD, and communist youth, to oppose the racist rhetoric of the AfD local politicians.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 28 August 2024, around a dozen people, including Municipal and District Councilor Josef Bierling (CDU), gathered in Hechendorf (Bayern), to protest against the decision by local authorities to stop providing free school bus transportation for children from the fifth grade onwards, citing safety concerns and the potential difficulty of the school route.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 28 August 2024, around 100 pharmacists, as well as Saxony's Minister of Health Petra Kopping (SPD), gathered in Dresden (Sachsen), to protest against the reform plans proposed by Federal Health Minister Karl Lauterbach (SPD). The demonstration was part of a broader effort to address concerns about economic conditions, the requirement for a pharmacist's presence, and the reduction of bureaucratic burdens.

organizers: Antifa; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 25 August 2024, between around 315 people and more than 500 antifascists participated in protests in Solingen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against far-right ideology and activities, following the knife attack in the city on 23 August 2024. One gathering was organized by the 'Wuppertal takes a stand' ('Wuppertal stellt sich quer') coalition, while another one was organized by the MLPD, Youth Association REBELL, and local groups. The two groups did not organize the protest together due to their different views on communism, the aim to preserve and/or abolish the democratic constitutional state, and on carrying a variety of flags at protests. At around 6 pm, around 45 far-right activists, including members of the AfD's youth wing JA, the Young Alternative for Germany, and the party 'Die Heimat,' gathered for a rally, holding banners stating 'Our people first', and criticized Germany's migration policy. The police kept Antifa and far-right protesters apart, although verbal disputes between the two groups occurred.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 25 August 2024, around 11,000 people gathered in Leipzig (Sachsen) for a protest organized by the 'Hand in Hand' alliance, protesting against far-right ideology and activity and advocating for democracy. The event, which took place a week before the state elections, saw participants, including Leipzig's mayor Burkhard Jung (SPD), express concerns about the rise of right-wing parties and emphasize the importance of defending democratic values in daily life.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 23 August 2024, around 200 people gathered in Erlangen (Bayern) to protest against far-right activities and racism. The protest was sparked by an event hosted by the 'SME-Union Middle Franconia' ('Mittelstands-Union Mittelfranken (MU)), which had invited lawyer Ulrich Vosgerau, known for defending persons like AfD member Bjorn Hocke. The 'Action Courage Erlangen' alliance ('Aktion Courage Erlangen') organized the demonstration, evaluating the MU as connected to far-right ideologies. Erlangen's Mayor, Florian Janik (SPD), also spoke at the event, emphasizing the need to stand against the spread of far-right views across the 'mainstream'.

organizers: Antifa; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 20 August 2024, between around 2,000 and 3,000 antifascist protesters, including members of the MLPD, the youth group REBELL, and other organizations, gathered in Jena (Thuringen) at the call of the 'Stop the Shift to the Right' ('Rechtsruck stoppen') alliance, to block a planned appearance by Bjorn Hocke, a prominent AfD politician, at a local community center and to protest against the AfD and Hocke's far-right ideologies. Despite attempts by the police to clear the way, the protesters prevented Bjorn Hocke from attending the event, leading to its cancellation. The event escalated when the police used pepper spray, batons, and physical force, including punches to the face, to break up the protesters' sit-in blockade. This resulted in several injuries among the demonstrators. No arrests were made.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 19 August 2024, people gathered outside the fuel element factory in Lingen (Niedersachsen), to protest against upcoming uranium deliveries from Russia. The Greens politicians, involved in the protest, warned of 'serious security issues and an incalculable risk' associated with these deliveries.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 August 2024, numerous people, including Mayor Stefan Streit (SPD) and Member of Parliament Anja Karliczek (CDU), gathered in Tecklenburg (Nordrhein-Westfalen), to protest against the planned power line through the Teutoburg Forest. The protesters demanded that the high-voltage line be laid underground to protect residential areas and preserve the natural landscape.

organizers: ADFC: German Bicycle Club; Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 17 August 2024, at the call of the NGO 'Changing Cities', 'Respect Cyclists' and ADFC, around 50 cyclists, and the Minister President of Thuringen Bodo Ramelow (The Left), participated in a two-week 'Tour de mobility transition' protest from Eisenach (Thuringen) to Berlin, to protest for better cycling infrastructure and public transportation. The protest aimed to raise awareness about the need for equal infrastructure investment and safer roads for cyclists, with the tour culminating in a final rally at planned Invalidenpark in Berlin on 30 August.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 August 2024, at the call of the SPD, 230 people, including MLPD, protested against AfD member Bjorn Hocke's event in Sonneberg (Thuringen), highlighting opposition to the AfD and its policies.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 August 2024, at the call of The Greens Cochem-Zell, around 60 participants gathered in Cochem (Rheinland-Pfalz), to protest against a right-wing pre-conference event organized by the AfD and to promote tolerance and democracy. The demonstrators aimed to counteract the influence of right-wing ideologies and show support for a diverse and inclusive society.

organizers: Environmental Union; FVC: Women Association Courage; IB: Internationalist Alliance; IGBCE: Industrial Union for Mining, Chemistry and Energy; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; SI: Solidarity International; The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union; Women (Germany)
description: On 17 August 2024, under the motto 'Workers and Unemployed Together Against Fascism and Social Cuts', over 1,000 people, including members of IGM, Ver.di, IGBCE, FVC, IB, Environmental Union, SI, 'Miners for AUF' (Kumpel fur AUF), 'Circle of Friends of Refugee Solidarity' (Freundeskreis Fluchtlingssolidaritat), The Left, MLPD, and REBELL, gathered in Eisenach (Thuringen), to protest against fascism, marking the 20th anniversary of the first Monday demonstration. The event aimed to address social inequalities, oppose fascism, and highlight the struggles of workers and unemployed individuals.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 12 August 2024, around 10 to 20 people, many affiliated with the Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany (MLPD), participated in a protest on Berliner Square in Witten (Nordrhein-Westfalen) as a part of the long-running Monday Demonstrations (Montagsdemo) movement, originally sparked by opposition to the Hartz laws, now addressing broader issues such as social injustice, anti-nuclear sentiments, opposition to coronavirus restrictions, and the Ukraine war.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 8 August 2024, around 40 people participated in a protest, organized by a newly formed initiative called 'Together Against War' (Gemeinsam gegen den Krieg), in Dippoldiswalde (Sachsen) against military escalation and the potential reintroduction of conscription. Furthermore, the participants protested the increased calls by politicians for rearmament and demanded a ban on the German Armed Forces' presence in Saxony schools and job fairs, and the introduction of civil clause in Saxony's universities and colleges to prevent military involvement. The Left party was involved.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 2 August 2024, at the call of The Left, people gathered for a peace demonstration in Pirna (Sachsen), calling for disarmament instead of rearmament. The protest aimed to oppose the planned stationing of US intermediate-range missiles in Germany starting in 2026 and to demand a reduction in military arms.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 31 July 2024, at the call of the 'Peace initiative Eimsbuttel' (Friedensinitiative Eimsbuttel), around 50 people, including members of The Left, gathered outside the Kaifu swimming pool in Hamburg - Eimsbuttel (Hamburg), to protest against an armed forces of the Federal Republic of Germany Bundeswehr recruitment banner displayed at the swimming pool. The participants objected to what they viewed as inappropriate military advertising in a public space meant for leisure.

organizers: The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 27 July 2024, around 50 people, including politicians (The Greens, The Left) and families, demonstrated in the Thekla district in Leipzig (Sachsen) against the far-right following the destruction of a refugee accommodation by a far-right affiliate (coded previously). They called for diversity and to welcome refugees. At the call of the AfD, around 200 people, mostly far-right members (unspecified groups), a CDU politician, and pensioners, gathered for a counter-protest. One counter-protester carried a placard with the message 'Remigration, now'.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 26 July 2024, around 70 people, including a municipal councilor (Greens), rallied in front of the Landgasthof Bruckhof hotel in Emmering (Bayern) to protest against the holding of a political event by the local AfD district branch at the venue, condemning hatred, right-wing extremism, and the prospect of new generations growing up exposed to far-right ideology.

organizers: BSW: Sahra Wagenknecht Alliance - Reason and Justice
description: On 22 July 2024, at the call of the alliance 'Creating Peace Without Weapons' (Frieden Schaffen Ohne Waffen) and BSW, around 50 people rallied and disrupted an SPD election campaign event at a restaurant's outside area in Leipzig (Sachsen) featuring Defense Minister Boris Pistorius, criticizing his support for NATO and military actions, and calling for support for Gaza. Three demonstrators were 'removed' from the audience, though the nature of the intervention, or the actors carrying it out, was not specified.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 21 July 2024, under the motto 'For Human Rights. Many. Together. Strong,', around 1,200,000 to 1,400,000 people, including President of the Bundestag Barbel Bas (SPD), Federal Minister of Health Karl Lauterbach (SPD), and Federal Minister of Culture Claudia Roth (The Grees), took part in a Christopher Street Day parade in Koln (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest for LGBTQ+ rights and diversity, and denounce discrimination against members of the community. Around 13 men rallied and shouted 'right-wing extremist and homophobic' slogans and tore down a rainbow flag during the event.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 21 July 2024, at the call of the initiative 'together.democratic.colorful' (gemeinsam.demokratisch.bunt), around 60 people, including the 'Alliance for Tolerance' (Bundnis fur Toleranz), Mayor Christiane Falk (SPD), numerous Grannies Against the Right members, a member of Starnberg Dialogue, and a representative of the Starnberg Inclusion Council, gathered in Starnberg (Bayern) to protest against right-wing extremism and exclusion. The event aimed to uphold democratic values and diversity in the city.

organizers: Antifa; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
