description: On 20 July 2024, around 100 to 130 people, including members of Grannies Against the Right, Antifa, CDU, SPD, The Greens, and the mayor Tobias Bergmann (SPD), gathered outside of a Greek restaurant in the Einfeld district of Neumunster (Schleswig-Holstein) to protest against a meeting between the Schleswig-Holstein branch of AfD and representatives of groups classified as 'right-wing extremist', including members of the Compact magazine, at the venue. Some participants set off a flare and firecrackers in a parking lot near the venue. Police forces cordoning off the venue briefly resorted to pepper spray to prevent some demonstrators from climbing over a barrier, keeping them at a distance.

organizers: GEW: German Education Union; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Teachers (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 18 July 2024, around 500 people, including students, university employees, union representatives from GEW and Ver.di and Science Minister Timon Gremmels (SPD), gathered in Darmstadt (Hessen), to protest against budget cuts in education and science. The protest took place in response to a 34 million euro reduction in university funding this year, with further cuts expected in 2025.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FFF: Fridays for Future; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Labor Group (Germany); Last Generation (Germany); Left Youth Solid; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany)
description: On 16 July 2024, around 130 people demonstrated in front of the town hall in Saarbrucken (Saarland) against what they define as cooperation between the CDU and the AfD in the Saarbrucken West District Council. Specifically, the election of the AfD candidate Werner Schwaben as first deputy in the West District Council generated criticism. Participants included the mayor (CDU), SPD, DGB, Jusos, Green Youth, Left Youth Solid, Last Generation and FFF members. Protesters also accused the SPD of contributing to the AfD's election success. They refused to allow the CDU mayor, who was taking part in the demonstration, to speak.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Students (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 14 July 2024, during the afternoon, at the call of Partnership for Democracy (Partnerschaft Demokratie), the District Youth Council (Kreisjugendring), political parties (unspecified), and associations, around 300 people, including the mayor (CDU), students, and Grannies Against the Right, demonstrated through the city center of Lauenburg/Elbe (Schleswig-Holstein) against far-right movements, from neo-Nazis to the AfD. They called for democracy, equality, freedom of expression, and human dignity.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Volt Europa; Women (Germany)
description: On 12 July 2024, during the evening, at the call of Open-minded Steglitz-Zehlendorf (Weltoffen), between 600 and up to 1,000 people, including Grannies Against the Right members, The Left, The Greens, SPD, and Volt, demonstrated in Berlin - Lichtenberg (Berlin) against the presence of the Austrian right-wing extremist Martin Sellner. They were against all fascism, racism, and Nazis. Around 50 people pushed police officers to break through a police cordon at times to get to the venue. The police were able to prevent the attempt and one person was arrested. No physical violence or fights were reported. The protest was peaceful according to the police. Sellner was a guest at a lecture given by former AfD politician Andreas Wild and attended by AfD and Young Alternative for Germany affiliates.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Former Military Forces of Israel (2022-); Government of Germany (2021-); Government of Israel (2022-); Israeli Group (Germany); Jewish Group (Germany); Protesters (Israel); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 10 July 2024, during the evening, at the call of the Israelite Religious Community and a Jewish political scientist, between around 500 and more than 1,000 people, including the Vice President of the European/World Jewish Congresses, Bavaria's Minister of the Interior (CSU), Munich's deputy mayor (The Greens), an SPD city councilor and chairwoman of 'Munich is colorful' (Munchen ist bunt), an FDP state chairman, the former Israeli army spokesman of 2024, the Consul General of the State of Israel for Southern Germany, and the association Democracy and Information e.V. (DEIN), gathered on St. Jakobsplatz in Munchen (Bayern) against what they defined as growing anti-Semitism. They insisted on their solidarity with Israel and called for the release of the Israeli hostages from Hamas. Bavaria's Minister spoke for a ceasefire soon and condemned anti-Semitism under the guise of criticism of the Israeli government.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 8 July 2024, at the call of the SPD, around 30 people, including SPD chief Hans Eckhard, chairman of the SPD Working Group for Employee Issues Orry Mittenmayer (AfA), and Grannies Against the Right, gathered in Lohfelden (Hessen), to protest against the AfD's summer festival.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 29 June 2024, under the motto 'Queer in Emden', around 1,000 people, including the mayor (Independent), President of the Ostfriesische Landscape (SPD), and a Bundestag member (SPD), participated in the Christopher Street Day protest in Emden (Niedersachsen) against discrimination, hatred, violence and exclusion and for solidarity, human dignity, LGBTQ+ rights, diversity, equality, acceptance, tolerance and an open approach to sexuality and against its tabooing.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Former Government of Germany (2021-); Iranian Group (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 29 June 2024, at the call of 'National Council of Resistance Iran' (Nationaler Widerstandsrat Iran), around 6,000 people, including members of the Iranian community, former Federal Minister of Economics (CDU), members of the CDU and members of the Ukrainian community, staged a protest in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) to call for democratic elections in Iran, the separation of state and religion, equal rights for women and men, more freedom and an end to executions. The participants also called on Germany and the EU to introduce a tougher policy towards the Iranian government.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 26 June 2024, around 300 people, including City Councilor Fritz Roth (FDP), gathered in Munchen (Bayern), to protest the planned construction that will remove 90 parking spaces for a new and wider bike lane. Their concerns include the loss of parking and the impact on the area.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 23 June 2024, at the call of 'Neuruppin stays colorful' (Neuruppin bleibt bunt), several hundred people, including Neuruppin's Mayor Nico Ruhle (SPD), gathered in Neuruppin (Brandenburg), to protest in solidarity with 'Doner Times' following a recent arson attack. The protest aimed to show support for tolerance, and unity, and condemn the violence against the local business.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 22 June 2024, around 5,000 people, including hospital staff and mayor Michael Dambacher (CDU), gathered in Ellwangen (Baden-Wurttemberg), to oppose the plans to downgrade the Virngrund-Klinik into a health center without surgical facilities, intensive care beds, or an emergency department.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 22 June 2024, around 360 people, including various leftist groups and The Left, gathered in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg), to protest against the awarding of the Hayek Medal to Argentina's President Javier Milei, due to Milei's far-right and extreme market-liberal policies.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 22 June 2024, thousands of people, including 210 groups and organizations, and Munich's mayors, Lord Mayor Dieter Reiter (SPD), Dominik Krause (Greens), and Verena Dietl (SPD), participated in the CSD parade in Munchen (Bayern), to protest for equal rights and social acceptance of the LGBTIQ* community and to stand against the rise of right-wing ideologies in Germany. The parade was part of the two-day finale of Pride Weeks, featuring various events, music, and discussions in the city center.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany)
description: On 20 June 2024, at the call of the alliance 'Grevesmuhlen for all' (Grevesmuhlen fur alle), between around 460 (according to police) and 500 (organizers) people, including the mayor (independent), students, a district administrator (CDU), associations, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern's Minister of Culture (SPD) and a Bundestag Member (SPD), participated in a protest in Grevesmuhlen (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) and formed a human chain against violence, racism, xenophobia and for cohesion, tolerance and a peaceful society. The event took place following a racist attack on a Ghanaian family in Grevesmuhlen.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 20 June 2024, at the call of the cathedral parish in Schwerin, people, including the State Justice Minister (The Left) and the Catholic Archbishop of Hamburg, participated in a protest in Schwerin (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) and formed a human chain against racism. The context of the protest was a recent racist attack against a Ghanaian family in Grevesmuhlen.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Students (Germany)
description: On 19 June 2024, around 800 people, including medical students and the state Health Minister (CDU), participated in a protest in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen) for better working conditions, standardized medical learning and training concepts and higher wages in line with the maximum Bafog student loan rate of up to 930 euros during the practical year taking place between the second and third state exam in medical studies. The protest was part of a nationwide action week.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; LGBTQ+ (Germany); Students (Germany)
description: On 19 June 2024, between 30 (according to observers) and more than 200 (organizers) people, including students, political organizations, student groups, Jusos and GJ, staged a protest at the university in Gottingen (Niedersachsen) and disturbed the lecture of Bundestag Member Mareike Wulf (CDU) on the self-determination-law of the coalition government, causing the termination of the lecture. The participants protested for trans rights and against what they consider to be misanthropic, trans-hostile and discriminatory statements by Wulf, arguing that they caused societal division and queerphobia.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); PARTEI: The Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 16 June 2024, under the motto 'Protect Democracy! We will not give way! - Democracy first, the third' and at the call of a city council member (PARTEI), 150 to 200 people, including the mayor (SPD) and a city council member (SPD), participated in a protest in Zweibrucken (Rheinland-Pfalz) against the shift to the right visible in the recent elections, to call on the parties in the city council not to work with the AfD and for a ban of the TikTok platform, which they considered to spread lies and be harmful to young people.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 15 June 2024, around 2,000 people, including 'Queer Feminist Collective Heidelberg' (Queerfeministisches Kollektiv Heidelberg), FFF, the mayor (SPD), 'Representation of the student body' (Vertretung der Studierendenschaft) and 'Queer Youth Heidelberg', participated in the Christopher Street parade in Heidelberg (Baden-Wurttemberg) to defend LGBTQ+ rights and more equality, and denounce queerphobia. The participants also called for workshops to sensitize civil servants to violence against the LGBTQ+ community.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 15 June 2024, under the motto 'The Hunsruck is colorful' and at the call of an alliance consisting of several political parties, the church and other organizations, between 500 and 600 people, including CDU, SPD, The Greens, FDP, the mayor (Independent), local politicians, representatives of the protestant church, and members of the Youth Parliament, participated in a protest in Simmern/Hunsruck (Rheinland-Pfalz) against an AfD state party conference and right-wing extremism and for tolerance, human rights, diversity, solution-oriented action despite discussions, cohesion regardless of origin, religion and skin color, and democratic values.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Police Forces of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 15 June 2024, at the call of CDU, SPD, the Greens and FDP, hundreds of people, including members of the State Parliament (CDU, FDP), representatives of the 'Police Union' (Gewerkschaft der Polizei), SPD, The Greens, and representatives of the church, participated in a protest in Fulda (Hessen) against violence against emergency services, to commemorate the police officer who was killed after a knife attack in Mannheim on 31 May 2024, set an example for solidarity and social cohesion, and to call for more respect and higher minimum penalties for violence against police, emergency services, and rescue workers.

organizers: Students (Germany); The Left (Germany); The Left.SDS
description: On 11 June 2024, at the call of the The Left.SDS and The Left, 140 people protested in Eichstatt (Bayern) in response to a racist attack on Iranian students that occurred on Pentecost Monday.

organizers: Students (Germany); The Left (Germany); The Left.SDS
description: Around 11 June 2024 (as reported), at the call of the 'No Deportation Prison in Gluckstadt and Elsewhere' coalition, including the Left.SDS and The Left members, 25 people protested in front of the Justice Ministry in Kiel (Schleswig-Holstein), demanding the closure of a prison in Gluckstadt and the release of a detainee who had been on a hunger strike for eight days at the time of reporting, and against the deportation of a man to Turkey.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 10 June 2024, at the call of 'Leipzig Takes a Stand' (Leipzig nimmt Platz), around 600 people, including local The Greens, The Left, and SPD politicians, gathered outside the new City Hall in Leipzig (Sachsen), to protest against the far-right shift in society, following the success of right-wing parties in East Germany's recent local elections.

organizers: EU: European Union; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 8 June 2024, around 10,000 people, including Matthias Ecke, an MEP and the SPD lead candidate for Saxony in the 2024 European elections, gathered in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) to protest against right-wing extremism ahead of the 2024 European elections.

organizers: Antifa; IG-BAU: Industrial Union Construction, Agriculture, Environment; IGBCE: Industrial Union for Mining, Chemistry and Energy; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 8 June 2024, at the call of the Action Alliance 'We are the Firewall' (Wir sind die Brandmauer) and under the motto 'Stop right-wing extremism - Defend democracy', around 8,000 to 12,000 people, including MLPD, The Left members, Antifa, IGM, IG-BAU and IG BCE, gathered in Dresden (Sachsen) to protest against right-wing extremism and support a democratic, open society, and encourage voter participation in the upcoming European elections. At the same time, Free Saxony members staged a counterprotest.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Volt Europa
description: On 8 June 2024, at the call of a broad coalition and under the motto 'Heart instead of Hate. For Democracy. Against the Right. For Each Other', around 300 people, including representatives of The Left, SPD, The Greens, and Volt gathered in Halle (Saale) (Sachsen), to protest against right-wing ideologies and to support a democratic, open society, and encourage voter participation in the upcoming European elections.

organizers: Former Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 8 June 2024, hundreds of people, including former MEP Helga Trupe (The Greens), gathered in Worpswede (Niedersachsen) to protest against right-wing extremism, and for democracy and tolerance.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; EU: European Union; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 7 June 2024, at the call of the Alliance against right-wing extremism, DGB, 'Alliance against Nazism in Chemnitz' (Bundnis Nazifrei), and the Alliance 'Hand in Hand' (Hand in Hand), around 600 to 700 people, including MEP and SPD lead candidate for the 2024 European elections in Saxony, Matthias Ecke, as well as Green party MEP Anna Cavazzini, gathered in Chemnitz (Sachsen) to defend democracy and denounce right-wing extremism. The gathering was also organized as a counter-demonstration to a simultaneous march involving around 200 far-right activists, including Free Saxons and PEGIDA leaders. There was no physical interaction between both groups.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 7 June 2024, at the call of the cross-party alliance 'Alliance for Democracy in Europe' (Bundnis fur Demokratie in Europa), which included CDU, SPD, FDP, the Greens, and FW, and under the motto 'Fidays for Freedom', around 60 people gathered in the Old Town of Konigswinter (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest in favor of democracy and freedom.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 7 June 2024, at the call of AfD, 700 people gathered in Mannheim (Baden-Wurttemberg) to protest against Islamism following the 2024 Mannheim stabbing on 31 May 2024, while 3,000 to 4,000 people joined two counter-demonstrations organized by unions, the 'Mannheim against right-wing extremism' Alliance (Mannheim gegen Rechts), and the Antifa to condemn the AfD's rhetoric, denouncing both racism and Islamism.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FDP: Free Democratic Party; OEDP: Ecological Democratic Party; PARTEI: The Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 7 June 2024, at the call of seven political parties (The Greens, CSU, SPD, FDP, OEDP, The Left, and PARTEI), around 40 people gathered in Traunstein (Bayern), urging citizens to participate in the 2024 European elections, emphasizing the need to counter internal and external threats, and promote democracy and European cooperation.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 6 June 2024, at the call of the GJ and Jusos and under the motto 'Against right-wing extremism! For human dignity!', over 400 people gathered in Freising (Bayern) to protest in defense of democratic values and against right-wing extremism.

organizers: Antifa; FFF: Fridays for Future; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 5 June 2024, several representatives from FFF, the open anti-fascist meeting, and members of the Green Party gathered in Wiesloch (Baden-Wurttemberg) to protest against a simultaneous AfD election campaign stand and the AfD's policies.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 4 June 2024, at the call of IGM and the Work Council, around 2,000 people, including employees of the Meyer Shipyard and the State Economic Minister (SPD), participated in a protest in Papenburg (Niedersachsen) against planned job cuts.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Students (Germany)
description: On 4 June 2024, at the call of the university Bonn-Rhein-Sieg, around 150 people, including the mayor (CDU), university staff, and students, participated in a protest in Sankt Augustin (Nordrhein-Westfalen) for human dignity and democracy.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 3 June 2024, at the call of 'Action Circle Democracy' (Aktionskreis Demokratie) and 'Cosmopolitan Thuringen' (Weltoffenes Thuringen), about 40 people, including members of the Left, participated in a protest in Eisenberg (Thuringen) against the AfD, racism, xenophobia, and for democracy, tolerance and cosmopolitism. The protest was organized in the context of an upcoming run-off election between two candidates (CDU and AfD) for the role of district administrator.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 3 June 2024, under the motto 'Our solidarity against your repression' and at the call of several alliances, including the initiative 'Leipzig sits down' (Leipzig nimmt Platz), Grannies Against the Right and the youth organization 'Young Struggle', around 400 people, including an SPD member, participated in a protest in Leipzig (Sachsen) on the anniversary of the 'DayX', to call for the review of a police operation on 3 June 2023, criticizing that the operation had no been adequately investigated, and that people continued to be persecuted, and that charges against those responsible had been dismissed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Jewish Group (Germany); Muslim Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 3 June 2024, at the call of the mayor (CDU), the city council, and various religious communities, people, including members of the Christian Church, the Jewish community and the Muslim community, Baden Wurttemberg's Interior Minister Thomas Strobl (CDU), State Parliament President Muhterem Aras (The Greens) and Federal Interior Minister Nancy Faeser (SPD), participated in a protest in Mannheim (Baden-Wurttemberg) against hatred, all forms of extremism and agitation, and to pay tribute to a police officer killed following the 31 May 2024 Mannheim stabbing, and to call for peace and cohesion.

organizers: Caritas; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 3 June 2024, at the call of the association 'Refugee Aid Oeventrop' (Fluchtlingshilfe Oeventrop e.V.), about 600 people, including the mayor (SPD), the deputy mayor (CDU) and Caritas members, participated in a protest in Oeventrop (Nordrhein-Westfalen) and formed a human chain for democracy, peace, diversity, the rule of law, openness and tolerance, and against right-wing extremism.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); IB: Internationalist Alliance; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 2 June 2024, at the call of the action alliance 'Rugen for All' (Rugen fur Alle), including regional initiatives and network, as well as the church, State Secretary Heiko Mirass (SPD), Dirk Niehaus (The Greens), city President Kerstin Kassner (The Left), around 100 people, including a pastor and IB members, participated in a protest in Bergen auf Rugen (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) against the AfD, violence, right-wing extremism, and fascism, and in favor of diversity, democracy, and tolerance, while calling on people to vote during at the 2024 European elections. The protest was part of the state-wide 'Action Day Democratic Mecklenburg Vorpommern' for democracy and human dignity.

organizers: AI: Amnesty International; Alliance Against the Right; Caritas; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FFF: Fridays for Future; GEW: German Education Union; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); Migrants (International); Protesters (International); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Teachers (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 2 June 2024, under the motto 'We are the firewall' and at the call of the alliance '#WeAreThefirewall' (#WirSindDieBrandmauer) consisting of around 340 politicians, organizations, enterprises and civil society actors, including Caritas, religious communities, FFF, Grannies Against the Right and Students Against the Right, between 8,000 to 10,000 (according to the police) and 15,000 (organizers) people, including GEW, IGM, 'Work Bicycle' (Jobrad), Badenova, 'German Alpine Association' (Deutscher Alpenverein), 'Migrant Advisory Board' (Migrant_innenbeirat), members of the LGBTQ+ community and the campaign 'Faces against right-wing extremism' (Gesichter gegen Rechts), AI, 'Freiburg against right-wing extremism' (Freiburg gegen Rechts), the migrant initiative 'We vote' (Wir Wahlen!), the Left, SPD, The Greens, CDU and FDP, participated in a protest in Freiburg im Breisgau (Baden-Wurttemberg) against right-wing extremism, fascism, hatred and agitation and for democracy, human rights and diversity as well as to call on people to vote in the upcoming elections.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Teachers (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 2 June 2024, under the motto 'Never again is now' and at the call of the alliance 'Grevesmuhlen for all' (Grevesmuhlen fur alle), including 'Alliance for Grevesmuhlen' (Bundnis fur Grevesmuhlen), regional initiatives and network, as well as the church, around 130 people, including members of SPD, The Left, The Greens, a pastor and teachers, participated in a protest in Grevesmuhlen (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) against the AfD and fascism and for diversity, democracy and tolerance. The protest was part of the state-wide 'Action Day Democratic Mecklenburg Vorpommern' for democracy and human dignity.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 2 June 2024, a good 200 people, including the mayor (SPD), a State Parliament member (CDU), and 'Alliance for Democracy' (Bundnis fur Demokratie) members, participated in a protest in Kusel (Rheinland-Pfalz) against right-wing extremism, in defense of democracy, freedom, and diversity, and to call on people to vote for democratic parties in the upcoming elections.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 2 June 2024, under the motto 'Our villages are colorful' and at the call of various associations and groups, around 400 people, including a pastor, a representative of the CDU, and the 'German catholic women community' (Katholische Frauengemeinschaft Deutschland), participated in a protest in the Bunnen area of Loningen (Niedersachsen) against racism, the AfD, agitation, and xenophobia, as well as in favor of tolerance, diversity and democracy. The protest was organized following reports of racist chanting at the 2024 Bunnen Shooting Festival during the Whitsun weekend.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 2 June 2024, around 250 people, including a State Parliament member (SPD), IGM, the Chairman of the Village Association and Head of the Village of Elben, 'Alliance for Tolerance and Civil Courage' (Bundnis fur Toleranz und Zivilcourage) and the Women's Alliance (Frauenbundnis), participated in a protest in Olpe (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against the AfD and right-wing extremism, and for democracy, human rights, freedom, equality, and justice.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Muslim Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); Protesters (International); Refugees/IDPs (International); Students (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 2 June 2024, under the motto 'Never again is now' and at the call of the initiative 'Rostock nazifree' (Rostock nazifrei) and the association 'Colorful instead of brown' (Bunt statt Braun), about 2,000 people, including the deputy chairwoman of the MV state student council, representatives of DGB, the mayor (The Left), members of the Protestant and Muslim communities, students and refugees, participated in a protest in Rostock (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) for democracy and diversity, and against right-wing extremism and the AfD. The protest was part of the state-wide 'Action Day Democratic Mecklenburg Vorpommern' for democracy and human dignity.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 2 June 2024, at the call of an action alliance, including regional initiatives and network, as well as the church, between 350 (according to the organizers) and 360 (police) people, including Minister President of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Manuela Schleswig (SPD), participated in a protest in Schwerin (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) against the AfD and fascism and for diversity, democracy and tolerance. The protest was part of the state-wide 'Action Day Democratic Mecklenburg Vorpommern' for democracy and human dignity.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 2 June 2024, under the motto 'A whole state demonstrates for Democracy and Stralsund is part of it' and at the call of an action alliance, including regional initiatives and network, as well as the church, and DGB, around 200 people, including Born's mayor (FDP), the Greens, and members of the children and youth parliament Stralsund, participated in a protest in Stralsund (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) for democracy, diversity, human dignity, an open society and tolerance, against extremism, fascism and the AfD, and to call on people to vote in the upcoming elections. The protest was part of a state-wide action day of the Action Alliance 'Democratic Mecklenburg Vorpommern' (Demokratisches MV) for human dignity and an open society.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 2 June 2024, under the motto 'Be loud against the Right!' and at the call of the alliance 'Sylt against the Right' (Sylt gegen Rechts), 450 people, including politicians and Sylt's third deputy major (The Greens), participated in a protest in Westerland (Schleswig-Holstein) against right-wing extremism and racism.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 1 June 2024, hundreds of people, including a member of the SPD, participated in a protest in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin), set up hundreds of children's shoes on Unter den Linden Street, and read the names of the children killed in Gaza to pay tribute to civilian deaths, express their discomfort with the politics of Germany, and criticize the gap between politics and media, which they argued left little room for nuanced opinions. The protest was organized in the context of Internationdal Child Day.

organizers: LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 1 June 2024, under the motto '100 percent human - without ifs and buts!', around 10,000 people, including SPD General Secretary, Kevin Kuhnert, participated in the Christopher Street Day protest in Dresden (Sachsen) to defend LGBTQ+ rights. Under the motto 'Normal instead of Pride' and at the call of the Homeland and 'Elblandrevolt' (Elblandrevolte), around 90 far-right activists, including members of Free Saxony, The Homeland, and JN, staged a counter-protest.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; JA: Young Alternative for Germany
description: On 1 June 2024, at the call of AfD and 'Free Schleswig Holstein' (Freie Schleswig-Holsteiner), about 80 people, including members of JA, participated in a protest in Kiel (Schleswig-Holstein) against the policies of the current government and for freedom of speech. At the call of Antifa Kiel, about 100 people staged a counter-protest.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 1 June 2024, under the motto 'Never again is now' and at the call of the 'Working Group Active against right-wing extremism' (Arbeitskreis Aktiv gegen Rechts), at least 200 people, including the mayor (CDU), representatives of the SPD, FW, the new Voters' Group 'Sabbagh' and the Greens, participated in a protest in Kirchheimbolanden (Rheinland-Pfalz) against right-wing extremism, racism, xenophobia, fascism, extremism and the AfD, in defense of human rights, tolerance, and to call on people to vote for a democratic party in the upcoming elections. The protest was organized in reaction to the simultaneous Palatine meeting of the AfD outside the town hall.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Independent Politicians (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 1 June 2024, 450 people, including a State Parliament member (SPD), the community mayor (independent), Nastatten's mayor (SPD) and doctors, participated in a protest in Nastatten (Rheinland-Pfalz) for the preservation of the Paulinerstift and for basic medical care in rural areas. The protest was organized after the Koblenz City Council decided to no longer support the Mittelrhein community clinic with public money.

organizers: Environmental Union; FFF: Fridays for Future; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 31 May 2024, at the call of FFF, around 400 people, including Grannies Against the Right, Environmental Union, and MLPD, participated in a protest in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen) for climate protection and democracy, against racism, fascism, the AfD and right-wing extremism, and to draw attention to the importance of the EU in tackling the climate crisis. The protest was organized as part of FFF's international climate strike to call for an EU-wide phase-out of coal, oil and gas by 2035, and a doubling of investments in renewable energies and climate-neutral industries.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; FFF: Fridays for Future; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Students (Germany); Volt Europa; Women (Germany)
description: On 31 May 2024, at the call of FFF, people, including Grannies Against the Right, BUND, Parents for Future, Volt Europa, 'Hof Alliance for Civil Courage: Hof is Colorful' (Hofer Bundnis fur Zivilcourage: Hof ist Bunt), 'Alliance against right-wing extremism in the metropolitan area Nurnberg' (Allianz gegen Rechtsextremismus), participated in a protest in Hof (Bayern) for climate protection and democracy, and to draw attention to the importance of the EU in tackling the climate crisis. The protest was organized as part of FFF's international climate strike to call for an EU-wide phase-out of coal, oil and gas by 2035, and a doubling of investments in renewable energies and climate-neutral industries.

organizers: BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; EU: European Union; FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Seebruecke; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 31 May 2024, at the call of FFF, between around 800 (according to the police) and 1,000 (organizers) people, including BUND, Turbo climate combat group Kiel' (Turboklimakampfgruppe Kiel (TKKG)), Grannies Against the Right, Seebruecke, a Member of the European Parliament (The Greens) and the Social group 'Those who have, give' (Wer hat, der gibt), participated in a protest in Kiel (Schleswig-Holstein) for climate protection and democracy, for more electricity from onshore wind and photovoltaics, the inclusion of climate protection in the Schleswig-Holstein state constitution, and to draw attention to the importance of the EU in tackling the climate crisis. The protest was organized as part of FFF's international climate strike to call for an EU-wide phase-out of coal, oil and gas by 2035, and a doubling of investments in renewable energies and climate-neutral industries.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 31 May 2024, at the call of FFF, about 150 people, including the mayor (The Greens), participated in a protest in Landau in der Pfalz (Rheinland-Pfalz) for climate protection, climate justice and democracy, and to draw attention to the importance of the EU in tackling the climate crisis. The protest was organized as part of FFF's international climate strike to call for an EU-wide phase-out of coal, oil and gas by 2035, and a doubling of investments in renewable energies and climate-neutral industries.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 30 May 2024, under the motto 'Never again is now' and at the call of the Alliance 'Democratic Mecklenburg Vorpommern' (Demokratisches MV), 360 people, including Minister-President Manuela Schlesig (SPD), participated in a protest in Schwerin (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) for democracy and tolerance, against racism and right-wing extremism, and to call on people to vote in the upcoming elections. The protest was part of a state-wide action day for democracy and tolerance.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; EU: European Union; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 26 May 2024, at the call of the 'Alliance for Democracy Oberlausitz' (Bundnis Demokratie Oberlausitz), people, including SPD MEP Matthias Ecke and a CDU district administrator, gathered in Zittau (Sachsen) to protest against right-wing extremism ahead of the 2024 European elections, seeking to counter the narrative of the regular Monday demonstrations by the Free Saxony party.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 26 May 2024, at the call of a broad coalition, including The Greens, CSU, the Left and Ver.di, around 500 people, including local elected officials and parliamentarians, gathered in Lindenberg im Allgau (Bayern) to protest against the AfD.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 25 May 2024, at the call of the 'Working Group against Right-Wing Extremism' (Arbeitsgruppe gegen Rechtsextremismus), around 3,500 people, including members of the SPD, gathered in Dortmund (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest against far-right ideologies and the AfD, and other right-wing extremist movements ahead of the 2024 European elections.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany)
description: On 25 May 2024, on the occasion of Christopher Street Day and under the motto 'Red Card Against Homophobia, Transphobia, Racism, and All Other Forms of Oppression', several thousand people, including mayor Josef Hinkel (CDU) and members of 'Carnival Club Rainbow' (Karnevalsvereins KG Regenbogen), gathered in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to defend the rights of the queer community. They marched through the city, draped in rainbow flags, dancing, and playing party music, aiming to raise awareness about LGBTQ+ rights and combat discrimination and oppression against members of the community.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 25 May 2024, over 100 people, including local councilors, administrators, and members of SPD, CDU, The Greens, and FDP, gathered in Wildeshausen (Niedersachsen) to support and defend the German Constitution, while denouncing the AfD.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany
description: On 24 May 2024, more than 100 people, including CDU politicians, gathered in front of the Synagogue in Heidelberg (Baden-Wurttemberg) to condemn racial hatred and antisemitism, following the revelation of plans to attack synagogue visitors.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FW: Free Voters; Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 24 May 2024, at the call of Jusos, around 300 people, including politicians from the SPD, FW, the Greens, and CSU, gathered in Starnberg (Bayern) to protest against the AfD and right-wing violence during the party's final campaign event for the European elections at the town's Schlossberghall.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 24 May 2024, on the occasion of the 75th anniversary of the German Basic Law and at the call of the Alliance Against the Right and various political parties, including SPD, The Greens, FDP, and FW, around 200 people, including mayor Christian Pape (independent) gathered in Wegberg (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest against war, hatred, and intolerance, and to promote democracy, freedom, and tolerance.

organizers: Antifascist Action; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 24 May 2024, around 100 people, including Grannies Against the Right, SPD and The Greens politicians, and the Antifascist Action, gathered in the Misburg district of Hannover (Niedersachsen) to protest against an AfD event where the party's lead European election candidate (Maximilian Krah) was supposed to speak but did not appear due to a ban on his appearance. The protesters argued the AfD was a threat to democracy.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 23 May 2024, at the call of local The Greens representatives and other community members, around 150 people gathered outside the Grobenzell Leisure Centre in Munchen (Bayern) to protest against an AfD election campaign event, aiming to voice opposition to the AfD's presence and its political stance, highlighting the importance of defending democracy and expressing discontent with the party's policies.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 22 May 2024, at the call of a coalition of parents' representatives, people, including SPD politicians, gathered in Hannover (Niedersachsen) to protest for better childcare services, citing ongoing issues and disruptions in childcare facilities. The event aimed to address problems such as staff shortages, closures, and reduced operating hours.

organizers: Antifa; CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 22 May 2024, around 200 people, including mayor Stefan Bosse (CSU) and Antifa activists, gathered in Kaufbeuren (Bayern) to protest against right-wing ideologies and for democracy, while simultaneously, the AfD held a campaign event with their European election lead candidate Maximilian Krah.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 22 May 2024, at the call of social welfare associations and labor groups, around 3,000 people, including CDU and The Greens politicians, gathered in Kiel (Schleswig-Holstein) to demand social justice, and protest against bureaucratic burdens, inadequate childcare, and what they perceived as the overall lack of support for social work.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 22 May 2024, over 300 people, including service employees, nurses, various union members, Bundestag member Carolin Wagner (SPD), and DGB affiliates, gathered in Regensburg (Bayern) to protest against low wages and poor working conditions at the University Hospital Regensburg.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 May 2024, at the call of 'Alliance Against Right-wing Extremism' (Bundnis gegen Rechtsextremismus) and the initiative 'Cosmopolitan Thuringen' (Weltoffenes Thuringen), more than 400 people, including the State Minister of the Interior and SPD leader, Georg Maier, participated in a protest in Eisenach (Thuringen) for democracy and cosmopolitanism, against racism, and to call on people to vote at the 2024 European elections.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 18 May 2024, at the call of 'Culture Bridge Palestine' (Kulturbrucke Palastina), 'Erfurt unsilenced', MLPD, and Handala Leipzig, around 300 people participated in a pro-Palestine protest in Erfurt (Thuringen) to call for a free Palestine and an end of what they claim to be a genocide in Gaza and against German arms deliveries to Israel. At the call of a city council member (CDU) and DIG, about 100 people participated in a counter-protest in solidarity with Israel and to call for a Gaza free from Hamas.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany)
description: On 18 May 2024, under the motto 'Democracy and Freedom' and at the call of a broad alliance of associations, political parties and the Protestant community, around 700 people, including two pastors, students, a state parliament member (SPD) and the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in Grunstadt (Rheinland-Pfalz) for freedom, democracy, tolerance and respect and against any form of extremism, intolerance, and xenophobia.

organizers: Former Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 May 2024, at the call of the alliance 'Neustadt remains colorful' (Neustadt bleibt bunt), around 350 people, including a former Minister-President of Rheinland-Pfalz (SPD), participated in a protest at Hambacher Schloss in Neustadt an der Weinstrasse (Rheinland-Pfalz) for diversity, human rights, and democracy and against a so-called 'Festival of Initiatives' taking place in the city center, which they considered as organized by 'enemies of democracy'.

organizers: Aid Workers (Germany); Former Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 18 May 2024, under the motto 'Festival against the Right' and at the call of 'Network Together against the Right - For a better democracy' (Netzwerk Gemeinsam gegen Rechts - Fur eine bessere Demokratie), people, including members of the aid organization 'Stelp' and a former State Parliament member (The Greens), participated in a protest in Stuttgart (Baden-Wurttemberg) against the AfD's remigration plans, fascism, and right-wing extremism.

organizers: Last Generation (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 18 May 2024, up to 100 climate activists, including Last Generation members, participated in protests inside the terminal at the airport in Stuttgart (Baden-Wurttemberg), demanding measures against growing air traffic and calling for an end to private jets, short-haul flights, and subsidized kerosene, some refusing to leave the airport after the demonstration, causing the police to intervene and take them outside. At the same time and as part of the same, coordinated demonstration, around 75 climate activists, including Last Generation and MLPD, participated in a protest in front of the airport and the General Aviation Terminal, without any incidents.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Independent Politicians (Germany); Jewish Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 18 May 2024, at the call of SPD regional parliamentary group leader, more than 200 people, including Grannies Against the Right, the mayor (Independent), a state parliament member (The Greens), the FDP district chairman, a member of the 'Europe Union' (Europa Union) and 'Vohl Initiative for Democracy, Tolerance and Europe' (Vohler Initiative fur Demokratie, Toleranz und Europa), which consists of 'Region against racism' (Region gegen Rassismus), SPD, the Greens, FDP, FW, the 'Synagogue support group' (Forderkreis Synagoge), and members of the Christian community, participated in a protest in Vohl (Hessen) for democracy, the rule of law, human rights, tolerance and a free Europe and against right-wing extremism, racial hatred, agitation, and an AfD European election campaign event taking place in town on that day.

organizers: Former Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 May 2024, under the motto 'Protect the Heart of Europe with us' and at the call of 'Neuwied's Alliance for Democracy and Tolerance' (Neuwieder Bundnis fur Demokratie und Toleranz), about 200 people, including former State Parliament member (SPD), participated in a protest in Neuwied (Rheinland-Pfalz) against the politics and ideas of the AfD. The protest was organized against an AfD election campaign event taking place simultaneously; protesters blocked the path to the event's venue.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 May 2024, under the motto 'Never again is now!' and at the call of 'Alliance Against the Right - Gotha is colorful' (Bundnis gegen Rechts - Gotha ist bunt!), around 100 people, including the Greens affiliates and a State Parliament member (SPD), participated in a protest in Gotha (Thuringen) against the AfD and right-wing extremism.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 15 May 2024, at the call of 'Palestine Solidarity Duisburg' (Palastina Solidaritat Duisburg), people, including MLPD, participated in a protest in Duisburg (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against the suppression of the expression of opinion in support of Palestinians and to commemorate the flight and expulsion of thousands of people in 1948 in the context of the Nakba after the founding of the state of Israel.

organizers: ATIK: Confederation of Workers from Turkey in Europe; Labor Group (Turkey); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 15 May 2024, people, including 'Zora', 'Young Struggle', ATIK and MLPD participated in a protest in Frankfurt am Main (Hessen) in solidarity with Palestinians. They were against what they claim to be a genocide in Gaza as well as German solidarity and arms deliveries to Israel.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 15 May 2024, under the motto 'Stop the Genocide in Gaza! Immediate end to Israel's ground offensive! Withdraw all troops' and at the call of IB Erfurt and MLPD, around 10 pro-Palestine activists participated in a protest in Erfurt (Thuringen) against Israel's ground offensive in Rafah and against the German government's support for Israel.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Palestinian Group (Germany); Turkish Group (Germany)
description: On 15 May 2024, under the motto 'May 15 is worldwide 'Nakba Day' - Stop the genocide in Gaza! Today we are all Palestinians' and at the call of MLPD, about 50 to 60 people, including Palestinians and the Turkish organization 'BirKar - Platform for the Unity and Friendship of Peoples' (BirKar - Plattform fur die Einheit und Freundschaft der Volker), participated in a protest in Essen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against what they claim to be a genocide in Gaza and Germany's support for the Israeli government and for a free Palestine, an end of German arms' deliveries, an immediate ceasefire and more international solidarity. The protest was organized in the context of the 76th anniversary of the flight and expulsion of thousands of people in 1948 in the context of the Nakba after the founding of the state of Israel.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Palestinian Group (Germany)
description: On 15 May 2024, at the call of the Palestinian community Koln, 'Palestinian Solidarity Koln' (Palastina Solidaritat Koln) and other left-wing groups, more than 200 people, including MLPD, participated in a pro-Palestine protest in Koln (Nordrhein-Westfalen) calling for a free Palestine and an end of German arms deliveries to Israel and an end of what they claim to be a genocide in Gaza. The protest was organized in the context of the 76th anniversary of the flight and expulsion of thousands of people in 1948 in the context of the so-called Nakba after the founding of the state of Israel. Around 30 people participated in a pro-Israel counter protest nearby calling to free Gaza from Hamas.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 15 May 2024, an estimated 1,000 people, including MLPD, participated in a protest in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg) against what they claim to be a genocide in Gaza. The protest was organized in the context of the 76th anniversary of the flight and expulsion of thousands of people in 1948 in the context of the so-called Nakba after the founding of the state of Israel. A verbal argument between a 42-year old man and participants of a pro-Palestine demonstration led to the man attacking a demonstrator with a wine bottle and leading to scuffles.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 13 May 2024, under the motto 'Showing up for Democracy' and at the call of the SPD's local Association chairman, about 40 people, including members of the Greens, representatives of the church and associations, participated in a protest in Wiesenbach (Baden-Wurttemberg) against all forms of extremism, intolerance, violence against politicians and increasing linguistic brutalization and for democracy, freedom, justice and respect.

organizers: Antifa; BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 11 May 2024, at the call of an alliance of various groups, around 250 people, including Jusos, SPD, city council members, 'Social Association VdK' (Sozialverband VdK), Grannies Against the Right, Antifa, FFF and BUND, participated in a protest in Miesbach (Bayern) against the AfD and for democracy and pluralism. The context of the protest was an event of the AfD planned to take place simultaneously which was relocated to Holzkirchen.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Farmers (Germany); FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 11 May 2024, under the motto 'Care is taking shape - promises are not enough!', at peak about 200 people, including doctors, pharmacists and a farmer as well as Bavarian Economics Minister (FW), a member of the State Parliament (CSU), the association 'Hand in Hand for our country' (Hand in Hand fur unser Land) and representatives of 'Hospital service company' (Krankenhausdienstleistungsgesellschaft (KDL)), participated in a protest in Regensburg (Bayern) to demand the enhancement of the nursing profession and a decoupling of the care and health sector from pure profit thinking. They demanded their pay to be brought into line with the collective agreement of Bavaria, better working conditions, a parking permit for mobile care services, rights to drive over construction sites, and the re-engagement of young people through compulsory and voluntary services.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 11 May 2024, under the motto 'Protest Democracy - Against Hatred, Agitation and Violence' and at the call of 2 members of the Greens, about 170 people, including a city council member (CDU), the mayor (Independent), a State Parliament member (SPD), representatives of the church and the Greens, participated in a protest in Frankenberg (Eder) (Hessen) for democracy, diversity, freedom and human rights and against right-wing tendencies and ideologies, violence and agitation.

organizers: DIG: German-Israeli Society; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Israeli Group (Germany); Jewish Group (Germany); Students (Germany)
description: On 10 May 2024, at the call of 'Fridays for Israel', 150 people, including Bundestag Member (FDP), the chairwoman of the 'Jewish Student Union Germany' (Judische Studierendenunion Deutschland) and the DIG chairman, participated in a protest at Humboldt-University in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) against hostility towards Israel at Berlin universities and criticized an open statement by university professors relating to pro-Palestinian protests. The participation of pro-Palestinian activists Udi Raz (Board member of the 'Jewish Voice for Just Peace in the Middle East' (Judische Stimme fur gerechten Frieden in Nahost) and provocations of three others lead to an intervention of the police who pulled the activists out of the crowd.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 10 May 2024, at the call of the Greens and the Left and supported by CDU, AWO, SPD, the protestant church and unions, around 150 people, including Essen's third mayor (The Greens), participated in a protest in Bochum (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against violence against politicians and for democracy.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 9 May 2024, at the call of MLPD and IB, people, including representatives of labor unions and the Monday demonstrations, participated in a protest at the Soviet Memorial in Treptower Park in Berlin - Treptow-Kopenick (Berlin) against anti-communism, racism, fascism, the AfD and anti-Semitism and for democracy.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 8 May 2024, under the motto 'It's 5 to 12 - For a cosmopolitan, tolerant and colorful Illertissen' and at the call of an alliance consisting of a pastor, city council members (The Greens, SPD) and others, around 60 people participated in a protest in Illertissen (Bayern) against right-wing extremism and for tolerance and to commemorate the victims of the second world war. They also were against racism. The protest was organized in the context of the end of the second world war on 8 May 1945.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 8 May 2024, under the motto 'Live democracy' and at the call of the association 'Heiligenhafen Citizen's Account' (Burger-Kontor Heiligenhafen), slightly more than 200 people, including Heiligenhafen's mayor (Independent), Grossenbrode's mayor (CDU), Bundestag members (CDU, SPD) and State Parliament members (CDU, SPD, The Greens) and representatives of the protestant church, participated in a protest in Heiligenhafen (Schleswig-Holstein) against hatred, racism, right-wing extremism, the AfD, violence against politicians and agitation and for democracy, equality, diversity, justice, peace, participation, freedom and tolerance. The protest was organized in the context of the end of the second world war on 8 May 1945.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Former Government of Germany (2021-); FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany)
description: On 8 May 2024, under the motto 'Grimma for Peace', about 200 people, including a city council member (FW), a former State Parliament member (CDU), the initiative 'Dare to make peace' (Frieden wagen), the mayor (Independent) and the alliance 'Grimma shows edge' (Grimma zeigt Kante), participated in a protest in Grimma (Sachsen) against armed violence and for a diplomatic resolution of wars instead of weapons. The participants also condemned Russia's war of aggression and Hamas' attack on Israel while emphasizing Palestinians' right to self-determination.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 8 May 2024, at the call of 'Alliance for Democracy and Diversity' (Bundnis fur Demokratie und Vielfalt), consisting of 31 parties and organizations and members of the SPD, nearly 100 people participated in a protest in Neuburg (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) against right-wing extremism, radicalism, hatred, racism and dictatorship and for democracy, freedom and human dignity. The protest was organized in the context of the end of the second world war on 8 May 1945.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 5 May 2024, under the motto 'March of Life', around 200 people, including politicians from the SPD, the Greens and CDU as well as Mayor Uwe Conradt (CDU), gathered in Saarbrucken (Saarland), to protest against anti-semitism and in support with Israel. People gathered for a counter-protest and slogans, including 'Free Palestine,' were occasionally shouted.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FFF: Fridays for Future; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 5 May 2024, around 3,000 people, including politicians from the Greens, SPD and CDU, and FFF, gathered in Dresden (Sachsen), to protest in solidarity with SPD politician Matthias Ecke after he was assaulted while hanging election posters, calling for democracy and condemning violence.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FFF: Fridays for Future; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 5 May 2024, around 1,000 people, including politicians from the Greens, SPD and CDU, and FFF, gathered in front of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin), to protest in solidarity with SPD politician Matthias Ecke after he was assaulted while hanging election posters, calling for democracy and condemning violence.

organizers: Evangelical Christian Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; VVN-BdA: Association of Persecutees of the Nazi Regime/Federation of Antifascists
description: On 5 May 2024, at the call of a broad coalition of parties, unions, initiatives, including VVN-BdA, MLPD, and the Evangelical Church, hundreds of people gathered in Russelsheim am Main (Hessen), to protest against an AfD event held on the same day. The event aimed to demonstrate clear opposition to the AfD and its policies, with demands for the party's prohibition.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 4 May 2024, at the call of 'Cultural Bridge Association' (Verein Kulturbrucke) and the 'Association for Secular Islam' (Verein Sakularer Islam), around 1,000 people, including the Kurdish Community, politicians such as Dennis Thering (CDU), Dirk Kienscherf (SPD), Dominik Lorenzen (The Greens), and parliament member Michael Kruse (FDP), gathered in St. Georg in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg), protesting against Islamism and antisemitism, displaying a diverse array of flags and symbols.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 4 May 2024, at the call of the Alliance for Democracy and Tolerance, around 200 people, along with various political parties, organizations, churches, and the mayor (CDU), gathered in Neuwied (Rheinland-Pfalz), to protest for democracy and tolerance.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 2 May 2024, 6,000 to 8,000 steel industry employees, primarily from Thyssenkrupp Steel, including Federal Minister of Labour Hubertus Heil (SPD), gathered in Duisburg (Nordrhein-Westfalen), to protest for job preservation, and against potential layoffs.

organizers: Antifa; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; DKP: German Communist Party; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; SDAJ: Socialist German Workers Youth; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the DGB and Ver.di, around 7,000 people, including SPD, Antifa, GJ, DKP, MLPD, and SDAJ, gathered on Marienplatz in Munchen (Bayern), demanding increased wages, fair compensation, and regulated working hours as fundamental rights for employees.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the DGB, around 350 people, including mayor Karin Welge (SPD) gathered in Gelsenkirchen (Nordrhein-Westfalen), demanding increased wages, fair compensation, and regulated working hours as fundamental rights for employees.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of DGB, around 2,000 to 3,000 people, including Prime Minister of North Rhine-Westphalia Hendrik Wurst (CDU) and DGB Chairperson Anja Weber, gathered in Aachen (Nordrhein-Westfalen), demanding European unity and social justice amidst concerns over labor conditions and the rise of right-wing ideologies.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the DGB, several hundred people, including mayor Stephan Keller (CDU), gathered in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen), demanding increased wages, fair compensation, and regulated working hours as fundamental rights for employees. During a speech Mayor Stephan Keller, he was disrupted by a group of youth participants with socialist affiliations, protesting with banners and loud interjections against his presence.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; GEW: German Education Union; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Teachers (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of DGB, around 7,000 people, including Grannies Against the Right and the Alliance Against the Right, mayor Peter Tschentscher (SPD) and National Chairperson of the Education and Science Union (GEW) Maike Finnern, gathered in Hamburg - Altona (Hamburg), to protest for 'More pay, more leisure time, more security.' The event aimed to draw attention to workers' rights and achievements, emphasizing solidarity and the ongoing need for improvement in areas such as wage losses and the expansion of collective bargaining agreements.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the DGB, around 2,000 to 2,500 people, including State parliament member Vanessa Gronemann (The Greens) gathered in Kassel (Niedersachsen), demanding increased wages, fair compensation, and regulated working hours as fundamental rights for employees.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the Left and DGB, 2,000 to 3,000 people gathered in Erfurt (Thuringen), to protest for workers' rights.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the Left and DGB, around 750 people, including MP Katharina Konig-Preuss (The Left), gathered in Gera (Thuringen), to protest for workers' rights and social justice.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the Left and DGB, around 14,000 people gathered in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin), demanding better wages and working conditions.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the Left and DGB, between 11,600 (according to the police) and 25,000 to 30,000 (according to organizers) people gathered in Berlin - Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg and marched through Berlin - Neukolln (Berlin), demanding fair wages and improved labor conditions, while addressing concerns related to the Gaza conflict, with participants displaying Palestinian flags and anti-Israel symbols.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Free Saxony; Querdenken
description: On 1 May 2024, people from the Querdenken movement and AfD supporters, including co-founder of Free Saxony Martin Kohlmann, gathered in Herrnhut (Sachsen), to protest against the politicization of the May Dance (Maitanz) tradition.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the DGB, hundreds of people, including Mayor Christian Thieme (CDU) gathered in Zeitz (Sachsen-Anhalt), to protest for workers' rights and core demands such as increased wages, and improved job security.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the DGB, people, including Prime Minister Manuela Schwesig (SPD), gathered in Torgelow (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern), demanding increased wages, fair compensation, and regulated working hours as fundamental rights for employees.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the DGB, people, including Minister Karl Lauterbach (SPD), gathered in Koln (Nordrhein-Westfalen), demanding increased wages, fair compensation, and regulated working hours as fundamental rights for employees

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, at the call of the DGB, people, including Prime Minister Bodo Ramelow (The Left), gathered in Eisenach (Thuringen), demanding increased wages, fair compensation, and regulated working hours as fundamental rights for employees.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Ver.di: United Services Union; Women (Germany)
description: On 1 May 2024, at the call of DGB, around 150 people, including SPD members, Ver.di and the women educational association 'Sofia', participated in a cycling and walking protest in Wolfratshausen (Bayern) calling for among other things emergency financial aid for hospitals from the federal government, a reduction in working hours with full wage compensation and comprehensive co-determination rights for employees, commemorating the forced laborers and refugees in the former Fohrenwald camp and denouncing the widening gap between rich and poor. The protest was organized in the context of the Labor Day.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 30 April 2024, at the call of IGM, significantly more than 10,000 people, including Thyssenkrupp steel workers, Federal Minister of Labor (SPD), State Minister of Labor (CDU), President of the Bundestag (SPD), the mayor (SPD) and SPD members of the state parliament, participated in a protest in Duisburg (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against job cuts and sales plans and demanded concrete concepts, plans and location guarantees.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 30 April 2024, people, including City council members of the Greens and the CDU, participated in a protest in Mauerpark in Berlin - Pankow (Berlin) calling for sound insulation and for the preservation of the green area for barbecues and playing music.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 April 2024, at the call of the 'Solidarity Network Halle' (Solidaritatsnetzwerk Halle), around 100 people, including a City Council Member (The Left), participated in a pro-Palestine protest in Halle (Saale) (Sachsen-Anhalt) during which allegedly anti-Semitic slogans were shouted. At the same time, people staged a pro-Israeli counter protest.

organizers: SDAJ: Socialist German Workers Youth; The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 April 2024, under the motto 'For peace and social justice', around 430 people, including Palestine supporters, SDAJ, 'Communist organization' (Kommunistische Organisation) and the Left, participated in a protest in Wedding in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) against war and calling for a free Palestine.

organizers: Students (Germany); The Left.SDS
description: On 29 April 2024, at the call of The Left.SDS, around 100 students staged a protest at the university in Koln (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against the decision of the university to allow the jurist and AfD lawyer Ulrich Vosgerau to keep his private lecture title and against the disinvitation of the US philosopher and feminist Nancy Fraser as an honorary professor. The context of the protest was a months-long investigation of the university against the jurist Vosgerau due to his participation in the secret meeting of right-wing extremist functionaries in November 2023 uncovered by the Correctiv network.

organizers: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 29 April 2024, at the call of the Kurdish community and MLPD, 70 people participated in a protest in Lubeck (Schleswig-Holstein) to express their outrage about the destruction of facilities of the Kurdish broadcasters SterkTV and Medya TV by Brussels police and to stand up for worldwide socialist liberation.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 29 April 2024, under the motto 'The Monday exists for Diversity' and at the call of several socio-cultural actors and the 'Alliance Clear Edge' (Bundnis Klare Kante), around 350 people, including the Left, CDU, the Greens, the Voters' Alliance 'Citizens for Gorlitz' (Burger fur Gorlitz, the working council 'Gorlitz Sustainable' (Gorlitz Anchali), 'Meetingpoint Memory Messiaen', 'A-Team', 'Ostritz' Peace Festival' (Ostritzer Friedensfest), 'Basta-Club' and the student club 'Mouse' (Maus), participated in a counter-protest in Gorlitz (Sachsen) for diversity and against the ongoing Monday demonstration. At the same time, around 260 people participated in the Monday demonstration without detailing the motives of the protest.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Students (Germany)
description: On 28 April 2024, at the call of associations and alliance, including 'Colorful' (BUNT), the 'Historical association' (Historischer Verein) and the local 'Social Association VDK' (Sozialverband VDK), between 200-300 (according to the police) and around 400 (organizers) people, including students, a state council member (FW), a protestant and catholic priest and the mayor (CSU), participated in a protest for diversity and democracy and against the AfD and hatred in Oberammergau (Bayern).
