organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Israeli Group (Germany); Jewish Group (Germany); Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 28 April 2024, under the motto 'Run for their lives' and 'Let our people go' and at the call of the Jewish Community, between 250 and 300 people, including two mayors (CDU), the 'Jewish Student Association NRW' (Judischer Studierendenverband NRW), the women's association 'WIZO', the association 'Kehilat NRW - Israeli Culture and Integration Association' (Israelischer Kultur und Integrationsverein Nordrhein-Westfalen e. V) and the state's Economics Minister (The Greens), participated in a protest in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen) calling for the release of Hamas' hostages and for solidarity with Israel.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Former Government of Germany (2021-); Government of Germany (2021-); Reich Citizens
description: On 27 April 2024, under the motto 'Oberlausitz for Peace - Together for freedom' and at the call of the initiative 'Blue Wave' (Blaue Welle) of the Compact Magazine which is classified as right-wing extremist, around 500 people, including Putin-supporters, Reich Citizens' members, former state chairman of the AfD Sachsen-Anhalt, and City Council Member Jorg Gullus (FDP), participated in a right-wing extremist protest in Zittau (Sachsen) to promote Putin's invasion of Ukraine as beneficial for Germany. They stated their support for Russia's foreign policy, criticized NATO, and used Reich Citizens' rhetoric about the occupation of Germany by the USA. At the call of a Regional Council Member (The Left), up to 230 people, including the mayor (Voters' Association 'Zittau can do more' (Zittau Kann Mehr (ZKM)), a Regional Council Candidate (CDU) and the State Secretary (CDU), participated in a counter protest. There were occasional verbal altercations between the participants of the two gatherings and 3 participants of the right-wing protest tried in vain without any physical action being reported to disrupt the counter protest several times.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Independent Politicians (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 27 April 2024, at the call of 'Initiative for Democracy' (Initiative fur Demokratie), more than 200 people, including the mayor (Independent), Grannies Against the Right, a member of the youth parliament and a State Council member (SPD), participated in a protest in Gehrden (Niedersachsen) against right-wing extremism, the AfD, hatred, xenophobia and agitation and for tolerance, diversity, democracy and solidarity.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 27 April 2024, under the motto 'Never again 1932' and at the call of 'Alliance Dessau Nazi-free' (Bundnis Dessau nazifrei), about 80 people, including a State Parliament member (The Left), participated in a protest in Dessau-Rosslau (Sachsen-Anhalt) against the AfD and fascism and to raise awareness for the similarities between historical and current developments.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); KFD: Catholic Women Association Germany; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 27 April 2024, under the mottos 'Sinsheim is colorful' and '75 Years Basic Law' and at the call of 'Alliance for Tolerance' (Bundnis fur Toleranz), between 400 and 500 people, including 40 associations, organizations, politicians, candidates for the local elections (FW, the Greens), Bundestag Members (The Greens, SPD), the deputy Chairman of the German-Ukrainian Society Rhine-Neckar (Deutsch-Ukrainische Gesellschaft Rhein-Neckar), Catholics, Grannies Against the Right and the Chairwoman of the Steinfurt KFD, participated in a protest in Sinsheim (Baden-Wurttemberg) for the Basic Law and against right-wing extremism, racism.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); Former Government of Germany (2021-); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 27 April 2024, around 400 people, including the former mayor (SPD), several associations and parties, representatives of the church, the local mayor (SPD), a member of the State Parliament (CDU) and the municipality mayor (SPD), participated in a protest in Ochtendung (Rheinland-Pfalz) against right-wing extremism, anti-Semitism, the AfD and xenophobia and for democracy, diversity and acceptance of other cultures and religions. The participants also called on people to vote in the upcoming local and EU elections.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 21 April 2024, at the call of the CDU, SPD, FW, FDP, Grannies Against the Right, 'Friendship Circle for Refuge and Asylum' (Freundeskreis Flucht und Asyl), and 'Family Forum in the Multigenerational House' (Familienforum im Mehrgenerationenhaus (MGH)), hundreds of people gathered in Markdorf (Baden-Wurttemberg), to protest against right-wing ideologies.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 21 April 2024, at the call of the District Association Koblenz/Rhein-Lahn of the Left, people gathered in Koblenz (Rheinland-Pfalz), to protest against a few aspects of the partial legalization of cannabis while expressing joy over the new law.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Government of Germany (2021-); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 18 April 2024, at the call of IGM under the motto 'SOS Bearing City - Future for Industrial Work in Schweinfurt', around 5,000 industrial workers from different companies, including Bosch Rexroth, Schaeffler, SKF, ZF Friedrichshafen, and Valeo, as well as the mayor (CSU) gathered in Schweinfurt (Bayern), to protest against the perceived gradual job losses due to the shift to electromobility and potential production relocation abroad, fearing the impact on their livelihoods and the regional economy.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DIG: German-Israeli Society; Government of Germany (2021-); Israeli Group (Germany); Jewish Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 16 April 2024, under the motto 'Hands off Israel! Together against the terror of the Islamic regime' and at the call of the 'Young Forum Saar' (Junges Forum Saar) and DIG, around 120 people, including the chairwoman of the 'Saar Synagogue Community' (Synagogengemeinde Saar), Minister President Anke Rehlinger (SPD), the state government's anti-Semitism commissioner, a number of state and local politicians and the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in front of the synagogue in Saarbrucken (Saarland) in solidarity with Israel in the context of Iran's recent missile attacks.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; BPD: The Grassroots Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 16 April 2024, around 300 people, including AfD and BPD, staged a protest against an event with FDP's European election candidate Marie-Agnes Strack-Zimmermann in Ravensburg (Baden-Wurttemberg) calling her a warmonger. They demanded peace without the use of weapons. There had previously been protests against Strack-Zimmermann by 'Youth Fights' (Jugendkampft).

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 16 April 2024, under the motto 'Moving Freiburg to the center', about 260 people, including representatives of the Left, SPD and Grannies Against the Right, participated in a protest in Freiburg im Breisgau (Baden-Wurttemberg) against the AfD's district association election campaign kick-off in the Burgerhaus Zahringen.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Independent Politicians (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: Around 15 April 2024 (as reported), about 50 people, including the candidates for the district council election (The Left, CDU, FDP, AfD, Independent), participated in a protest in Sulza (Thuringen) for two district roads in Saale-Holzland and better bus connections.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: Around 15 April 2024 (as reported), around 70 people, including the mayor (SPD) and a member of the Greens, participated in a protest in Hartlingen (Rheinland-Pfalz) for democracy, peace and freedom and against right-wing extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DIG: German-Israeli Society; Government of Germany (2021-); Israeli Group (Germany)
description: On 14 April 2024, under the motto 'Hands off Israel - against the Islamic missile terror of the Iranian regime' and at the call of the Young Forum of the DIG, around 100 people, including a city council member (CDU), participated in a protest in Leipzig (Sachsen) in solidarity with Israel and against Iran's direct attack on Israel. The participants also called for more solidarity with the protest movement in Iran.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DIG: German-Israeli Society; Government of Germany (2021-); Israeli Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 14 April 2024, under the motto 'Hands off Israel' and at the call of DIG, about 500 people, including a member of the Bundestag (the Greens) and the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest on Pariser Platz in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) in solidarity with Israel and against anti-Semitism and the Iranian attack on Israel.

organizers: DIG: German-Israeli Society; Government of Germany (2021-); Iranian Group (Germany); Israeli Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 14 April 2024, under the motto 'Against Iran's attack on Israel' and at the call of the DIG, around 120 people, including members of the Iranian Group and a member of the Bundestag (The Greens), participated in a protest in front of the Iranian Consulate General in Winterhude in Hamburg - Hamburg-Nord (Hamburg) in solidarity with Israel and against the Iranian attack on Israel.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 14 April 2024, around 300 people, including the mayor (CDU) and a state council member (SPD), participated in a protest in Mechernich (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against right-wing extremism and racism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; OEDP: Ecological Democratic Party; PP: Pirate Party (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Volt Europa
description: On 14 April 2024, at the call of Volt Europa, around 200 people, including SPD, OEDP, PP and the Alliance Against the Right, participated in a protest in Nurnberg (Bayern) to commemorate the Nurnberg trials and to demonstrate against right-wing extremism, the AfD, populism and for democracy.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 13 April 2024, senior citizens, including members of the Left, staged a protest in Hamburg - Eimsbuttel (Hamburg) for the construction of a public and barrier-free toilet with a changing table on Osterstrasse.

organizers: IGBCE: Industrial Union for Mining, Chemistry and Energy; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 13 April 2024, under the motto 'Never again is now' and at the call of the 'Alsdorf Alliance for Democracy' (Alsdorfer Bundnis fur Demokratie), around 500 people, including members of the SPD and IGBCE, participated in a protest in Alsdorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen) for democracy, humanity and diversity and against right-wing extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 13 April 2024, at the call of 'Hattingen for diversity and democracy' (Hattingen fur Vielfalt und Demokratie), a good 200 people, including a member of the Greens, participated in a protest in Hattingen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) for democracy, human dignity and the constitution and against racism, the AfD and the Monday protesters. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 12 April 2024, around 25 people, including members of the State Parliament (CDU and The Greens), participated in a pro-Israel protest in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) against anti-Semitism, Hamas, hatred, and division. The protest was organized to denounce the so-called 'Palestine-Congress' taking place on the weekend, which the protesters considered as a way to demonize and delegitimize Israel.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); Students (Germany); Teachers (Germany)
description: On 12 April 2024, people, including students, university lecturers, psychotherapists in training, newly qualified psychotherapists, representatives of training centers, psychotherapist associations, psychotherapist chambers, delegates of the 'German Institute for Pedagogical and Therapeutic Professions' (Deutsches Institut fur Padagogische und Therapeutische Berufe (DPT)) and the Bavarian State Minister for Health, Care and Prevention (CSU), staged a protest in Wurzburg (Bayern) to demand regulations for the funding of psychotherapeutic training by law.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 12 April 2024, at the call of the association 'Verden is colorful' (Verden ist bunt) and 'Untouchable' (Unantastbar), around 300 people, including students, the mayor (SPD) and Grannies Against the Right, participated in a protest in Verden (Niedersachsen) for democracy and against right-wing extremism and the AfD. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 12 April 2024, around 150 people, including Grannies Against the Right affiliates, members of the 'Citizens' Association Ohe' (Burgerverein Ohe) and the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in front of the castle in Reinbek (Schleswig-Holstein) against far-right extremism and for democracy, as an AfD event was simultaneously taking place inside the venue. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 12 April 2024, a handful of AfD supporters participated in a protest in Konigswinter (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against immigration. At the call of an alliance consisting of CDU, SPD, FDP, The Greens and the 'Konigswinter Voters' Initiative' (Konigswinter Wahlerinitiative), nearly 100 people, including the mayor (Konigswinter Voters' Initiative), participated in a counter-demonstration for diversity and against right-wing extremism.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 8 April 2024, hundreds of people, including activists and SPD affiliates, gathered in Dortmund (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to protest against a proposed industrial area in the Brechten district. Some cited environmental concerns.

organizers: Antifa; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 8 April 2024, around 200 people, including members of various entities, including 'Our Street stays Bright' (Unsere Strasse bleibt hell), Grannies Against the Right, The Left, and the North East Antifa, gathered outside the AfD party office in Blankenburg (Harz) (Sachsen-Anhalt) to protest against the visit of AfD European election candidate Maximilian Krah, aiming to express opposition to the AfD's political agenda.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 7 April 2024, at the call of the Alliance against Antisemitism and Antizionis, around 400 to 700 people, including members of the Protestant community, Lower Saxony State Parliament President Hanna Naber (SPD) and Mayor Jurgen Krogmann (SPD), as well as various other politicians from the SPD, gathered in Oldenburg (Niedersachsen) to express their solidarity with the Jewish community following a recent arson attack on a local synagogue. The protest was organized to denounce antisemitism.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 7 April 2024, at the call of local councilor Thorge Heinisch (The Left) and supported by various organizations, around 300 people gathered at the market square in Sande (Niedersachsen) to protest for democracy, diversity, and tolerance in response to an incident involving an AfD sticker on a memorial site.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 7 April 2024, at the call of the Alliance for Democracy and Tolerance, around 150 people, including Member of the Bundestag Jens Brandenburg (FDP) and district board politician Busra Isik (SPD), gathered in Sandhausen (Baden-Wurttemberg) to protest for democracy and tolerance and against right-wing extremism.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 7 April 2024, at the call of the 'Together for Democracy and Diversity' alliance, around 60 people, including city councilor Hans Schmidt (The Greens), gathered in Gelting (Bayern) to participate in a bicycle rally against right-wing extremism.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 7 April 2024, under the motto 'Wesertal is Colorful', around 60 people, including state parliament members Esther Dilcher (SPD) and Jan Kersting (The Left), gathered in Gieselwerder (Hessen) to protest against the presence of around 40 neonazis who had gathered to honor convicted criminal Rudolf Hess on that day.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 6 April 2024, 45 AfD affiliates took to the streets in Lunen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to demonstrate in support of their party line. 650 people took to the streets for a counter-demonstration, at the call of the Action Circle against Right-Wing Extremism, against right-wing extremism and the AfD.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 April 2024, under the motto 'Release the hemp', one dozen people, including several representatives of the Left, protested in Essen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) for a liberal drug policy and criticized that the regulations of the new cannabis law are over-bureaucratized. The protest was organized in the context of the partial legalization of cannabis on 1 April 2024.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 1 April 2024, under the motto 'Without peace, everything is nothing' and at the call of AfD, more than 500 people, including AfD representatives such as national chairman Tino Chrupalla and state chairman Jorg Urban, participated in a peace protest in Dresden (Sachsen) against arms delivers to Ukraine. The event was organized as the AfD's election campaign's kick off event.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Labor Group (Germany); NGPM: Network of the German Peace Movement; Querdenken; Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 1 April 2024, more than 300 people, including members of Querdenken, Ver.di, and the AfD, participated in a peace protest in Rostock (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern). The event was part of the traditional annual Easter peace protests coordinated by the NGPM and supported by 50 initiatives and organizations, including labor unions, political parties, the church (Christian groups), and migration organizations.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Former Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); NGPM: Network of the German Peace Movement; The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 April 2024, under the motto 'Put down your weapons! Peace-capable instead of war-capable', around 1,000 people, including a former State Parliament member (The Left), participated in a peace protest in Frankfurt am Main (Hessen) against armament, arms deliveries and war. The event was part of the traditional annual Easter peace protests coordinated by the NGPM and supported by 50 initiatives and organizations, including labor unions, political parties, the church (Christian groups), and migration organizations.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Last Generation (Austria); NGPM: Network of the German Peace Movement; Protesters (Austria); Protesters (Switzerland); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 1 April 2024, under the motto 'Peace Power Europe', around 300 people, including member of the Austrian Last Generation, a Bundestag member (SPD) and representatives of the 'Group for a Switzerland without an Army' (Gruppe fur eine Schweiz ohne Armee), participated in a peace protest in Friedrichshafen (Baden-Wurttemberg) for justice and climate protection and against nuclear weapons. The event was part of the traditional annual Easter peace protests coordinated by the NGPM and supported by 50 initiatives and organizations, including labor unions, political parties, the church (Christian groups), and migration organizations.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 April 2024, a good 50 people, including a city council member (The Greens), a SPD member, and several members of the Left, protested in Leipzig (Sachsen) to demand a right to intoxication and further legalization of cannabis. The context of the protest was the partial legalization of cannabis on 1 April 2024.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany)
description: On 30 March 2024, in the evening, under the motto 'Peace with Russia' and at the call of the right-wing extremist magazine 'Compact', about 300 people, including AfD members, a Bundestag member (Independent), and Russia supporters, participated in a protest in Velten (Brandenburg) for peace, against the German government, and in solidarity with Russia. At the call of the Left, a good 100 people participated in a counter protest against the event.

organizers: Alliance Sahra Wagenknecht; Christian Group (Germany); Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; NGPM: Network of the German Peace Movement; Protestant Christian Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 March 2024, under the motto 'Active against the threat of world war - take to the streets' and at the call of 'Wilhelmshaven Easter March 2024 Alliance' (Wilhelmshavener Bundnis Ostermarsch 2024), about 60 people, including members of labor unions, the Kurdish movement, the Left, Alliance Sahra Wagenknecht, MLPD and the protestant church, participated in a protest in Wilhelmshaven (Niedersachsen) against the militarization of society, the arms deliveries to Ukraine and the Israeli government's war against the Palestinian people. They showed support for Palestinians. The event was part of the traditional annual Easter peace protests coordinated by the NGPM and supported by 50 initiatives and organizations, including labor unions, political parties, the church (Christian groups), and migration organizations.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 30 March 2024, around 350 people, including midwives, ambulance drivers, members of the CDU and members of the midwives' association, participated in a protest in Preetz (Schleswig-Holstein) against the closure of the delivery room in the local hospital.

organizers: AI: Amnesty International; Catholic Christian Group (Germany); Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); NGPM: Network of the German Peace Movement; Pax Christi; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 30 March 2024, about 2,100 people, including Pax Christi, members of various left-wing and communist parties and labor unions, many Ukrainians, Amnesty International, and a city council member (SPD), participated in a peace protest in Stuttgart (Baden-Wurttemberg) against violence, media's reporting on weapons, and Germany's arms deliveries to Israel. They were also against Russia and wanted to show support for Ukraine. Protesters also called for aid deliveries to people in the occupied territories in Palestine. The event was part of the traditional annual Easter peace protests coordinated by the NGPM and supported by 50 initiatives and organizations, including labor unions, political parties, the church (Christian groups) and migration organizations.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); NGPM: Network of the German Peace Movement; The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 March 2024, under the motto 'We do not pay for wars! Stop the killing in Palestine, Ukraine and all over the world' and at the call of the Left, the alliance 'Stop the war' (Stoppt den Krieg), 'Action alliance Peace Movement South Westfalen' (Aktionsbundnis Friedensbewegung Sudwestfalen) and the anti-racist alliance 'Zaytun', around 70 people participated in a peace protest in Siegen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against rearmament, weapons and the renaissance of old military concepts in foreign policy'. The event was part of the traditional annual Easter peace protests coordinated by the NGPM and supported by 50 initiatives and organizations, including labor unions, political parties, the church (Christian groups), and migration organizations.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); NGPM: Network of the German Peace Movement; The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 March 2024, under the motto 'For a civilian turnaround, end wars, stop rearmament', about 700 people, including a Bundestag Member (The Left), started the three day peace protest 'Rhein-Ruhr' in Koln (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against rearmament, weapons, the renaissance of old military concepts in foreign policy and for peace. Protesters denounced what they perceived as an aggression against Russia. The event was part of the traditional annual Easter peace protests coordinated by the NGPM and supported by 50 initiatives and organizations, including labor unions, political parties, the church (Christian groups), and migration organizations.

organizers: Alliance Sahra Wagenknecht; Antifa; DKP: German Communist Party; Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 March 2024, under the motto 'Ready for war - never again', around 3,500 people, including the representatives of the 'Peace Coordination Berlin' (Friedenskooperation Berlin), the Left, Alliance Sahra Wagenknecht, DKP, Marxist groups, Antifa, labor unions and anti-Israel activists, participated in a peace protest in Berlin - Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg (Berlin) for disarmament and against arms deliveries for Ukraine, the increase in the arms budget, Bundeswehr maneuvers and the deployment of German soldiers on Russia's border. Some participants also used left-wing, anti-Israel and conspiracy slogans or called for Germany's withdrawal from NATO or for peace negotiations with Russia and in Gaza. A counter protest was staged under the motto 'Transverse front is betrayal of the working class', referring to the mixing of right-wing and left-wing positions.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 March 2024, in the afternoon at the call of 'Alliance for Dialogue and Tolerance' (Bundnis fur Dialog und Toleranz), about 300 people, including a pastor and members of the SPD, The Left and the Greens, participated in a protest in Velten (Brandenburg) against right-wing extremism, exclusion and agitation and for democracy, freedom and the dignity of all.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 30 March 2024, at the call of Alliance Against the Right, 500 people, including the mayor (SPD) and representatives of the church, participated in a protest in Eckernforde (Schleswig-Holstein) against far-right extremism and for diversity, human rights and democracy. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 29 March 2024, GJ and Jusos staged a protest in Frankfurt am Main (Hessen) and called for the abolition of the ban on dancing on Good Friday and for the 'freedom of individual decisions and against patronizing and religiously motivated laws'.

organizers: JL: Young Liberals
description: On 29 March 2024, at the call of JL, people participated in a protest in front of the State Parliament in Wiesbaden (Hessen) and called for the abolition of the ban on dancing on Good Friday which they consider to not fit into a liberal, secular society.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; The Left (Germany)
description: On 28 March 2024, at the call of a broad alliance, 250 people, including a State Parliament member (The Left) and MLPD and REBELL representatives, participated in a peace protest in Erfurt (Thuringen) against war. The participants also accused Russia and NATO as warmongers, criticized the German government's loyalty to the Israeli government and pointed out wars' negative consequences for the environment. The event was part of the nationwide peace marches coordinated annually at Easter by the Peace Cooperative.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 28 March 2024, people, including representatives of labor unions, 'Landliebe - dairy plants' employees and the mayor (SPD), participated in a protest in Heilbronn (Baden-Wurttemberg) against the planned plant closures in Heilbronn and Schefflenz. They also gathered in front of the Kaufland meat plant.

organizers: Aid Workers (Germany); CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross; Independent Politicians (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 28 March 2024, under the motto '48 hours', about 60 people, including employees of the rescue services and the German Red Cross (DRK) as well as Ver.di members, members of the 'Federal Tariff Commission of the DRK', Stuhr's mayor (The Greens), Weyhe's mayor (SPD), Bassum's mayor (Independent), two members of the Bundestag (SPD & CDU) and two members of the State Parliament (SPD & CDU), participated in a protest in Kirchweyhe (Niedersachsen) to raise awareness for their challenging working conditions and call for shorter working hours. The protest was organized in the context of public bargaining negotiations.

organizers: Antifa; Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany); Turkish Group (Germany)
description: On 28 March 2024, at the call of the 'Turkish People's Association Solingen and the Surrounding Area' (Turkischer Volksverein Solingen und Umgebung), 'Armin T. Wegner Association' (Armin T- Wegner Gesellschaft), Antifa, 'Solingen Appeal' (Solinger Appell), 'Amadeu Antonio Foundation' (Amadeu Antonio Stiftung), 'Initiative against right-wing extremism, racism and anti-Semitism' (Initiative gegen Rechtsextremismus, Rassismus und Antisemitismus), more than 150 people, including a member of the city council (The Greens), participated in a protest in the district of Hochscheid in Solingen (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to commemorate the victims of an arson attack with a possible racist, xenophobic motive on Monday 25 March 2024. The participants called for vigilance against xenophobia, demanded investigations and to not rule out a xenophobic motive from the start.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 28 March 2024, at the call of 'Alliance for Democracy and Tolerance', around 200 people, including representatives of the church, labor unions, the Greens, DGB, the Alliance Against the Right and schools as well as two Bundestag members (SPD, CDU), students and the superintendent of the Protestant church district, participated in a protest in Wetschen (Niedersachsen) for democracy, tolerance, and justice. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 27 March 2024, at the call of groups belonging to the left-spectrum, just under 100 people, including Jusos, participated in a protest in Stralsund (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) against a planned event of the AfD that day. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 25 March 2024, around 250 people, including Grannies Against the Right, SPD and CDU politicians gathered in Colditz (Sachsen), to protest for democracy, diversity, and tolerance, emphasizing the importance of defending democratic values against racism, homophobia, and other forms of discrimination.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 25 March 2024, around 150 people, including SPD politicians, gathered in Heidelberg (Baden-Wurttemberg), to protest against an AfD event, expressing concerns over the rise of right-wing ideologies and the AfD's influence in Germany. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 25 March 2024, around 250 people, including Interior Minister Georg Maier (SPD), gathered in Bad Bibra (Sachsen-Anhalt), to protest against the AfD. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Former Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 24 March 2024, under the motto 'Solidarity in the Lambrecht Valley: Against Extremism, Racism, and Discrimination,' organized by former Mayor Michael Stohr (CDU) and former Deputy Mayor Eva Ockenfus-Boese (The Greens), around 20 people gathered in Lambrecht (Rheinland-Pfalz). The event aimed to advocate for democracy and denounce extremism, racism, and discrimination in the region.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 23 March 2024, under the motto 'Trifelsland stays colorful instead of blue-brown', hundreds of people, including Grannies Against the Right and SPD councilor of Annweiler, gathered in Annweiler am Trifels (Rheinland-Pfalz), to protest against an AfD event taking place that day. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 23 March 2024, as part of the 'Together for Democracy and Diversity' alliance, around 80 people, including Third Deputy Mayor Annette Heinloth (The Greens) and Councilor Patrick Lechner (FDP), gathered in Wolfratshausen (Bayern) forming a large heart symbol to protest against rising right-wing ideologies.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Farmers (Germany)
description: On 22 March 2024, between around 160 and a maximum of 200 farmers and vehicle drivers, including the German Farmers' Association (Deutschen Bauernverband), an AfD representative, and affiliates of conspiracy ideologies and far-right movements, gathered at the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) to protest against the policies of the federal coalition government, notably regarding agriculture. They demonstrated under the motto 'Middle class holds together Saxony/South Brandenburg'. Some people carried Russian flags. The event was part of a nationwide farmers' demonstration movement.

organizers: Caritas; Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 21 March 2024, on the occasion of the International Week against Racsim and under the motto 'Human Rights for All', around 50 people, including Caritas affiliates, gathered in Hannover (Niedersachsen) to protest against racism. Hannover's Mayor (The Greens), emphasized the city's commitment to diversity.

organizers: Farmers (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 March 2024, under the motto 'Agricultural policies need to be pragmatic' and at the call of the 'Farmer's association Heilbronn-Ludwigsburg' (Bauernverband Heilbronn-Ludwigsburg), more than 400 people, including farmers and the mayor (SPD), with 200 tractors gathered on Wartberg in Heilbronn (Baden-Wurttemberg), some reaching it as convoys, to demonstrate. The event was part of a nationwide farmers' demonstration movement against several agricultural policies of the federal government, including planned agricultural subsidy cuts.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 March 2024, under the motto 'Orms is and remains colorful', people, including the mayor (SPD), participated in a protest in Urmitz (Rheinland-Pfalz) against racism and for more tolerance, diversity, and respect. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 16 March 2024, under the motto 'Schluchtern shows color', about 350 people, including a city councilor (SPD), a protestant priest, the mayor (Independent), the association 'Hand on Heart' (Hand aufs Herz), the Home and History association 'Mountain Angle' (Bergwinkel), and representatives of the SPD, CDU, The Greens and FDP, participated in a protest in Schluchtern (Hessen) for democracy, tolerance, acceptance and diversity, and against the AfD and right-wing extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)

The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 2 March 2024, under the motto 'Protect democracy! Unmask the AfD!' and at the call of a local alliance, up to 1,000 people, including members of the SPD and Jusos, participated in a protest in Herzogenrath (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against right-wing extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 2 March 2024, under the motto 'Stand up against racism - for freedom and democracy', 350 people, including the mayors of Langenlonsheim-Stromberg (CDU) and Guldental (SPD), members of the state parliament (CDU and SPD), DGB District Chairman (SPD), and church representatives, participated in a protest in Guldental (Rheinland-Pfalz) against racism, the AfD, anti-Semitism, sexism, misanthropy and right-wing extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Students (Germany)
description: On 2 March 2024, at the call of the 'Alliance for democracy and Diversity' (Bundnis fur Demokratie und Vielfalt), consisting of 20 institutions, organizations and associations, more than 650 people, including the mayor (CDU), students, a priest and city councilors, participated in a protest in Hofgeismar (Hessen) for democracy and diversity. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 1 March 2024, at the call of FFF and Ver.di, about 3,200 people, including a Bundestag member (The Greens), public transport employees and representatives of MLPD, participated in a protest in Hannover (Niedersachsen) for climate protection and better working conditions in the public transport sector. The event was part of a nationwide campaign called 'We Ride Together' organized by Ver.di and FFF, focusing on the need for better public transportation jobs.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 1 March 2024, at the call of Ver.di and FFF, about 400 people, including about 30 to 40 Ver.di members, State Parliament Members (SPD), Bundestag Members (SPD), environmental activists, IGM representatives, as well as members of MLPD and REBELL, participated in a protest in Bochum (Nordrhein-Westfalen) for climate protection and better working conditions in the public transport sector. The event was part of a nationwide campaign called 'We Ride Together' organized by Ver.di and FFF, focusing on the need for better public transportation jobs.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Students (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 1 March 2024, around 500 people, including Grannies Against the Right, the mayor (CDU) and students, staged a protest in Spaichingen (Baden-Wurttemberg) against right-wing extremism, agitation, hatred and racism and for democracy and human rights. The event aimed to draw attention to historical events and condemn recent nationalist incidents in the region. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Farmers (Germany)
description: On 28 February 2024, around 300 people staged a protest in Lubben (Spreewald) (Brandenburg), advocating against a local, planned refugee accomodation, focusing on broader political issues. The protesters discussed national topics like arms exports, agricultural appreciation, and education, with a presence of tractors, farmers, and AfD representatives.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 26 February 2024, people staged a protest in Treysa (Hessen), demonstrating against right-wing extremism. The event, organized by various groups and with the participation of SPD, The Greens, CDU, FDP and FW, happened following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: The Greens (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2024, around 1,000 people, including members of the Ukrainian community and a Green politician, staged a protest in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg), advocating for peace and solidarity with Ukraine. The protest took place on the second anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 24 February 2024, people staged a protest in Mainz (Rheinland-Pfalz), advocating for peace and solidarity with Ukraine. Rhineland-Palatinate Interior Minister Michael Ebling (SPD) participated in the protest, which took place on the second anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with nationwide actions taking place in various cities across Germany.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 24 February 2024, several hundred people staged a protest in Neubrandenburg (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) against right-wing extremism and xenophobia. Bundesrat President Manuela Schwesig (SPD) started the event with a speech. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Antifa; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 24 February 2024, around 2,000 people staged a protest in Rottweil (Baden-Wurttemberg), against a simultaneous AfD conference. The event, organized by the Alliance for Democracy and Diversity, included participants from various groups like IG Metall, MLPD, Autonome Antifa activists, families and youth, and happened following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2024, around 150 people staged a protest in Renningen (Baden-Wurttemberg), advocating for peace and solidarity with Ukraine. The event was organized by various groups and members of the CDU, The Greens, and the SPD and took place on the second anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with nationwide actions taking place in various cities across Germany.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: Around 20 February 2024 (as reported), students of the elementary school Am Castrum participated in a protest in Gehrden (Niedersachsen) to set a sign for climate protection. The mayor (Independent) and a building committee member (The Greens) joined the protest for discussion. The context of the protest are plans of the city to fell 45 trees due to the imminent demolition and new construction of the school.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 20 February 2024, at the call of the alliance 'Schwerin for everyone', around 600 people, including Mecklenburg-Vorpommern's Minister President (SPD), participated in a protest in Schwerin (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern). The protest was organized against right-wing extremism and exclusion and for democracy and tolerance. The participants also commemorated Alexei Navalny, the victims of the racist attack in Hanau 4 years ago, and Mehmet Turgut (who was killed 20 years ago by right-wing extremist NSU-activists).

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Students (Germany)
description: On 20 February 2024, several thousand people, including students, CDU members, '151, the autonomous, extremist Action' (151, die autonome, extremistische Aktion), participated in a protest in Herne (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against right-wing extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 19 February 2024, at the call of Ver.di, 650 to 700 employees of Ustra (according to police) or around 1,200 (according to Ver.di), including bus and tram drivers as well as the mayor (The Greens), participated in a protest in Hannover (Niedersachsen) to demand better working conditions, more vacation days and better shift times.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 19 February 2024, at the call of the 'State Association of Municipal Migrant Representatives' (Landesverband der kommunalen Migranten Vertretungen), just under 200 people, including a city council member (SPD), participated in a protest in Stuttgart (Baden-Wurttemberg). The protest was organized to commemorate the victims of the racist attack in Hanau 4 years ago as well as all other victims of right-wing extremist violence and to set a sign for diversity.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 19 February 2024, at the call of the local 'Integration Council' (Integrationsrat), just under 100 people, including the mayor (The Greens), participated in a protest in Bonn (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against racism and right-wing extremism, to commemorate the victims of the racist attack in Hanau 4 years ago and to set a sign for the equal coexistence of people with and without a migration background.

organizers: ADFC: German Bicycle Club; BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; NABU: Nature and Biodiversity Conservation Union; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Volt Europa
description: On 18 February 2024, around 80 people, including representatives of ADFC, BUND, NABU, 'Climate decision Duisburg' (Klimaentscheid Duisburg), The Left, The Greens and Volt Europa, participated in a cycling protest in Duisburg (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against the tree policies of the city administration and the felling of trees. They argued that although preserving the trees was costly, it was worth it from a climate perspective.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 18 February 2024, around 200 citizens, including members of The Greens, and 3 mayors (CDU & SPD), participated in a protest on the road L412 between the two districts Arpke and Sievershausen in Lehrte (Niedersachsen) against the condition of the road and the repeated postponement of the promised refurbishment.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 February 2024, around 200 people, including the mayor (SPD) and representatives of IGM, participated in a protest in Rosenberg (Baden) (Baden-Wurttemberg) against the impending closure of the Magna plant.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 18 February 2024, at the call of the alliance 'Shoulder-to-shoulder alliance of Wolfsburg democrats' (Schulterschluss der Wolfsburger Demokraten) consisting of political parties, labor unions, the soccer team VfL Wolfsburg and the VW Group, around 6,000 people, including the VW Group's CEO and Head of Works Council, as well as the mayor (CDU) and members of the soccer club VfL Wolfsburg, participated in a protest in Wolfsburg (Niedersachsen). The protest was organized under the motto 'For Democracy and Cohesion' against far-right extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Unitary Democratic Coalition; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 18 February 2024, at the call of 'Democratic Network Hunsruck-Hochwald' (Demokratisches Netzwerk Hunsruck-Hochwald) 400 to 500 people, including a State Parliament Member (CDU) and the church, participated in a protest in Idar-Oberstein (Rheinland-Pfalz) against right-wing extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: Around 18 February 2024 (as reported), at the call of Jusos, just under 1,000 people, including the mayor (SPD) and a State Parliament member (SPD), participated in a protest in Gladbeck (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to commemorate the victims of the racist attack in Hanau 4 years ago. The protest was organized under the motto 'Hanau is always and everywhere' against racism and resentment. At the call of the AfD, around 20 people participated in a counter protest.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 18 February 2024, at the call of a broad alliance of political parties on the initiative of the local CDU leader, between 1,000 and 1,200 people, including a catholic priest, members of the city council (CDU), The Greens, SPD, FDP and FW as well as the CDU top candidate in the state for the European elections and members of the 'Youth Delegation Kornwestheim' (Jugenddelegation Kornwestheim), participated in a protest in Kornwestheim (Baden-Wurttemberg). The protest was organized under the motto 'It is Time to set a Sign' against right-wing extremism and for democracy and diversity. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 18 February 2024, 230 people, including a State Parliament Member (The Left), participated in a protest in Schnellroda (Sachsen-Anhalt) against the 'Institute for State Policy' (IfS - Institut fur Staatspolitik) which is classified as right-wing extremist. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 February 2024, at the call of the alliance 'Cosmopolitan Werder' (Weltoffenes Werder) and more than 30 initiatives, around 1,000 people, including representatives of SPD and the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in Werder (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern). The protest was organized against the political shift to the right, right-wing extremism, and racism and for democracy. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Unitary Democratic Coalition; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of the citizens alliance 'Hand in Hand', around 80 people, including the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in Merzig (Saarland) for solidarity with employees in agriculture, gastronomy, trade and logistics. The protesters expressed their dissatisfaction with the policies of the federal coalition government, the removal of subsidies in agriculture and the increase in tolls in logistics and called for a reduction in bureaucracy, more planning security and improved competitiveness. The event was part of a nationwide demonstration movement against the federal government and its economic and agricultural policies.

organizers: Farmers (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, people, including farmers, craftsmen, other entrepreneurs, Kloster Lehnin's mayor (Independent), other mayor of the region and Brandenburg's Agricultural Minister (The Greens), participated in a protest on the road B1 near Jeserig (Brandenburg) and partly blocked the road with their vehicles causing people to slalom. The event was part of a nationwide demonstration movement against the federal government and its economic and agricultural policies.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, up to 3,000 people, including FDP Security politician Marie-Agnes Strack-Zimmermann and Green politician Anton Hofreiter, participated in a protest in Munchen (Bayern) on Odeonsplatz for peace in Ukraine and to demand more support from the western states. The protest occurred in the context of the Munich Security Conference taking place the same weekend.

organizers: The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, a couple dozen people, including members of the Greens and the Left, participated in a protest near Remagen (Rheinland-Pfalz) against the founding of the new political party 'Werteunion'. For the founding of the party Hans-Georg Maassen, former president of the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, and his supporters met on a chartered excursion boat on the Rhine near Remagen.

organizers: Antifa; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of SPD Lichterfelde Ost and Sud, the Left and the alliance 'SZ cosmopolitan' (SZ weltoffen), up to 1,500 people, including Antifa, participated in a protest in Lichterfelde in Berlin - Steglitz-Zehlendorf (Berlin) against a discussion event with former AfD politician Andre Poggenburg and right-wing extremism. The protest was organized under the motto 'Our neighborhood is colorful. No space for Racism'. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of a private entrepreneur, around 2,500 people, including Grannies Against the Right, the church community, labor unions, Member of the Bundestag Ralf Stegner (SPD) and former minister president of Schleswig-Holstein Peter Harry Carstensen (CDU), participated in a protest in Bordesholm (Schleswig-Holstein) against right-wing extremism. The protest was organized under the motto 'Demonstration against the Right!' against extremism, hatred, anti-Semitism, xenophobia, agitation and the AfD. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of the initiative 'Roth is colorful' around 2,000 people, including a member of the State Parliament (SPD) participated in a protest in Roth (Bayern) against right-wing extremism and for democracy. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)

The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FFF: Fridays for Future; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Seebruecke; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)

The protest was organized under the motto 'Bochum in solidarity - hand in hand against the Right'. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, around 2,500 people, including people with a migration background, the mayor (The Greens), students, representatives of the Disability Advisory Council (Behindertenbeirat), and the Seniors' Advisory Council (Seniorenbeirat) participated in a protest in Rheinberg (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against right-wing extremism, xenophobia, violence, and exclusion. They called for tolerance and peace. Protesters also commemorated Alexei Navalny, the victims of the racist attack in Hanau 4 years ago, and all other victims of right-wing extremist violence. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); Students (Germany); Women (Germany)

The protest was organized under the motto 'We in Bedburg for democracy - United in Diversity' against right-wing extremism, hatred, the AfD and exclusion. They called for diversity and democracy. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of all parties and parliamentary groups represented in the city council, as well as more than 30 associations, the churches and labor unions, around 2,000 people, including representatives of FDP, The greens, SPD, FW, CDU, the protestant church and the 'Alliance for Diversity and Tolerance' (Bundnis fur Vielfalt und Toleranz) as well as the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in Bad Durkheim (Rheinland-Pfalz). The protest was organized under the motto 'Never again is now! Stand up for Democracy' against right-wing extremism. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of a broad alliance of political parties, associations and institutions, between 800 and 1,200 people, including a protestant priest, the chairman of the 'Association of Sponsors of the Kaltenkirchen Concentration Camp Memorial Site' (Tragerverein der KZ-Gedenkstatte Kaltenkirchen), the local SPD-chairwoman and the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in Kaltenkirchen (Schleswig-Holstein). The protest was organized under the motto 'Together strong for democracy and Diversity' against far-right extremism, racism, anti-Semitism and agitation. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany)

The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

The protest was organized under the motto 'Stand up. Look. Defend Democracy' to set a joint, strong and peaceful sign for freedom of speech, tolerance and diversity. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Protestant Christian Group (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of a protestant priest, about 1,000 people, including the mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in Grunstadt (Rheinland-Pfalz) for democracy. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of 'Alliance for Dialogue and Tolerance' (Bundnis fur Dialog und Toleranz), around 200 people, including the mayor (SPD), participated in a protest in Velten (Brandenburg). The protest was organized under the motto 'And where do you stand?' against far-right extremism, the division of the society, exclusion, and xenophobia as well as against a planned public festival by a right-wing extremist magazine. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 February 2024, at the call of political parties, the Church, and several associations and organizations, around 400 people, including the mayor, a City councilor (SPD), a protestant priest (representing also catholic church communities) and representatives of DGB, participated in a protest in Neckarsteinach (Hessen). The protest was organized under the motto 'Neckarsteinach for democracy' against right-wing extremism.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Farmers (Germany); Former Government of Germany (2021-); FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 February 2024, around 1,500 people, including numerous mayors (CDU), State Parliament Members (SPD & CDU), the former Minister of the Interior, representatives of the catholic and protestant church, DGB representatives, members of the Greens and FW, a school principal, and members of the German Farmers' Association, participated in a protest in Nastatten (Rheinland-Pfalz). The protest was organized under the motto 'Rhein-Lahn-District stands up against the Right' against racism, right-wing extremism and xenophobia. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Students (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 16 February 2024, at the call of Ver.di and FFF, around 2,500 people, including bus drivers and several local and state politicians (FDP and 'South Schleswig Voters' Association' (Sudschleswigsche Wahlerverband (SSW)) participated in a protest in Kiel (Schleswig-Holstein) and handed over a petition for better public transport funding to politicians to tackle climate change. The bus drivers from municipal companies have been on a warning strike since Wednesday, private companies joined yesterday.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 16 February 2024, at the call of 'Free Russia NRW' (Freies Russland NRW), about 300 people, including State Parliament Members (The Greens), participated in a protest in Dusseldorf (Nordrhein-Westfalen) to commemorate Alexei Navalny and protest against the Russian regime.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 16 February 2024, at least 30,000 people, including representatives of SPD, The Greens, the Left, Munster's social associations, churches, the city's Integration Council and the 'Youth Alliance against Anti-Semitism' (Jugendbundnis gegen Antisemitismus) as well as around 30 mayors of the region, including Munster's Mayor (CDU), participated in a protest in Munster (Nordrhein-Westfalen) against right-wing extremism, hatred, exclusion, racism and xenophobia and for democracy, human dignity, tolerance and diversity. The context of the protest was the AfD's New Year's reception in the city hall. The protest was organized following reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and far-right activists in Potsdam in November 2023, during which remigration plans were discussed.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany

description: On 14 February 2024, 22 mayors, including Christian Scheuerer (independent) and Elisabeth Koch (CSU), gathered in front of the hospital in Garmisch-Partenkirchen (Bayern) to protest against the federal government's health policies which according to the protesters caused the hospital's financial hardship and to demand financial support.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Students (Germany); Teachers (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)

Earlier, students and teachers had held a similar protest. The dance demonstration was part of the worldwide 'One Billion Rising' campaign, which was launched in 2012 by US playwright, author and artist Eve Ensler.

The protest was prompted by concerns over a secret meeting between AfD representatives and extremists, discussing mass deportations of individuals with German citizenship and migrant backgrounds, leading to a heightened awareness and mobilization against right-wing ideologies in various cities.

description: On 15 January 2024, between 400 and 500 people participated in a protest in Trier (Rheinland-Pfalz) called for by a broad alliance of SPD, the Greens, the Left and representatives of the LGBTQ+ community, against the AfD and right-wing groups to set a sign for democracy.

organizers: Attac; FFF: Fridays for Future; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 15 January 2024, around 1,500 people participated in a protest in Tubingen (Baden-Wurttemberg) called for by FFF and supported by Ver.di, SPD, The Greens, The Left, Attac and various student organizations, under the motto 'Protect Democracy - Tubingen against the Right'. The protest was organized after recent reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and right-wing extremists in Potsdam past November.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 14 January 2024, about 4,800 people, including District Administrator Roland Grillmeier (CSU), participated in a protest in Tirschenreuth (Bayern) called for by 'Clinic Rescue Initiative' (Initiative Klinik Retten) for the preservation of the clinics in the district of Tirschenreuth and against the restructuring plans of Kliniken Nordoberpfalz AG (KNO).

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Farmers (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 14 January 2024, around 400 people, including Member of the state parliament Winfried Mack (CDU) and Kirchheim's mayor Danyel Atalay, with around 100 tractors participated in a protest in Kirchheim (Hersfeld-Rotenburg, Hessen). The event was part of a nationwide farmers' demonstration movement against planned agricultural subsidy cuts.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Farmers (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany)
description: Around 14 January 2024 (as reported), around 250 people, including farmers and other entrepreneurs as well as representatives of the State Farmers' Association (Landesbauernverband) and mayor Gunter Buhler (CDU), protested in Bopfingen (Ostalbkreis, Baden-Wurttemberg) with a warning fire. The event was part of a nationwide farmers' demonstration movement against planned agricultural subsidy cuts.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 14 January 2024, around 10,000 people, including mayor Mike Schubert (SPD), Brandenburg's Minister for Culture Manja Schule (SPD), Federal Chancellor Olaf Scholz (SPD) and Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock (The Greens), as well as many families with children and members of the left spectrum, participated in a protest in Potsdam (Brandenburg), called for by the alliance 'Potsdam shows color' (Potsdam bekennt Farbe) to set a sign against far-right ideologies. The protest occurred after recent reports of a secret meeting between AfD members and right-wing extremists in Potsdam past November.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Students (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany); XR: Extinction Rebellion
description: On 14 January 2024, 25,000 people, including human rights activists, Left Party Federal Chair Janine Wissler, participated in a protest in Berlin - Mitte (Berlin) called for by 'Joint General Association' (Paritatischer Gesamtverband), Fridays for Future, and numerous other organizations, and supported by Jusos, GJ, Grannies Against the Right, Extinction Rebellion and the association 'Hawwar help' (an association that stands up for a self-determined life in safety for everyone) under the motto 'Defend democracy, stick together' against the shift to the right in Germany and the AfD. The protest occurred in the context of recent reports of a secret meeting between AfD members and right-wing extremists in Potsdam past November.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Left Youth Solid; Mission Lifeline; Seebruecke; Students (Germany)
description: On 14 January 2024, between 1,000 and 2,000 people, including many families and children as well as members of 'Dresden Resists' (Dresden Widersetzen), participated in a protest in Dresden (Sachsen) under the motto 'Protect Democracy' (Demokratie verteidigen) against the AfD and racism and to show solidarity with migrantized and racialized people, queer people, Jews, and disabled people. Several alliances, including FFF, Seebruecke, GJ, Jusos, Left Youth Solid, the Student Council of the Technical University in Dresden and Mission Lifeline, had called for the protest after reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and right-wing extremists in Potsdam past November.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 14 January 2024, around 700 people, including mayor Eva Weber (CSU), participated in a protest in Augsburg (Bayern) called for by Jusos and GJ against the AfD and the party's plans for remigration. The protest was organized after recent reports about a secret meeting between AfD members and right-wing extremists in Potsdam past November.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FFF: Fridays for Future; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); JL: Young Liberals; JU: Young Union; Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Labor Group (Germany); Left Youth Solid; Students (Germany)
