description: On 8 April 2023, at the call of Ver.di, striking employees of department store chain Galeria Kaufhof gathered at Herbert-Wehner-Platz in Hamburg - Harburg, to protest against planned job cuts. The senator of finance, Andreas Dessel (SPD), addressed the protesters claiming solidarity.

organizers: DKP: German Communist Party; Evangelical Christian Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; The Left (Germany)
description: On 8 April 2023, around 300 people, among which were members of MLPD, REBELL, The Left, DKP, and evangelical groups, staged a protest march through the inner city of Leipzig, to protest for peace and call for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine. The protest was part of a series of traditional protests during the easter holiday.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 8 April 2023, at the call of The Left, people gathered at St. Georg in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte, to protest for peace and call for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine. The protest was part of a series of traditional protests during the easter holiday.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 8 April 2023, at the call of The Left, around 100 people gathered at Platz der Einheit in Potsdam, to protest for peace and call for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine. The protest was part of a series of traditional protests during the easter holiday.

organizers: The Left (Germany)

They showed support to Palestinians and denounced Israeli occupation policies. Demonstrators were against colonialism and imperialism.

They were against further nuclear power plant lifetime extensions. Demonstrators gathered on the occasion of the 12th anniversary of the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

The mayor Belit Onay of The Greens, addressed the protesters and called on them to resist conspiracy theories and antisemitism. A counter-protest with around 65 people was organised by BPD to support Ganser.

The protest, in which Bremen's Education Senator (SPD) and a representative of the Kurdish Women's Council took part, was part of a series of global protests on International Women's Day.

The protest was part of a series of global protests on International Women's Day.

The event was part of a day of joint action called by FFF and Ver.di to demand more climate action on the occasion of a Global Climate Strike and higher wages amid inflation.

organizers: AI: Amnesty International; Alliance Against the Right; Government of Germany (2021-); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); Protesters (Ukraine); Refugees/IDPs (Ukraine); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 24 February 2023, on the one-year anniversary of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, people, including the town's mayor (SPD), Ukrainian refugees, and a Protestant priest, took part in a vigil at the Postplatz in Schwerte to show solidarity with Ukraine and call for an end to the war in Ukraine. The event organized by the integration council of the city of Schwerte, several political parties, the local working group for asylum, the 'Schwerte gegen Rechts' alliance and the local branch of Amnesty International.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Government of Ukraine (2019-); Protesters (Ukraine); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2023, people gathered on the red carpet at the Berlinale film festival in Berlin - Mitte to show solidarity with Ukraine and call for an end to the war in Ukraine on the one-year anniversary of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Among the protesters were Mariette Rissenbeek, Carlo Chatrian, and actress Kristen Stewart. They were supported by the Federal Minister of Culture (The Greens), Claudia Roth, and the Ukrainian Ambassador to Germany, Oleksii Makeiev.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Protesters (Ukraine); Refugees/IDPs (Ukraine); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2023, around 300 people, including Ukrainian refugees, gathered at the Marktplatz in Bonn to show solidarity with the Ukrainian refugees and call for an end to the war in Ukraine on the one-year anniversary of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The mayor Katja Dorner (The Greens) addressed the protesters and called for an end to the war.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 24 February 2023, at the call of MLPD, people gathered in front of a building by company Siemens in Berlin - Spandau, to protest for an end to the war in Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

organizers: Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 24 February 2023, at the call of MLPD and Freunde der Internationalen Automobilarbeiterkonferenz, people gathered at a factory by car company Opel in Russelsheim am Main, to protest for peace and an end to arms deliveries to Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 24 February 2023, at the call of MLPD and REBELL, people gathered in Dortmund, to protest for peace and an end to arms deliveries to Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

organizers: Environmental Union; FVC: Women Association Courage; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Women (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2023, at the call of MLPD, REBELL, Environmental Union, and FVC, around 40 people gathered in Heilbronn, to protest for peace and an end to arms deliveries to Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Environmental Union; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 24 February 2023, around 30 people gathered in Bremen at the call of Herz fur Ukraine e.V.' and DGB, to protest for peace and an end to arms deliveries to Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia. Members of MLPD, REBELL, Arbeiterbund fur den Wiederaufbau der KPD, Anticapitalistas, and Environmental Union were also present.

organizers: Environmental Union; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; SI: Solidarity International
description: On 24 February 2023, at the call of MLPD, REBELL, Environmental Union, Solidarity International, and Kumpel fur Auf, around 80 people gathered at Neumarkt in Gelsenkirchen, to protest for peace and an end to arms deliveries to Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2023, around 60 people, including a member of parliament (The Left), gathered for a vigil in Kaufbeuren, to protest for peace and an end to arms deliveries to Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2023, at the call of Lendringsen hilft, hundreds of people including the Mayor Roland Schroder (SPD) and members of the Ukrainian community, gathered in Menden, to protest against Russia's war efforts and show solidarity with Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); JL: Young Liberals; JU: Young Union; Students (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2023, at the call of JL, JU, GJ, and university students, people gathered at the Holzmarkt in Tubingen (Baden-Wurttemberg, Tubingen) to protest against Russia's war efforts and show solidarity with Ukraine, one year after the invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 23 February 2023, members of IB and MLPD demonstrated at the ferry terminal Teufelsbruck in Hamburg - Altona against imperialism, financing wars, and the war in Ukraine.

organizers: Protestant Christian Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 22 February 2023, around 60 people, including members of The Greens and Protestants, gathered in front of the Russian General Consulate in Bonn (Nordrhein-Westfalen, Bonn) to protest against Russia's war in Ukraine, two days before the one-year mark of the conflict. The night before the demonstration, 'Z' symbols were spray-painted on the walls of the Consulate.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 21 February 2023, at the call of Ver.di, about 2,000 employees of the public sector, including nurses and a Lehrte councilwoman (The Left), protested at the Schutzenplatz in Lehrte (Niedersachsen, Region Hannover) to demand higher wages amid inflation.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 20 February 2023, around 300 people, including the mayor (SPD), demonstrated and formed a human chain along the federal highway 192 in Waren to call for a peaceful solution to the war in Ukraine. They opposed further arms deliveries to Ukraine and had gathered on the occasion of the Munich Security Conference (SIKO).

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Free Saxony; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 20 February 2023, at the call of an AFD city councilor, around 530 people, including Free Saxony affiliates, demonstrated in a public parking lot on the Nordring in Eilenburg against a refugee accommodation. At the call of the Left Youth and 'Leipzig takes a seat', around 90 people, including The Left MPs, gathered for a counter-demonstration.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Protesters (Ukraine); The Greens (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 18 February 2023, at the call of Munich Stands Up (affiliated with Querdenken), around 10,000 people, including 250 AFD members, marched from Odeonsplatz to Marienplatz in Munchen to protest against the Munich Security Conference (SIKO), NATO, and the shipment of weapons to Ukraine. Around 1,000 people, including Ukrainian citizens, members of the Ukrainian community, and elected officials (The Greens, FDP), gathered for a counter-demonstration to show support for Ukrainians amid the Russo-Ukrainian War. They called on the German government to send more weapons to Ukraine while introducing more sanctions against Russia.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Women (Germany)
description: On 18 February 2023, at the call of the city's Equality Commissioner, around 50 people, including elected officials and the mayor (CDU) - most of them women -, gathered in front of the home of the victim of a femicide in Rendsburg to denounce the crime and raise awareness about violence against women in the country.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 16 February 2023, at the call of Ver.di, around 1,500 employees of the public sector protested at the Wilhelm-Leuschner-Platz in Leipzig (Sachsen, Leipzig), to demand higher wages amid inflation. A politician and state representative of The Left held a speech during the protest, claiming solidarity with the protester's cause.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 15 February 2023, around 200 people, some of which affiliated with The Left such as politician Ferat Kocak, protested in front of the newly opened police station at Kottbusser Tor in Berlin - Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg (Berlin, Berlin) against its construction and to demand more checks on police violence.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); OBR: One Billion Rising; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 14 February 2023, around 2,500 people, including the Federal Minister for Women (The Greens) and women, demonstrated in Berlin against violence against women and girls. They gathered for a dance and called the event 'One Billion Rising'.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 14 February 2023, at the call of Ver.di union, around 520 people, mostly employees of the public sector, municipal hospitals, Savings Banks Southwest Palatinate, Protestant daycare centers from Zweibrucken, and a member of the Parliament (SPD), demonstrated in Pirmasens to call for better pay and better working conditions.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); OBR: One Billion Rising; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 14 February 2023, people, including a women's shelter director, city councilor (The Left), and SPD member of the state parliament, demonstrated at the Markischer Platz in Rathenow against violence against women and girls. This was part of the 'One Billion Rising' campaign.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; OBR: One Billion Rising; Women (Germany)
description: On 13 February 2023, at the call of the Equality commissioner, around 500 people, including a CDU politician and women, demonstrated in Henstedt-Ulzburg against violence against women and girls. They gathered for a dance and called the event 'One Billion Rising'.

organizers: Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Students (Germany)
description: On 13 February 2023, around 1,000 leftists, at the call of the Technical University student union and Jusos, gathered and carried out sit-in blockades around the Dippoldiswalder Platz in Dresden against historical distortion, Nazis, and far-right appropriation of the Dresden commemoration march of the destruction of Dresden in the Second World. During the sit-ins, police officers used batons and pepper spray against the demonstrators. One person threw stones at a police officer.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 11 February 2023, at the call of a member of the Parliament (The Greens), between 80 and 150 people gathered in Pilsting to show solidarity with refugees, against hate against them, and to denounce hateful acts targeting them. At the call of AFD, around 60 people gathered at the Volksfestplatz for a counter-demonstration.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 11 February 2023, at the call of the group Imland and WKE - Eckernforde Economic Circle, dozens of people, including the mayor (SPD) and health workers, demonstrated in Eckernforde for the preservation of the Imland hospital.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Iranian Group (Germany); Protesters (Netherlands); Women (Germany)
description: On 11 February 2023, between 4,700 and 10,000 people, including the mayor (CDU), the Iranian community, and people from the Netherlands, demonstrated in Dusseldorf to call for support and solidarity with Iranian people, following the death of a 22-year-old Kurdish-Iranian woman in police custody on 16 September 2022. Demonstrators were against the Iranian government and chanted the slogan 'Women, life, freedom'.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 8 February 2023, at the call of AFD, people gathered in Radeburg (Sachsen, Meissen) to oppose arms deliveries to Ukraine.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 8 February 2023, at the call of AFD, 14 people gathered outside a McDonald's restaurant in Thiendorf (Sachsen, Meissen) to oppose arms deliveries to Ukraine.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 8 February 2023, at the call of AFD, people gathered in Grossenhain (Sachsen, Meissen) to protest for peace and oppose arms deliveries to Ukraine.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 7 February 2023, at the call of AFD, around 100 protesters gathered in Teterow (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Rostock) to call for stricter migration policies. The party had organized the protest amid an opposition movement to the accommodation of refugees in centers in the region. A few neo-Nazi activists attended the event.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 5 February 2023, around 100 residents and AFD members, as well as city councilors, demonstrated against a refugee accommodation in front of the site of a planned emergency shelter for asylum seekers in Leipzig - Stotteritz. At the call of Leipzig Takes A Seat, around 80 people, including The Left and The Greens members, gathered for a counter-demonstration in favor of the relocation of refugees and against racism.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 4 February 2023, between 180 (according to the police) and 300 (according to organizers) people, including AFD members, gathered at the market square in Sangerhausen to call for a diplomatic solution to the war in Ukraine, denouncing the delivery of weapons to the country. They expressed grievances over an escalation of the, and also complained about past coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 2 February 2023, at the call of The Left, 30 people gathered at Bahnhofspark in Grimma (Sachsen, Leipzig) to oppose arms deliveries to Ukraine and call on the federal government to seek more diplomatic approaches to end the war. The group had installed a red tank statue on the the square to draw attention to their demands.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 1 February 2023, at the call of AFD, about 100 people protested over the establishment of a new refugee center in Bach an der Donau (Bayern, Regensburg). A counter-rally called by the 'Alliance for Tolerance and Human Rights' and the 'Initiative against the Right', in which SPD, Greens and the Left representatives took part, gathered around 230 people.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 31 January 2023, around 30 people, at the call of AFD, demonstrated in Kramerhof (in the Parow district) against the refugee shelter and the federal government's asylum policy. They denounced what they perceived as 'mass migration'.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Free Saxony; NPD: National Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 31 January 2023, around 200 people, including Free Saxony activists, NPD, and AFD politicians, demonstrated in Strelln (Sachsen, Nordsachsen) against the planned accommodation of refugees in the community in the district of North Saxony near Leipzig. They gathered in front of a building where a public information event on the planned accommodation was to take place. Brief scuffles between demonstrators and the police took place when participants were prohibited from entering the building.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; Catholic Christian Group (Germany); CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2023, at the call of The Greens, SPD, FDP, CDU, Free Voters, DGB, Catholics, Protestants, AWO, the Network for Tolerance, Working Group Region Against Racism, Democracy Celebration Project, and Association to Act Nonviolently, around 80 people, including elected officials, demonstrated in Korbach for peace in Ukraine. They were in favor of the tank deliveries to Ukraine even though they described it as a new dimension of the war.

organizers: Antifa; BPD: The Grassroots Democratic Party of Germany; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany)
description: On 30 January 2023, between 1,500 (according to the police) and 5,000 (according to organizers) people, including students, employees, the city's mayor (SPD), elected officials (CDU), Antifa, and BPD members, gathered in Leipzig for an action called 'Leipzig lights up' to send a signal for democracy, human rights, openness, diversity, solidarity, and social cohesion. Verbal tensions occurred between Antifa and BPD members who called for peace without weapons.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 28 January 2023, around 100 people, at the call of the AFD, demonstrated in front of the state parliament in Saarbrucken under the motto 'energy transition, climate, sanctions, and more democracy'. Around 30 people from the left-wing scene gathered for a counter-demonstration. There was a physical altercation between two people, and one of the members of the counter-demonstration was slightly injured.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; BPD: The Grassroots Democratic Party of Germany; Querdenken
description: On 28 January 2023, around 100 people, including BPD, Querdenken, and AFD members, demonstrated in Aachen against arms deliveries to Ukraine amid the war. Around 20 people, including Antifa members, gathered for a counter-demonstration.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 28 January 2023, at noon, around 50 people, including elected officials (The Left), at the call of the Anti-War Alliance, demonstrated in Aachen against arms deliveries to Ukraine. They denounced it as a decision that could reinforce the prospect of a Third World War.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 28 January 2023, around 500 people, including MLPD affiliates, demonstrated in Mossingen (Baden-Wurttemberg, Tubingen) to remember activists who performed a general strike in 1933. They also condemned Russia's aggression against Ukraine but opposed the shipment of weapons to Ukraine.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 23 January 2023, around 175 people, including AFD elected officials, demonstrated in Wittenberg to demand that when freedoms are restricted because of coronavirus-related measures, there should be a committee to reexamine the measures daily. They also criticized the delivery of Leopard battle tanks to Ukraine.

organizers: Health Workers (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 21 January 2023, around 850 people, including health workers and physicians, at the call of The Greens and SPD, demonstrated in Lubeck against the takeover of the Marien hospital by the University Hospital Schleswig-Holstein (UKSH), which would cause the hospital to move to the campus of the university.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Volt Europa; Women (Germany)
description: On 21 January 2023, around 120 people, including MLPD, SPD, and Volt Europa members, demonstrated in Lubeck against the Iranian government and for Iranian women's rights in the wake of Mahsa Amini's death. They called on the European Union to support 'democracy movements' in Iran. Demonstrators demanded an end to executions and to the dress code for women. They demanded the release of all political prisoners.

organizers: Protesters (Iran); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany); Women (Iran)
description: On 21 January 2023, at the call of the Greens, around 70 people, including Iranians, demonstrated in Olsberg against the Iranian government and for Iranian women's rights following the death of Mahsa Amini. Demonstrators demanded an end to executions and the release of all political prisoners.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 20 January 2023, about 60 The Left members and supporters protested in Kriebethal against far-right politics of threats and violence, supporting the accommodation of refugees in their hometown. AfD supporters engaged in a counter-protest, displaying anti-refugee sentiments and opposing the accommodation of refugees in Kriebethal.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 19 December 2022, around 115 people, at the call of the AfD, demonstrated on the Bitterfeld market square in Bitterfeld-Wolfen against the federal government, CDU political party, inflation, and high energy costs.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 17 December 2022, around 850 people, including elected officials (SPD, CDU) and mayors (The Greens), at the call of Women, Life, Freedom, demonstrated in front of the city hall in Bonn against the Iranian government. They called on the German government to sanction the Iranian one by closing embassies for example. They gathered following the death of a 22-year-old Kurdish-Iranian woman in police custody on 16 September 2022.

organizers: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 17 December 2022, around 120 people, including the Kurdish community and MLPD members, demonstrated in Lubeck against Turkish bombings in Rojava (northeastern Syria).

organizers: ATIK: Confederation of Workers from Turkey in Europe; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); Labor Group (Turkey); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Turkey); REBELL: Youth League Rebel; SI: Solidarity International; Women (Germany); YPG: People's Protection Units
description: On 17 December 2022, around 300 people, including TIKB, MLPD, Partizan, REBELL, ATIK, MLKP, SI, IGM, Young Struggle, Alinteri (an oppositional workers' newspaper published in Turkey), YPG, PYD, KGO, Nav-Dem, Environmental Trade Union, at the call of ICOR Europe, and the Kurdish/Turkish organizations United Revolutionary Struggle, United Movement of Women and the Alliance of Democratic Forces of Europe, demonstrated in Duisburg in front of the central station. They gathered under the motto 'workers and peoples of the world against fascism and imperialism'.

organizers: IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; SI: Solidarity International; South Korean Group (Germany)
description: On 17 December 2022, members of MLPD, REBELL, SI, IGM and the South Korean community demonstrated in front of the South Korean embassy in Berlin - Mitte to support South Koreans demanding freedom on the same day that trade unions in South Korea called for nationwide protests against the country's government. They were also against imperialism.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 December 2022, around 150 people, including the Minister of Education (The Greens) and DGB members, demonstrated in Eschede against far-right movements and extremists. They called on the government to support initiatives against far-right affiliates and Nazis.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 14 December 2022, employees of the rail vehicle manufacturer Alstom (from Bautzen and Gorlitz), at the call of IGM, including an elected official (The Left), protested in Berlin against the management's plan to cut jobs.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 13 December 2022, around 150 people, at the call of AFD, demonstrated on Schlossplatz in Dessau-Rosslau against coronavirus-related measures, sanctions against Russia amid inflation, and welcoming refugees. They gathered under the motto 'peace, freedom, prosperity - Germany first'. Around 100 people, at the call of 'Dessau Nazi Free', including students and some coming 'from abroad', gathered at the main train station for a counter-demonstration against Nazis, fascism, and racism.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 10 December 2022, around 120 people, at the call of AFD, including elected officials (AFD), demonstrated in Illerkirchberg to express displeasure with current migration policies after the deadly attack on two girls in Illerkirchberg by an asylum seeker (with no political motive). People gathered for a counter-demonstration to call for peace, solidarity, and tolerance.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 5 December 2022, around 430 people, at the call of AFD, with AFD elected officials, demonstrated in Bitterfeld-Wolfen against the federal government's policies. Demonstrators were against the sanctions against Russia as they could increase inflation, criticized immigration policies, and called for the opening of the Nordstream 2 natural gas pipeline. They were against the possible NATO accession of Ukraine. They walked via the Bundesstrasse 100 and Rathenaustrasse back to the market square.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Last Generation (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 5 December 2022, around a dozen people, mostly members of ALG and an elected official (The Greens), demonstrated and blocked traffic at the Weender Tor in Gottingen to call for climate protection. Demonstrators were carried off the street by police officers and firefighters helped remove the glue from those who stuck themselves to the road.

organizers: BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 3 December 2022, around 200 people, including an elected official (The Greens), and BUND members, demonstrated on the market square in Grunheide (Mark) against the expansion of the Tesla factory as environmental requirements are not met. They called for a citizens' consultation on the further development of the US company.

organizers: FVC: Women Association Courage; Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: Around 3 December 2022 (as reported), more than 60 participants, at the call of the 8 March Alliance, Kurdish Society Center, FVC, The Left, MLPD, and REBELL, demonstrated in Heilbronn in solidarity with Iranian and Kurdish women. They were against the Iranian government and denounced the violence following the death of a 22-year-old Kurdish-Iranian woman in police custody on 16 September 2022.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 3 December 2022, around 20 residents, at the call of an elected official (The Greens), accompanied by around 20 children, demonstrated in Heidelberg for the closure of the street Langer Anger between Da-Vinci-Strasse and Galileistrasse.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 2 December 2022, around 500 AFD affiliates, including elected officials (AFD), demonstrated in Zwickau around the Cathedral with the motto 'Zwickau is heating up!'. Around 1,000 people gathered for a counter-demonstration to defend peace.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 2 December 2022, people gathered at the call of the 'Friendship Festival' and The Left, during a festival, to demonstrate in Pirmasens and call for an immediate stop to the bombings in Ukraine.

organizers: Women (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 25 November 2022, in the afternoon, at the call of Citizens' Initiative Saar (IRBIS), around 200 people, including Saarland Women's Council members and an SPD state parliament member, gathered on Landwehrplatz in Saarbrucken to protest in solidarity with women and girls in Iran in the wake of Mahsa Amini's death. Participants chanted the slogan 'Women, Life, Freedom.'

organizers: Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union; Women (Germany)
description: On 25 November 2022, in the afternoon, at the call of Bundnis Buntes Zweibrucken, Arbeitsgemeinschaft sozialdemokratischer Frauen (SPD), the Greens, Ver.di, and the Migrationsbeirat, 80 or so people, including an actress, marched from Alexanderplatz to Herzogplatz in Zweibrucken to protest against the Iranian regime and denounce the curbing of the protest movement in the country, in the wake of the death of Mahsa Amini.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Police Forces of Germany (2021-); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); Protesters (Iran); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany); Women (Iran)
description: On 25 November 2022, at noon, on the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women and to commemorate the assassination of the Mirabal sisters, people, including an Iranian woman and representatives of various associations and institutions (Protestant Women's Work, Equal Opportunity Commission, the city's mayor (SPD), Women's Refuge Kaiserslautern, Police Headquarters Western Palatinate), gathered at the Altenhof in Kaiserlautern to denounce violence against women and express solidarity with the protest movement in Iran in the wake of Mahsa Amini's death.

organizers: FVC: Women Association Courage; IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Women (Germany)
description: On 25 November 2022, people, including members of FVC, MLPD, IB, and REBELL, demonstrated in Halle (Saale) to denounce violence against women and called for more freedom. They gathered under the slogan 'Woman, Life, Freedom' and on the occasion of International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. Demonstrators also denounced the consequences of inflation and wars on women's safety.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 25 November 2022, on the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, members and workers employed by the city council, including the mayor (SPD), gathered outside the town hall of Velten with placards denouncing violence against women. They also expressed support for the women involved in the ongoing protest movement in Iran following the death of Mahsa Amini.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 25 November 2022, on the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, at the call of the Luneburg Alliance Against Violence Against Women, people, including the town's mayor (Greens), took to the streets in Luneburg to denounce violence against women.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 25 November 2022, on the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, Arbeitsgemeinschaft sozialdemokratischer (SPD) Frauen (ASF) and Grannies Against the Right affiliates took part in a rally in front of the district office and a silent march to the town hall in Aalen. They denounced violence against women.

organizers: The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 24 November 2022, people, including Green Party affiliates, gathered outside the State Parliament (Maxmonument) in Munchen to call for more protection against violence against women in refugee shelters. The event was organized ahead of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 24 November 2022, in the evening, as part of the #SoldarischerHerbst campaign and at the call of the Superreiche zur Kasse Alliance, which includes the Ver.di, DGB and AWO unions, as well as the SPD, Green, and Left parties), between 350 (according to the police) and 1,000 people (organizers) gathered in Odeonsplatz in Munchen to demand social justice, greater wealth distribution, and more support from authorities amid the energy crisis. They specifically demanded higher taxes for the 'super-rich' and an additional energy price flat rate of 500 euros.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 24 November 2022, in the evening, at the call of AfD and under the slogan 'Peace, Freedom, and Prosperity', people gathered in Halle (Saale) to oppose sanctions amid the war in Ukraine, claiming they were instrumental in prompting inflation and rising energy prices. At the call of the Halle Against the Right Alliance, up to 700 people, including an SPD affiliate, took to the streets to oppose the far-right ideology.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 22 November 2022, between 100 and 200 people, including MLPD members, demonstrated in Wuppertal (Elberfeld) against the Turkish government and its military operations in Syria. Demonstrators carried flags of the YPG (People's Protection Unit Flags). Demonstrators, who were asked by the police to stop the rally, later gathered at another location and held a spontaneous demonstration with a final rally.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 19 November 2022, around 300 people gathered in Speyer at the call of AFD and demonstrated for solidarity amid inflation, and called for job preservation. Around 250 people, including political parties (SPD, CDU, The Greens) members, DGB, Grannies Against the Right, the mayor (CDU), associations, clubs, catholic churches, and institutions gathered for a counter-demonstration.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 13 November 2022, between 200 and 250 cyclists, including the town's mayor (The Greens), at the call of the alliance 'Women, Life, Freedom', demonstrated in Bonn against the Iranian regime following the death of a 22-year-old Kurdish-Iranian woman in police custody in Iran on 16 September 2022. They rode their bicycles from the Hofgarten via Beuel and the city center to the Botanical Garden.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Iranian Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 12 November 2022, around 150 people, at the call of elected officials (The Greens) and the Iranian community, demonstrated in Duisburg to express their solidarity with the protesters in Iran following the death of a 22-year-old Kurdish-Iranian woman in police custody in Iran on 16 September 2022. They demanded a tougher stance from the EU and the German government against the Mullah regime.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 12 November 2022, at the call of AfD, people gathered at Market Square in Stuttgart to denounce rising inflation and energy prices and call for the lifting of sanctions against Russia amid the war in Ukraine. Several counter-demonstrations were organized across the city on that day.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Iranian Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 12 November 2022, around 4,000 people, including elected officials (SPD, The Greens), 'Munchen is colorful!' (Munchen ist bunt!), DGB members, and exiled Iranian women, demonstrated in Munchen to show support for the protests in Iran following the death of a 22-year-old Kurdish-Iranian woman in police custody in Iran on 16 September 2022. They gathered under the slogan 'Woman, Life, Freedom'.

organizers: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 12 November 2022, at least 30,000 people, including MLPD members, Kurdish organizations such as KON-MED (Confederation of the Communities of Kurdistan in Germany) and YJK-E (Association of Women from Kurdistan in Germany), demonstrated in Dusseldorf against the alleged use of chemical weapons operations by the Turkish government against Kurdistan (northern Iraq). They accused the German government of selling weapons to the Turkish government. They gathered in the city center and at the Rhine meadow.

organizers: Antifa; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 12 November 2022, around 150 people, including Antifa activists, affiliates of the Alliance for Peace and Democracy (Bundnis fur Frieden und Demokratie), and elected officials (independent, The Greens), demonstrated in Remagen against anti-Semitism, Nazis, far-right violence, racism, and to call for more democracy, solidarity and diversity. They all gathered on the occasion of the Day of Democracy.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 8 November 2022, more than 100 people, including elected officials (The Left), gathered at the call of unions (AWO, People's Solidarity, Tafel, Elstal), and The Left, in Falkensee to denounce inflation, high energy costs, and to call for social justice.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Students (Germany); The Left.SDS
description: On 8 November 2022, around 150 students, including members of Jusos, ASTA, The Left.SDS, GJ, demonstrated in front of the Audimax in Greifswald against the presence of an AFD law professor holding a lecture.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); OEDP: Ecological Democratic Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Teachers (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 7 November 2022, more than 250 people, including teachers, demonstrated, at the call of the Foreigners' and Integration Advisory Council, SPD, The Greens, OEDP, and The Left members as well as elected officials, demonstrated in Erlangen (Besiktasplatz) to show solidarity with the people in Iran following the death of a 22-year-old Kurdish woman in police custody in Iran on 16 September 2022.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 7 November 2022, around 700 people, including elected officials (The Greens), demonstrated in Kiel to denounce the alleged attack on people of the LGBT community on 5 November 2022.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 7 November 2022, leftists, including elected officials (The Left), demonstrated in Naunhof to show solidarity with the people in Ukraine.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 7 November 2022, around 840 people, at the call of AFD, demonstrated in Bitterfeld-Wolfen against the policies of the federal government amid inflation.

organizers: Grannies Against the Right (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 7 November 2022, around 60 people, including Grannies against the right, SPD and The Greens members, demonstrated in front of Reinbek Castle in Reinbeck against the nationalist-folkish Desiderius Erasmus Foundation, the AFD, and far-right members.

organizers: IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 3 November 2022, around 400 workers of MAN and MLPD members, gathered at the call of IGM and demonstrated in Oberhausen in front of the gate of a factory for better pay.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 November 2022, around 400 people, members of The Left and Christians, demonstrated in Halle (Saale) to call for more social justice amid inflation. Demonstrators called for fair distribution amid the economic crisis. Far-right affiliates gathered for a counter-demonstration and to call for support for a former elected official.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 31 October 2022, around 210 people, at the call of AFD, including elected officials (AFD), demonstrated in Grossenhain to call for an immediate end to the war in Ukraine, mostly to end economic sanctions against Russia, and obtain better energy policy amid inflation.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Health Workers (Germany); Reich Citizens
description: On 31 October 2022, around 2,700 people, including Reich Citizens affiliates, health workers, and AFD members, demonstrated in Wittenberg against coronavirus-related measures (such as the ones concerning vaccination). They also discussed xenophobic and conspiracy theories. The event was called Reformation 2.0. Members of 'Doctors for Enlightenment' were present.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 31 October 2022, between 600 and 2,000 people, at the call of The Left, demonstrated in Leipzig against high energy prices. Between 500 and 1,000 people, mostly far-right members and Free Saxony affiliates, gathered for a counter-demonstration and against high energy prices.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Free Saxony
description: On 31 October 2022, about 340 people, including AfD affiliates and members of Free Saxony, took to the streets for a 'Monday Walk' in Waldheim. Protest motives were not specified.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 30 October 2022, more than 100 people, at the call of The Left, demonstrated in Bautzen at the Kornmarkt to denounce the suspected xenophobic arson attack on the Spreehotel and to show solidary with refugees.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; JA: Young Alternative for Germany
description: On 29 October 2022, around 50 members of AFD and JA demonstrated in Berlin - Tempelhof-Schoneberg against the new counseling facility for queer (LGBT) people. Around 320 people gathered for a counter-demonstration, at the call of The Greens. Some threw water bombs.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; Ende Gelaende; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Labor Group (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 29 October 2022, more than 1,600 people, at the call of Alliance for Social Justice (ASJ), unions (Ver.di, IGM), Ende Gelaende, Alliance Against the Right, ASTA, Jusos, The Green Youth, demonstrated in Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg) (Mitte), from the Berliner Tor to the Rathausmarkt, for more solidarity, affordable life, and social justice. They denounced inflation and poverty.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 28 October 2022, 60 members of AFD demonstrated in Ochsenfurt against coronavirus-related measures. Around 100 people gathered for a counter-demonstration.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 28 October 2022, around 40 people, at the call of The Left, demonstrated in Ludwigsfelde against inflation, the government's policies, and high energy costs. Demonstrators distanced themselves from Nazis and far-right movements. They called for more taxes on companies that make profits during inflation, and the withdrawal of Russia from Ukraine amid the war.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 27 October 2022, people, including CDU members, craftsmen, and tradesmen, with around 300 vehicles, demonstrated in Jena against inflation, high energy costs, and the government's policies. They gathered at Sparkassen-Arena, the Saale-Holzland, and drove from the Weimarer Land to the Saale-Orla districts.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 24 October 2022, around 1,100 people, at the call of AFD, demonstrated in Magdeburg against inflation and high energy costs.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 24 October 2022, around 300 people, including an AFD elected official, demonstrated in Kothen against inflation, high energy costs, and the current government.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 24 October 2022, around 350 people, including workers, at the call of AFD, demonstrated in Bitterfeld-Wolfen against high energy costs, the government's policies, inflation, and for social justice.

organizers: FVC: Women Association Courage; Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Ver.di: United Services Union; Women (Germany)
description: On 24 October 2022, nurses, doctors clinic staff, therapists, trainees, FVC members, and MLPD, at the call of Ver.di, demonstrated in Tubingen for better working conditions and a better health care system.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; PEGIDA: Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamisation of the Occident
description: On 24 October 2022, around 700 people, mostly Pegida and AFD affiliates, demonstrated in Dresden at Neumarkt square near the Frauenkirche church for a far-right 'walk'. They gathered for the 8th anniversary of the Pegida movement. Around 700 people, including students and the alliance 'Hope. Fight racism', gathered for a counter-demonstration in front of the Gewandhaus to call for tolerance and cosmopolitanism. They tried to block the other protesters with sit-ins but the police, without physical intervention, managed to separate the two groups.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 22 October 2022, several members of the Kurdish community, including an elected official (The Greens), demonstrated at the Iranian Embassy in Berlin - Steglitz-Zehlendorf against the violent actions of the Iranian security forces in Iran. The demonstration was triggered by the death of a 22-year-old Iranian Kurdish woman in police custody on 16 September 2022.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Iran); Women (Germany)
description: On 22 October 2022, around 80,000 people, including Iranians from all over the country, and MLPD members, demonstrated at the call of feminist organizations (Woman Life Freedom Collective), from the Grosser Stern (Victory column) through the Berlin government district in Berlin - Mitte to show solidarity with the protests in Iran. Demonstrators demanded more women's rights and freedom. They called for the overthrow of the Islamic government system and the death of Iran's head of state. Occasionally, there were scuffles or disputes in which police officers had to intervene to mediate. 6 people were temporarily arrested. The demonstrations were triggered by the death of a 22-year-old Iranian Kurdish woman in police custody on 16 September 2022.

organizers: Attac; BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; Campact; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; GEW: German Education Union; Government of Germany (2021-); Greenpeace; Labor Group (Germany); Teachers (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 22 October 2022, between 2,800 (according to the police) and 6,000 (according to organizers) people, including elected officials (The Left), at the call of an alliance (DGB, Solidarity Autumn (SH), Campact, GEW, Ver.di, Attac, BUND, Greenpeace, Parity Welfare Association (PW), People's Solidarity (VS), the citizen's movement Financial Turnaround (BF)), demonstrated in Berlin - Mitte (from the Invalidenpark to the Brandenburg Gate) under the slogan 'Solidarity through the crisis'. They denounced inflation and its consequences. Demonstrators called for social justice (redistribution), and solidarity amid the energy crisis. The alliance sharply distanced itself from far-right movements.

organizers: DKP: German Communist Party; Left Youth Solid; SDAJ: Socialist German Workers Youth; The Left (Germany)
description: On 21 October 2022, between 30 and 40 people, at the call of The Left, DKP, SDAJ, and Left Youth Solid, demonstrated in Hattingen against arms deliveries to Ukraine amid the war with Russia and inflation, high energy costs, and sanctions against Russia.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Free Saxony; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 18 October 2022, between 1,000 and 3,000 people, including elected officials (CDU) and Free Saxony members, demonstrated in Grimma against inflation and high energy costs. Demonstrators were also in solidarity with Ukrainian refugees and condemned the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 17 October 2022, between 1,100 (according to the police) and 2,000 (according to organizers) people, including AFD members, demonstrated in Bitterfeld-Wolfen to call for lifting the sanctions against Russia amid the war in Ukraine and to criticize the German government. Demonstrators denounced inflation and energy costs.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 15 October 2022, around 30 members of AFD demonstrated in Bergheim against coronavirus-related measures, refugees, and the policies of the German government concerning the war in Ukraine. Around 80 people, including SPD, CDU, The Greens, FDP, The Left, PP, FW members, gathered for a counter-demonstration and for democracy, respect of laws, as well as human rights.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 15 October 2022, around 1,000 people, at the call of The Left, Ver.di, and AWO, demonstrated in Potsdam for social cohesion and solidarity. Demonstrators denounced inflation and called for more government aid in the energy crisis. They asked for the government to reallocate German armaments billions to social and ecological tasks. The Unemployment Association, the German Tenants' Association, People's Solidarity and Food Bank participated.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 15 October 2022, around 250 people, including members of Fifty-Fifty, the Left, and climate activists, demonstrated in Dusseldorf from the main train station to the city hall against inflation and for social justice. They called for a reintroduction of the 9-euro ticket in public transportation, a cap on energy prices not just in March, and extended protection against dismissal for tenants.

organizers: Anarchist Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 15 October 2022, between 1,000 and 3,000 people, including anarchists, at the call of The Left, demonstrated in Leipzig against inflation, and for social justice (better redistribution) especially during the energy crisis as well as climate protection. Several hundred motorists also demanded cheaper fuel prices during a joint ride into the city center. Pyrotechnics were set off.

organizers: GEW: German Education Union; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Teachers (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 15 October 2022, around 30 people, including The Left, SPD and GEW members, demonstrated in Ingolstadt against inflation. Demonstrators called for higher pensions, and more tax justice. A demonstrator criticized the company Shell and the energy prices freeze that will only be implemented in March.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Catholic Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 15 October 2022, around 160 people, including Catholics, priests from the brotherhood of St. Pius X who are linked to far-right movements, and an AFD elected official, demonstrated in Saarbrucken, in front of the 'Pro Familia' counseling center, for a strict abortion ban. The 'Christians for Life' action committee had called for the 'March for Life'. Almost 320 counter-demonstrators, at the call of two feminist groups 'My Body My Choice', for women's rights of self-determination over their own bodies. 20 counter-demonstrators blocked the demonstrators and which in response engaged in some light pushing. No violence was reported.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: Around 11 October 2022 (as reported), around 50 people, including Meiningen's mayor (SPD), demonstrated at the former border between Eussenhausen and Henneberg [coded to Henneberg] against the Sudlink power line.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 October 2022, over 100 people, including AFD members, demonstrated in Potsdam for an end to sanctions against Russia amid the war in Ukraine and against all coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 October 2022, less than 1,200 people, at the call of AFD, demonstrated in Magdeburg against coronavirus-related measures and the war in Ukraine. Demonstrators denounced the current inflation.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 October 2022, around 100 people, at the call of AFD, demonstrated in Eisenach against inflation and called on the government to put '[their] country first' and make life more affordable.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 10 October 2022, thousands of people, including members of MLPD and The Left, demonstrated in Dusseldorf against the Iranian regime.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 8 October 2022, 30 people, at the call of SPD, Jusos, and DGB, demonstrated in Duisburg in front of a theater against violence against women in Iran, following the death of a young woman who was in custody of the Morality Police for not wearing her hijab properly.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 5 October 2022, about 250 people, including activists and the mayor of Neubrandenburg (The Left), gathered for a rally in Neubrandenburg, demanding the preservation of a local maternity hospital.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Free Saxony; NS: New Strength
description: On 3 October 2022, around 10,000 far-right representatives and supporters gathered on the Day of German Unity in Gera to protest against the government's energy policy and sanctions against Russia amid the war in Ukraine. Several high-profile individuals from Free Saxony, AfD and NS addressed the crowd.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 3 October 2022, around 2,000 far-right representatives and supporters gathered on the Day of German Unity in an AfD-organized anti-government protest in Bitterfeld-Wolfen, condemning the government's energy policy and the sanctions against Russia amid the war in Ukraine. AfD MPs joined the protesters.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 30 September 2022, around 250 employees of the technology company ZF and several elected officials, including from the CDU, SPD and The Greens, joined a protest in Eitorf against the closure of the plant.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Government of Germany (2021-); Iranian Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 28 September 2022, in the morning, more than 100 people, including women, politicians (the Green Party leaders and a CSU MP) and an Iranian-born actress, protested in front of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin - Mitte against the regime and oppression of women in Iran. The protest was triggered by the death of a woman who was arrested by the morality police for infringing hijab rules.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Protesters (Iran); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany); Women (Iran)
description: On 28 September 2022, in the afternoon and evening, up to 1,800 people, including Iranian women, writers and actors, joined a protest at Pariser Platz in Berlin - Mitte in solidarity with protests taking place in Iran and condemned Germany's lack of sanctions against Iran, demanding a 'feminist foreign policy'. The Minister of Agriculture (The Greens) joined the protest. The current protest was triggered by the death of a woman who was arrested by the morality police for infringing hijab rules.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 28 September 2022, many people, joined by politicians, including Schleswig-Holstein Minister of Social Affairs (The Greens), protested outside the State Parliament in solidarity with women and protesters in Iran in Kiel. The current protest was triggered by the death of a woman who was arrested by the morality police for infringing hijab rules.

organizers: JL: Young Liberals; Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 21 September 2022, people, including JL, Jusos and The Greens members, demonstrated in Hannover in front of the parliament to call for the voting age to be lowered to 16 ahead of state elections in Lower Saxony.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 20 September 2022, around 200 people, at the call of The Left, demonstrated in Rathenow against inflation, and rising energy and food costs. They denounced the government's policies.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 19 September 2022, between 700 (according to the police) and 1,000 (according to organizers) people, at the call of AFD, demonstrated in Bitterfeld-Wolfen (Wolfen-Nord) against the federal government, sanctions against Russia, and their consequences, notably citing inflation. Demonstrators called for an end to arms deliveries to Ukraine.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 19 September 2022, around 100 people, including AFD members, demonstrated in Nossen against inflation, the war in Ukraine, and the energy crisis.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 19 September 2022, between 800 and 900 people, including AFD members, demonstrated in Possneck against inflation.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 19 September 2022, around 150 people, at the call of an AFD elected official, demonstrated in Ebersbach-Neugersdorf against inflation, the war in Ukraine and the energy crisis.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 19 September 2022, around 350 people, including elected officials (AFD), demonstrated in Sommerda against inflation.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); IBD: Identitarian Movement Germany
description: On 19 September 2022, around 2,500 people, including IBD members and elected officials (AFD), demonstrated in Chemnitz against inflation, the Ukraine war, and the energy crisis.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 19 September 2022, at the call of MLPD, people demonstrated in Essen (Katernberg) against poverty and inflation.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); Greek Group (Germany); Health Workers (Germany); Orthodox Christian Group (Germany)
description: On 17 September 2022, between 1,000 and 3,150 people, including CDU members, health workers, Christians, Catholics, and the Greek Orthodox community, marched through Berlin (Brandenburg Gate, Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf, Potsdamer Platz, Friedrichstrasse, to the city center) against the right for abortion. The event, which was called 'March for Life', was organized by the 'Federal Association for the Right to Life' (BVL). A demonstrator punched the camera of a journalist.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 17 September 2022, more than 30 people, at the call of SPD, demonstrated in Burgdorf against the defective elevator at the Burgdorf train station. They called for Deutsch Bahn (DB) to take into account senior citizens and people with disabilities.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 17 September 2022, between 600 (according to the police) and 800 people (according to organizers) people, including feminists, the LGBT community, the association 'What the Fuck', Alliance for Sexual Self-Determination (BSS) members, Grannies Against the Right, The Greens, and DGB delegates, gathered for a counter-demonstration in Berlin (Brandenburg Gate, Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf, Potsdamer Platz, Friedrichstrasse, to the city center) in favor of the right to abortion. Police officers intervened and used physical force against protesters in Berlin - Mitte as they were blocking traffic.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Free Saxony; Querdenken
description: On 12 September 2022, just under 1,000 people, including AFD, Free Saxony, and Querdenken members, demonstrated in Dresden against the German government's energy policy, inflation and energy prices.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 12 September 2022, around 750 people, including AFD members, demonstrated in Querfurt against inflation, the high cost of energy, and the government's sanctions against Russia, given the current rising cost of living.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Students (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 11 September 2022, around 2,500 people, including elected officials (The Left), demonstrated in Erfurt at the call of DGB, FFF and AWO against inflation and for a stronger compensation for the rising food and energy prices. Demonstrators were also against far-right movements.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 10 September 2022, around 2,000 people, including the LGBT community, elected officials, members of SPD, The Left, The Greens, and FDP, demonstrated in Halle (Saale) for gender and sexual diversity. The event was organized by the association BBZ ('lifestyle') on the occasion of Christopher Street Day (CSD). Far-right protesters gathered for a counter-demonstration. A 'a minor confrontation' happened, but no injuries nor physical fight was reported.

organizers: IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: Around 10 September 2022 (as reported), people, including MLPD and IGM members, demonstrated in Baunatal in front of the main gate of the company Volkswagen AG Baunatal to call for permanent contracts for temporary workers.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 7 September 2022, employees of Alstom demonstrated in Gorlitz against job cuts. Economics Minister Martin Dulig (SPD), Gorlitz Mayor Octavian Ursu (CDU) and District Administrator of the Gorlitz district, Stephan Meyer (CDU) were also in attendance.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 5 September 2022, several hundred people demonstrated at the call of AFD in Bitterfeld-Wolfen against inflation and the current policies of the government.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Farmers (Germany); FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 5 September 2022, around 200 people, including farmers, FW members, a mayor (CSU) and elected officials (SPD), demonstrated in Dorfen against new rail tracks (called 'Limone') planned in the area by the Deutsche Bahn.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 5 September 2022, around 150 people, including The Left affiliates, demonstrated on Augustusplatz in Leipzig against the government's energy and social policies, as well as inflation. They were also denouncing Nazis, fascism, and far-right ideologies as several hundred members of Free Saxony and AFD simultaneously demonstrated in Leipzig against inflation on that day.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Russian Group (Germany)
description: On 4 September 2022, around 1,000 people, including AFD members and the Russian community, gathered for a pro-Russian rally in Koln (on Roncalliplatz) for the end of the war in Ukraine, against sanctions, price increases and coronavirus vaccinations. Around 400 people, including the Ukrainian and Russian communities as well as Antifa members, gathered for a counter-demonstration against Nazis.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; BPD: The Grassroots Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 4 September 2022, between 1,800 and 2,000 people, including AFD and BPD members, demonstrated in Lubmin to call on the German government to open the Nord Stream 2 natural gas pipeline to tackle the 'energy crisis'. Demonstrators also demanded an export ban on weapons to Ukraine and the resignation of the German government. Some Russian flags were present.

organizers: ATIK: Confederation of Workers from Turkey in Europe; DKP: German Communist Party; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); Labor Group (Turkey); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Palestinian Group (Germany); REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Women (Germany); YPG: People's Protection Units
description: On 3 September 2022, around 100 people, including members of DKP, MLPD, REBELL, the Palestinian community, ATIK, YPG, the women's organization ZORA, IGM colleagues from the Ford company, marched through the city center of Koln to protest against wars (notably Kurdistan and Ukraine) and imperialism. Other associations were present: Peace Forum, Solidarity Network, Mala Kurda, and Atif.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 3 September 2022, around 7,000 people, including the LGBT community and an elected official (SPD), demonstrated in Dresden for LGBT rights and tolerance on the occasion of Christopher Street Day (CSD) and against discrimination.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 3 September 2022, at the call of IB, around 30 people, including MLPD members, demonstrated in Bochum against the war policy of the government amid the war in Ukraine. Demonstrators protested against imperialism and the war in Ukraine.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; Students (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 September 2022, people, including students, FFF, and The Left members, demonstrated in front of the town hall in Halle (Saale) against war, violence, and against the war in Ukraine specifically. Members of the 'Peace Circle' were present. They gathered on the occasion of Anti-War Day.

organizers: DFG-VK: The German Peace Community; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); Students (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 1 September 2022, people, including elected officials (The Left), DFG-VK, FFF, a Protestant pastor, members of the local 'Peace Movement', DGB, and the 'Action Alliance', demonstrated in Ingolstadt against the war in Ukraine on the occasion of Anti-War Day. Demonstrators called for money to be invested in social issues, climate protection, and energy supply instead of war.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); Left Youth Solid; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 1 September 2022, around 150 people, including members of DIDF (Foderation Demokratischer Arbeitervereine), Left Youth Solid, MLPD, Kurdish community, DGB and the Peace Forum, demonstrated in Essen against 'imperialist wars', including the war in Ukraine. They gathered on the occasion of Anti-War Day.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 27 August 2022, 20 people, including members of AFD, demonstrated on Munsterplatz in Freiburg im Breisgau against abortion. Between 400 and 500 people gathered for a counter-demonstration and against Nazis, far-right, and the presence of far-right movements.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 21 August 2022, nearly 200 people, including an elected official (CDU), demonstrated in Friedland against a rally of the far-right group 'Awakening Homeland' (AH) and to promote diversity.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 20 August 2022, between 300 (according to the police) and 400 people (according to organizers), including elected officials (The Greens), demonstrated in Hassfurt for LGBT rights and under the motto 'Visibility creates safety'. They gathered on the occasion of Christopher Street Day (CSD).

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 17 August 2022, around 300 people, including members of AFD and The Left, demonstrated in Neuruppin against the presence of the Chancellor of Germany, and to denounce inflation.

organizers: ADFC: German Bicycle Club; BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; FFF: Fridays for Future; OEDP: Ecological Democratic Party; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 13 August 2022, hundreds of people, including members of BUND, ADFC, FFF, The Greens, The Left, and OEDP, demonstrated in Kempten (Allgau) against the expansion of a highway (B12) and for more cycle paths. They gathered during a visit of the Prime Minister.

organizers: LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 13 August 2022, around 3,000 people, including the LGBT community and The Greens members, demonstrated in Mannheim to stand up for diversity, acceptance, respect, and freedom. Demonstrators were also against the war in Ukraine and called for freedom for Ukrainians. They also denounced the exclusion of transsexual people when they flee. They gathered for Christopher Street Day (CSD).

organizers: Antifa; Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Palestinian Group (Germany); REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 13 August 2022, around 250 people, including members of MLPD, Antifa, REBELL, and the Kurdish as well as Palestinian communities, demonstrated in Leipzig against the attacks of the Israeli army on Gaza, Palestine. The association Handala called for the event. A good dozen people gathered for a counter-protest with Israeli flags.

organizers: Cameroonian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 12 August 2022, around 300 people, including MLPD members and an elected official (The Greens) who is also Cameroonian, demonstrated in Dortmund against police violence after the death of a teenager killed by police officers on 8 August 2022. The participants demanded clarification, justice, and that those responsible be held accountable.

organizers: Antifa; Ende Gelaende; FFF: Fridays for Future; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); IL: Interventionist Left; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 9 August 2022, around 700 people, including members of FFF, The Greens, GJ, IL, Ende Gelaende, and Antifa, camped and demonstrated in Hamburg - Altona (Hamburg) to call for climate protection and protest against the G20 summit in Altona Volkspark.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; IB: Internationalist Alliance; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Japan)
description: On 7 August 2022, around 150 people, including members of MLPD, DGB, ICAN (International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons), IB, and a Japanese musician, demonstrated in Frankfurt am Main to call for the abolition of all nuclear weapons. They called on the government to sign the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT). Demonstrators also denounced the Turkish army's raid on the Kurdish areas. Protesters gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 6 August 2022, around 250,000 people, including members of the LGBT+ community, company representatives, the mayor (SPD), members of football clubs (FC St. Pauli), FDP, and The Greens, marched across Hamburg - Hamburg-Mitte (Hamburg), St. Georg, to draw attention to increasing hate crime against queer people. They had gathered for Christopher Street Day (CSD). The organizer of the event was the association 'Hamburg Pride'. Members of LSU (Lesbians and Gays in the Union) were also in attendance.

organizers: ATIK: Confederation of Workers from Turkey in Europe; FVC: Women Association Courage; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); Labor Group (Turkey); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Turkey); Women (Germany)
description: On 6 August 2022, around 30 anti-nuclear activists, including members of ATIK, FVC, MLPD, IGM, and ICOR (The International Coordination of Revolutionary Parties and Organizations), protested in Hamburg (Hamburg) to call for the government to abolish nuclear weapons and nuclear energy. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine, imperialism, and the prospect of a nuclear third world war. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 6 August 2022, anti-nuclear activists, including MLPD members, protested in Rostock to call for the government to abolish nuclear weapons and nuclear energy. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine, imperialism, militarization, and the prospect of a nuclear third world war. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 6 August 2022, a few anti-nuclear activists, including members of MLPD and IB, protested in Munchen to call for the government to abolish nuclear weapons and nuclear energy. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine, imperialism, militarization, and the prospect of a nuclear third world war. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: Labor Group (Italy); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Italy)
description: On 6 August 2022, anti-nuclear activists, including an Italian worker and MLPD members, protested in Hattingen to call on the government to abolish nuclear weapons and nuclear energy. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine and the prospect of a nuclear third world war. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (China); Protesters (Denmark); Protesters (Syria)
description: On 6 August 2022, anti-nuclear activists, including Syrians, Danes, Chinese, and MLPD members, protested in Mulheim an der Ruhr to call for the government to abolish nuclear weapons and nuclear energy.
