Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine and the prospect of a nuclear third world war. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 6 August 2022, 26 anti-nuclear activists, including members MLPD, IB, and REBELL, gathered in Lubeck to call on the government to abolish nuclear weapons and nuclear energy. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine, imperialism, militarization, and the prospect of a nuclear third world war. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan. In front of the Greens' office, demonstrators denounced the party's policies and its agreement, as part of the government coalition, to extend the life cycle of nuclear power plants.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 6 August 2022, anti-nuclear activists, including MLPD members and elected officials (The Left, The Greens), protested at the airbase in Buchel, calling on the government to abolish nuclear weapons and nuclear energy. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine and the prospect of a nuclear third world war. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan and called for the government to sign the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT).

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 6 August 2022, people, including MLPD members, demonstrated in Leverkusen on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan to publicly denounce the atomic bombing of Hiroshima as a 'barbaric crime' against people.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Russia); Protesters (Ukraine)
description: On 6 August 2022, around 50 people, including MLPD members, Russians and Ukrainians, demonstrated in Stralsund for peace amid the war in Ukraine. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 6 August 2022, a few activists, including members of MLPD, IB, and IGM, demonstrated in Dresden against the war in Ukraine, nuclear weapons, NATO, and imperialism. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: FVC: Women Association Courage; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); IB: Internationalist Alliance; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Ver.di: United Services Union; Women (Germany)
description: On 6 August 2022, between 60 and 80 people, including members of MLPD, FVC, REBELL, IB, IGM, Grannies Against the Right, and Ver.di, demonstrated in Berlin - Mitte (Moabit district) against the war in Ukraine, nuclear weapons, and the threat of nuclear wars. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 6 August 2022, around 50 people, including the mayor (SPD) and local organizations (Peace Initiative), demonstrated in Bonn (Beuel district) against the war in Ukraine, nuclear weapons, and the role of the German government in the ongoing war in Ukraine. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan and commemorated the victims.

organizers: FVC: Women Association Courage; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Women (Germany)
description: On 6 August 2022, at least 25 anti-nuclear activists, including members of MLPD, IAC (International Automobile Workers Coordination), and FVC, protested in Sindelfingen to call for the government to abolish nuclear weapons and nuclear energy. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine, imperialism, militarization, and the prospect of a nuclear third world war. They had gathered on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings in Japan.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 30 July 2022, around 200,000 people, including members of the LGBT community and elected officials (The Greens), demonstrated in Stuttgart for LGBT rights. They gathered for Christopher Street Day (CSD). Some demonstrators waved Ukrainian flags to express solidarity with the country amid the war in Ukraine.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 28 July 2022, around 50 people, including The Greens members, demonstrated in Murnau am Staffelsee to call for the preservation of trees on Poschinger Allee and against the municipal council majority's proposal to build a road in the middle of a cycle path which they claimed would be too costly.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); LGBTQ+ (International); Protesters (International); Protesters (Ukraine); The Left (Germany)
description: On 23 July 2022, around 150,000 people 'from all over the world', including members of the LGBT community, elected officials, The Left members, and Ukrainians, demonstrated throughout Berlin - Mitte (from Spittelmarkt to the Brandenburg Gate) for LGBT rights and to denounce violence against the queer community. Demonstrators were also against the war in Ukraine. The motto of the event was 'United in Love - Against Hate, War and Discrimination'.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 23 July 2022, around 20 people, including elected officials, The Left, and local association members, demonstrated in Kiel to denounce poverty and how it affects them. They denounced inflation (rising food prices). Demonstrators called for a basic child allowance, crisis-proof protection for old-age and disabled pensioners, and the abolition of 'undignified sanctions'.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany)
description: On 23 July 2022, around 200 people, including the mayor (independent) and CSU members, demonstrated in Weilheim in Oberbayern to call for more stable train services between Munchen and Mittenwald.

organizers: Labor Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 July 2022, people, including employees of the company Ford and elected officials (Environment Minister, SPD), demonstrated in Saarlouis against job cuts and Ford management.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 10 July 2022, around 500 people, including the mayor (SPD), and members of the LGBT+ community, demonstrated in Olpe for LGBT+ rights, solidarity, and against discrimination towards the queer community. They gathered for Christopher Street Day (CSD). They denounced the attack against the LGBT+ community in Oslo on 25 June 2022. The event was organized by CSD Olpe e.V.

organizers: Antifa; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 9 July 2022, around 400 Antifa members, as well as MLPD activists, demonstrated in Oberhausen to denounce an IED attack on the local headquarters of the political party The Left in the same city.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 9 July 2022, around 4,500 people, including members of the LGBT community and The Greens elected officials, demonstrated in Kiel for LGBT rights and a more diverse society.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 8 July 2022, MLPD and REBELL members demonstrated in Buchel against the nuclear weapons base in the city and to call for the signature of the UN Treaty on the Prohibition of the Use of Nuclear Weapons.

organizers: Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 8 July 2022, at the call of Ver.di, people, including employees of HAVAG, and affiliates of The Left, REBELL, and MLPD, demonstrated in Halle (Saale) to maintain the 9-euro national public transport ticket, demanding free public transportation for the population.

organizers: Health Workers (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 7 July 2022, people, including nurses, health workers of 6 university hospitals, metal workers from Siemens Mobility Krefeld, and MLPD members, demonstrated in Essen to call for better working conditions.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 5 July 2022, at the call of the International Physicians Against Nuclear War (IPPNW) and the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN), people, including MLPD and REBELL members, demonstrated and camped in Buchel against the nuclear weapons base in the city and to call for the signature of the UN Treaty on the Prohibition of the Use of Nuclear Weapons.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 5 July 2022, around 250 people, including members of The Left, demonstrated in Oberhausen against far-right terrorism and fascism following an alleged attack with explosives on one of The Left's offices by far-right members on 4 July 2022.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); LGBTQ+ (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 3 July 2022, around 1,200,000 people, including members of the LGBT community, firefighters, members of CDU, The Greens, and elected officials, demonstrated in Koln for LGBT and human rights as well as to denounce discrimination against the queer community. They gathered for Christopher Street Day (CSD). The association KLuST organized the demonstration.

organizers: Antifa; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 3 July 2022, at the call of CDU, between 350 (according to the police) and 1,000 (organizers), including members of SPD, FDP, The Greens, and around 30 hooded alleged Antifa members, demonstrated in Dotlingen (Brettorf district) against the far-right political party AFD and their meetings.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany
description: On 2 July 2022, around 350 people affected by the flood disaster in the Ahr Valley (14 July 2021) and CDU members demonstrated in Mainz to denounce faltering payments from the reconstruction fund and the decision to dismantle flood relief centers in the Ahr Valley by the end of July.

organizers: Antifa; ATIK: Confederation of Workers from Turkey in Europe; DKP: German Communist Party; FVC: Women Association Courage; GEW: German Education Union; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); IB: Internationalist Alliance; Labor Group (Germany); Labor Group (Italy); Labor Group (Turkey); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Italy); Protesters (Palestine); REBELL: Youth League Rebel; S.I. COBAS: Inter-category Trade Union; SDAJ: Socialist German Workers Youth; Students (Germany); Teachers (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union; VVN-BdA: Association of Persecutees of the Nazi Regime/Federation of Antifascists; Women (Germany)
description: On 2 July 2022, between 1,400 and 4,000 people, including students, employees (Siemens, Thyssen, Volkswagen), communists, anti-militarists, Palestinians, dockworkers, Grannies Against the Right, Antifa, members of SDAJ, GEW, Ver.di, VVN-BdA, MLPD, IB, The Left, FVC, and ATIK, demonstrated in Bebelplatz in Berlin - Mitte for peace in Ukraine and against the rearmament amid the war in Ukraine. Demonstrators were against the government's decision to dedicate 100 billion euros to military spending and called for the funds to be used on social welfare, health, education, culture, and climate protection. The demonstration was organized by a group called 'Civilian change of times' (ZZ).

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 28 June 2022, around 20 people, including MLPD and REBELL members, demonstrated in Bochum against militarization and the acute danger of world war amid the war in Ukraine. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine and the aggressions from Russia and the US.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 26 June 2022, between 800 (according to the police) and 2,000 (according to organizers) people, including IB, and MLPD members, demonstrated in Garmisch-Partenkirchen near Elmau Castle against the ongoing G7 Summit and imperialism. Among the central themes of the rally were the climate crisis and fears of an escalation of the Ukraine war. The event was organized by the Alliance 'Stop G7 Elmau'. 4 people were arrested.

organizers: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 25 June 2022, between 5,000 and 20,000 people, including the Kurdish community, members of MLPD and REBELL, demonstrated in Dusseldorf to defend Kurdistan and Kurdish independence.

organizers: PARTEI: The Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 25 June 2022, between 120 and 150 people demonstrated in Moers at the call of several organizations (SPD, The Greens, The Left, and Die Partei) against the planned concert of a far-right musician, far-right movements, and Nazis. Around 35 counter-demonstrators, including members of Pegida and 'Lower Rhine People's Community' (VN), gathered for a counter-demonstration.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 June 2022, more than 100 people, mostly cyclists and an SPD member, demonstrated in Kassel (Steinweg district) to obtain a bike path in the city.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: Around 13 June 2022 (as reported), 12 people, including MLPD and REBELL members, demonstrated in Lubeck at the call of IB for peace and against the danger of a Third World War amid the war in Ukraine.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 12 June 2022, members of MLPD and REBELL demonstrated in Koln against rearmament amid the war in Ukraine. The action was named 'No 100 billion for German wars'.

organizers: Anarchist Group (Germany); Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 11 June 2022, around 250 people, including the Kurdish community, MLPD members, and anarchists, demonstrated in Stuttgart against rearmament and war amid the war in Ukraine. The action was named 'No 100 billion for German wars'. Demonstrators also condemned the Turkish president's war in northern Syria against Kurds.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 11 June 2022, around 30 people, including MLPD and REBELL members, demonstrated in Essen against armament and the danger of a Third World War amid the war in Ukraine.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 8 June 2022, 7 people demonstrated in Wurzen at the call of The Left for the preservation of the pediatric ward and obstetrics at the city's hospital.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 28 May 2022, around 250 people, including DGB members and the mayor (The Greens), demonstrated in Hannover against the presence of a rally of the far-right political party AFD. Around 30 people also blocked a street to prevent AFD members to access the meeting.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 18 May 2022, around 100 people, including civil servants and their association, elected officials (CDU), and Ver.di members, demonstrated in Hannover for better pay.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 16 May 2022, around 300 people, including the mayor (SPD), demonstrated in Nordenham against the deepening of the Weser River. Demonstrators feared further environmental, economic and social consequences if the project were to be implemented.

organizers: ADFC: German Bicycle Club; BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; Critical Mass; GJ: Green Youth (Germany); PARTEI: The Party; The Left (Germany)
description: On 15 May 2022, around 100 people, including members of BUND, the Green Youth, Die Partei, the Left, ADFC, and the local association 'Climate Initiative' (Klimaentscheid), and Critical Mass, demonstrated from Aalen to Schwabisch Gmund for a bicycle expressway along the road B29. They also went through the city Mogglingen [coded to Schwabisch Gmund].

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 8 May 2022, people, including elected officials (SPD), demonstrated in Potsdam to call for peace and reconciliation amid the war in Ukraine. Demonstrators gathered to commemorate the end of World War II and National Socialism in Europe.

organizers: ATIK: Confederation of Workers from Turkey in Europe; FVC: Women Association Courage; GEW: German Education Union; IGBCE: Industrial Union for Mining, Chemistry and Energy; IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Kurdish Ethnic Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); Labor Group (Turkey); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (International); Protesters (Turkey); Protesters (Ukraine); REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Refugees/IDPs (Ukraine); SI: Solidarity International; Teachers (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union; Women (Germany); YPG: People's Protection Units
description: On 8 May 2022, more than 1,500 people, including protesters from several countries (France, Greece, Turkey, Kurdistan, Iraq, Iran, Ukraine, Palestine, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Morocco, Nigeria and Switzerland), members of organizations (MLPD, REBELL, IGM, IGBCE, Ver.di, GEW, FVC, Solidarity International, ATIK, and YPG), Ukrainian refugees, miners, workers from enterprises (Opel Bochum, Russelsheim, Ford, Daimler), demonstrated in Gelsenkirchen to denounce the danger of a new world war. Demonstrators were against the war in Ukraine and imperialist aggressions.

organizers: Azerbaijani Group (Germany); Bulgarian Group (Germany); Georgian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); Jewish Group (Germany); Polish Group (Germany); Protesters (Ukraine); Refugees/IDPs (Ukraine); Russian Group (Germany); Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 8 May 2022, around 2,000 people, including members of the Russian, Polish, Georgian, Bulgarian, Azerbaijani, Jewish, and Ukrainian communities, Green Party members, law students, Ukrainian refugees, as well as the mayor (independent), demonstrated in Koln against the war in Ukraine and the 2022 Russian invasion. They gathered to commemorate the end of World War II on 8 May 1945.

organizers: Antifa; DKP: German Communist Party; IL: Interventionist Left; SDAJ: Socialist German Workers Youth; SJD: Socialist Youth Germany - The Falcons; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 8 May 2022, around 250 people, including Trotskyists, and members of SPD, The Left, IL, DKP, SDAJ, SJD, and Antifa, demonstrated in Dortmund against fascism on the occasion of the 77th anniversary of the end of World War II on 8 May 1945.

organizers: FW: Free Voters; The Greens (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 8 May 2022, at the call of the Ukrainian community, between 1,000 and 3,000 people, including members of FW and The Greens, demonstrated in Munchen against war. Demonstrators paid tribute to the victims of World War II and the war in Ukraine.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Independent Politicians (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 7 May 2022, around 80 people, including the mayor (independent) and The Greens members, demonstrated in Mosbach against the war in Ukraine.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Querdenken
description: On 7 May 2022, a large number of people, including coronavirus deniers, members of Free Assange, Querdenken, and MLPD, demonstrated in Koln against the war and arms deliveries to Ukraine. Demonstrators gathered to counter an ongoing political rally by The Greens for the North Rhine-Westphalia elections, in which the country's Foreign Minister was taking part. Three men were arrested. One because he ignited pyrotechnics.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Protesters (Ukraine); Refugees/IDPs (Ukraine)
description: Around 26 April 2022 (as reported), around 5 people, including Ukrainian refugees, demonstrated in Stralsund at the call of CDU against the presence of the Minister President of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern and to call for her resignation amid allegations that she's involved with the 'controversial' climate and environmental foundation MV partially financed by Russia amid the war in Ukraine.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 23 April 2022, between 40 (according to the police) and 100 (according to organizers) people, including DGB, The Left members, demonstrated in Kiel to call for more and better housing under the slogan 'Housing is a human right'.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 23 April 2022, between 300 and 700 people, including the mayor (CDU), demonstrated in Beverungen against the planned logistics center for nuclear waste in Wurgassen.

organizers: AWO: Worker Welfare; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; FDP: Free Democratic Party; FW: Free Voters; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: Around 18 April 2022 (as reported), around 150 people, including Christians, demonstrated in Korbach at the call of several organizations (DGB, AWO, SPD, CDU, FDP, The Greens, Free Voters, The Left) for peace in Ukraine and against the use of weapons. Demonstrators protested in solidarity with Ukrainians. They had gathered for an Easter March.

organizers: DFG-VK: The German Peace Community; DKP: German Communist Party; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; VVN-BdA: Association of Persecutees of the Nazi Regime/Federation of Antifascists
description: On 18 April 2022, around 800 people, including members of DFG-VK, DKP, MLPD, REBELL, VVN-BdA, demonstrated in Dortmund to call for peace amid the war in Ukraine, denouncing the war and militarization. Some demonstrators fought (one demonstrator was choked) because some demanded the eviction of MLPD from the demonstration before police officers separated demonstrators, with no reported injuries. description: On 26 February 2022, around 500 people, including SPD members, demonstrated in Koblenz at the call of Jusos against the war and Russian invasion of Ukraine on 24 February 2022.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 26 February 2022, around 100 people, SPD members, Christians, workers, and the current Minister President of Rhineland-Palatinate, demonstrated in Trier against the war and Russian invasion of Ukraine on 24 February 2022. Demonstrators gathered for a prayer.

organizers: IB: Internationalist Alliance; MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; SDAJ: Socialist German Workers Youth
description: On 26 February 2022, around 100 people, including members of REBELL, SDAJ, IB, MLPD, and Communists, demonstrated in Essen against the war in Ukraine

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 26 February 2022, around 5,000 people, including SPD members, demonstrated in Kiel against the Russian invasion of Ukraine on 24 February 2022.

organizers: GJ: Green Youth (Germany); Government of Germany (2021-); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 26 February 2022, around 200 people, including the mayor, demonstrated in Mosbach at the call of The Greens and Green Youth to call for peace in Ukraine.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 25 February 2022, around 150 people, including a mayor, CDU, SPD, The Greens, FDP, demonstrated in Leverkusen against the Russian government and the invasion of Ukraine on 24 February 2022. Demonstrators called for economic sanctions on Russia and to welcome Ukrainian refugees.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany
description: On 24 February 2022, around 300 people, including SPD and CDU members, demonstrated in Saarbrucken in solidarity with Ukrainians and against the Russian invasion.

organizers: The Greens (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2022, hundreds of people, including the Ukrainian community, The Greens members, demonstrated in Koln against the war in Ukraine and the Russian government.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 24 February 2022, around 500 people, including the Prime Minister and The Left members, demonstrated in Weimar against the war in Ukraine and the Russian government.

organizers: JL: Young Liberals; JU: Young Union; Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD
description: On 23 February 2022, a small group of people, including JU, Jusos, and JL members, demonstrated in Bottrop in solidarity with Ukraine and against the war.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Ukrainian Group (Germany)
description: On 23 February 2022, around 200 people, including the Ukrainian community, demonstrated in Hamburg - Hamburg-Nord (Hamburg), in front of the Russian Consulate, at the call of several organizations (SPD, The Greens, CDU, FDP) against the war in Ukraine and the Russian government.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; Health Workers (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 22 February 2022, around 200 people, including health workers, gathered in Holzkirchen at the call of SPD, FDP, and The Greens to show solidarity with the people who are in the front lines of the coronavirus health crisis. They wanted to counter the events of people who are hostile to coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 22 February 2022, between 600 and 700 people, including SPD, The Left members, demonstrated in front of the Russian Embassy in Berlin - Mitte to call for peace in Ukraine, against the Russian government, and 'against the violation of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity, as well as aggression and escalation'.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FDP: Free Democratic Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); Volt Europa
description: On 22 February 2022, around 250 people demonstrated in Frankfurt am Main at the call of several organizations (The Greens, Volt, CDU, SPD, FDP) against the war in Ukraine and the Russian government.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Querdenken
description: On 19 February 2022, around 120 people, including Querdenken and AFD members, demonstrated in Heilbronn against coronavirus-related measures. People, including SPD members, gathered for a counter-demonstration, some participated in the protest for Hanau victims.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 19 February 2022, around 500 people, including the mayor, SPD, and The Greens members, demonstrated in Dusseldorf against racism and to commemorate the racist attack of Hanau (which happened on 19 February 2020). Demonstrators have criticized the slow investigation of the attack and demanded political consequences as well as more policies against racism.

organizers: The Left (Germany)
description: On 19 February 2022, around 20 people demonstrated in Gottingen at the call of The Left to denounce increasing energy prices (gas, electricity, fuel). Demonstrators called for more financial aid from the government.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 19 February 2022, around 1,000 people, including CDU, SPD, and the mayor, demonstrated in Hanau to commemorate the racist attacks in Hanau, on 19 February 2020. Demonstrators were against racism and far-right movements. Demonstrators have criticized the slow investigation of the attack and demanded political consequences.

organizers: Alliance Against the Right; DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 19 February 2022, around 200 people, including SPD, The Greens, The Left, Ver.di, DGB, and Alliance Against the Right members, demonstrated in Heilbronn against racism and to commemorate the victims of a racist attack in Hanau which happened on 19 February 2020.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 13 February 2022, around 230 people demonstrated in Heidelberg at the call of several organizations (SPD, Catholic and Protestant churches, The Greens, IGM, and Jusos) to demand more solidarity within the society during the coronavirus health crisis. They wanted to oppose conspiracy theories concerning coronavirus. Demonstrators were in favor of vaccination and formed a human chain.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 13 February 2022, between 500 and 800 people, mostly neo-Nazis and AFD members, demonstrated in Dresden for a 'Funeral March' to denounce the destruction of the city by Allies. They used slogans comparing the bombings to the Holocaust. More than 3,000 people, including leftists and Grannies against the Right members, gathered for a counter-demonstration against Nazis. Police officers used tear gas and intervened to disperse several groups.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 9 February 2022, around 40 people, including the mayor and CDU members, demonstrated in Dusseldorf to counter the current national movement against coronavirus-related measures. People gathered in solidarity with those suffering from the coronavirus health crisis and called on Querdenken members to respect laws.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 7 February 2022, around 220 people, including AFD members, demonstrated in Bad Hersfeld against coronavirus-related measures. Around 140 people, including The Greens members, gathered for a counter-demonstration in favor of vaccination.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 7 February 2022, around 40 people demonstrated and gathered in Ganderkesee at the call of SPD against the Querdenken movement.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria
description: On 5 February 2022, between 250 (according to the police) and 400 (according to organizers) people, including CSU members, demonstrated in Grafing bei Munchen against the planned expansion of a south expressway (Sudschnellweg) in place of a forest.

organizers: Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Students (Germany)
description: On 4 February 2022, between 150 and 200 people, including students, temporary workers of Volkswagen and Opel, demonstrated in Kassel at the call of MLPD against the planned dismissal of 570 temporary workers at Volkswagen Kassel.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Labor Group (Germany); Teachers (Germany)
description: On 1 February 2022, around 60 people, including daycare workers, educators, CDU members, and parents, demonstrated in Mainz to express their concerns during the coronavirus health crisis and called for compulsory testing for the children's safety.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 31 January 2022, around 800 people demonstrated in Cottbus at the call of AFD against coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 31 January 2022, around 150 people, including AFD members, demonstrated in Wandlitz against coronavirus-related measures. Around 250 people gathered for a counter-demonstration and formed a human chain.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 29 January 2022, around 1,250 people, including SPD and CDU members, demonstrated in Cuxhaven in support of coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 26 January 2022, around 60 people, including AFD members, demonstrated in front of a parliament and other places in Hannover against coronavirus-related measures. Around 140 people gathered for a counter-demonstration.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; IBD: Identitarian Movement Germany; The Third Path
description: On 26 January 2022, between 900 and 1,500 (according to authorities) people, including AFD, IBD and The Third Path members, in various groups, demonstrated throughout Berlin - Mitte (Berlin), including in ARD-Hauptstadtstudio, street of Unter den Linden, Berlin Cathedral and Berlin city center, against coronavirus-related measures on the occasion of the debate about a possible compulsory coronavirus vaccination requirement. Between 20 and 30 people gathered for a counter-demonstration in various places within the city as well.

organizers: PP: Pirate Party (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 25 January 2022, around 180 people demonstrated in Hof at the call of SPD, The Greens, and The Pirate Party, to demand solidarity, compliance with coronavirus-related measures, and coronavirus vaccination.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 24 January 2022, around 120 people demonstrated and formed a human chain in Meckenheim at the call of SPD to demand more solidarity during the coronavirus health crisis and to show support to health workers. Between 80 and 100 people gathered for a counter-demonstration against coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 24 January 2022, between 60 and 70 people demonstrated in Stralsund at the call of SPD to demand solidarity and cohesion during the coronavirus health crisis and to pay tribute to the victims of coronavirus.

organizers: FDP: Free Democratic Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 24 January 2022, around 50 people, including SPD, The Greens, FDP, and The Left, demonstrated in Erkrath against people who are against coronavirus-related measures. They also paid tribute to the victims of the coronavirus health crisis.

organizers: Christian Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Ver.di: United Services Union
description: On 24 January 2022, more than 500 people, including MLPD, REBELL, Ver.di members, and Christians, demonstrated and formed a human chain in Heilbronn against the Querdenken movement and to call for unity.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 24 January 2022, around 40 people, including SPD members, gathered in front of the town hall in Kopenick in Berlin - Treptow-Kopenick (Berlin), to form a solidary human chain and protested against the spread of conspiracy ideologies in the coronavirus pandemic. Around 300 people inlcuding AFD, NPD, and the Third Path staged a counter-demonstration on the Luisenhain against the corona measures. Police dissolved both groups of protesters and arrested 87 of them.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; Health Workers (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 24 January 2022, around 230 people, including health workers, The Greens, FFF, and Jusos members, demonstrated in Fritzlar against the Querdenken movement, Nazis, and to call on people to get vaccinated against coronavirus. Demonstrators denounced links between Querdenken members and far-right movements (AFD). A handful of people gathered for a counter-demonstration against coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Third Path
description: On 24 January 2022, around 220 people, including the Third Path and AFD members, demonstrated in Unterschleissheim against coronavirus-related measures. Around 70 people, including the mayor, The Greens, and SPD members, gathered for a counter-demonstration in favor of vaccination, against anti-Semitism and far-right movements as well as to call for more solidarity within the society concerning the coronavirus health crisis. Counter-demonstrators also wanted to support health workers.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 23 January 2022, between 340 and 500 people, including families and AFD members, demonstrated in Jessen (Elster) against coronavirus-related measures such as compulsory vaccination.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 23 January 2022, around 100 people demonstrated in Fussen at the call of AFD against coronavirus-related measures. 72 people gathered for a counter-demonstration at the call of SPD.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 22 January 2022, around 135 people demonstrated in Hannover at the call of AFD against coronavirus-related measures and inflation. Around 380 people gathered at the call of Ver.di union for a counter-demonstration and sit-ins against AFD members and conspiracy theories.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Free Saxony; Querdenken
description: On 22 January 2022, more than 100 people, including far-right, AFD, and Querdenken members, demonstrated in Dresden at the call of Free Saxony against coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: Catholic Christian Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 22 January 2022, around 5,000 people, including SPD members, Catholics and Protestants, demonstrated and formed a human chain from Ulm to Neu-Ulm [coded to Neu-Ulm] against the movement protesting coronavirus-related measures and Querdenken members.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 22 January 2022, around 100 people, including SPD members and a mayor, demonstrated in Herne to denounce death threats received by a pastor by people who were against coronavirus-related measures. Protesters gathered in solidarity with the pastor.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 22 January 2022, around 100 people, including AFD members and elected officials, demonstrated in Hassloch against coronavirus-related measures such as those concerning vaccination. Around 50 people gathered for a counter-demonstration against racism and far-right movements.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Teachers (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 22 January 2022, between 350 and 400 people, including SPD, The Greens members, students, teachers, and local elected officials, demonstrated in Waldbrol against racism, homophobia, and discrimination. People were also against the AFD (far-right political party).

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FDP: Free Democratic Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 18 January 2022, in the evening, around 350 people gathered, at the call of CSU, SPD, The Greens, FDP and The Left, in Bad Kissingen to protest against unregistered 'walks' against coronavirus-related measures and to call for solidarity during the pandemic. The participants formed a human chain.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; FW: Free Voters; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 17 January 2022, in the evening, about 600 people, including local Green party, SPD, FW and CDU affiliates, took part in a registered rally called 'We Are Democracy' in Schopfheim to protest against 'Monday Walks' against coronavirus-related measures and defend democracy and the rule of law.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 17 January 2022, in the evening, between 520 and 550 people took to the streets, at the call of the local AFD section, in Querfurt to protest against coronavirus-related measures. A dozen counter-demonstrators gathered nearby.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 17 January 2022, in the evening, 1,100 people took to the streets, at the call of AFD, in Bitterfeld-Wolfen to protest against coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Labor Group (Germany)
description: On 17 January 2022, in the evening, around 600 people, including a local entrepreneur and an AFD affiliate, gathered at a rally at Marktplatz in Neustadt an der Weinstrasse to protest against coronavirus-related measures. About 50 people answered the call of the 'Alliance Against the Right' and gathered nearby for a counter-protest.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 15 January 2022, in the afternoon, about 160 people, including an AFD State Parliament member, gathered, at the call of AFD, for a 'walk' through the streets of Idar-Oberstein to protest against coronavirus-related measures. About 135 people protested against the demonstration at various locations across the city.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 15 January 2022, in the evening, people, including the SPD Science Minister of Brandenburg, gathered for a vigil at the Brandenburg Gate in Potsdam to call on people to protect themselves by observing coronavirus-related measures and to commemorate the victims of the pandemic.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); Health Workers (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 15 January 2022, late in the morning, around 300 people, including SPD, FW, CSU and Green party district politicians and elected officials, and the chief intensive care physician at the district hospital, gathered in Ebersberg to protest against 'Monday Walks' and support solidarity and coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 15 January 2022, people took to the streets for a 'walk' in Dessau-Rosslau to protest against coronavirus-related measures, specifically denouncing a simultaneous vaccination action day staged in the CDU local offices. The protest was called by AFD.

organizers: Antifa; FFF: Fridays for Future; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 15 January 2022, about 700 counter-demonstrators to a anti-coronavirus measures 'walk' in Kassel was organized by entities including FFF, The Left, Grannies Against the Right, and The Greens. A group of Antifa activists split off from the main counter-demonstration and ignited flares, in the hopes of meeting Querdenken-affiliated demonstrators. The police, who temporarily arrested about 35 participants from the Antifa counter-demonstration to keep both groups separated, also pushed some of the group's participants, injuring one mildly.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Labor Group (Germany); Turkish Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 14 January 2022, more than 100 people, including a local DGB representative, members of the Action Alliance, a member of The Left, a representative of the Turkish People's House Association and representatives of democratic associations, gathered near the Turkish Consulate General in Frankfurt am Main to protest the Turkish government's plan to nominate a man who allegedly beat a protesting miner in the town of Soma in Turkey in May 2014 and confidant to the President of Turkey as commercial attache to Turkey's Representation Office in Frankfurt am Main.

organizers: The Greens (Germany)
description: On 14 January 2022, environmental activists and Green party affiliates staged, as part of the 'Alliance for Land Saving' ('Bundnis fur Flachensparen'), a protest in downtown Erding, replicating a four-lane bypass planned for a nearby airport in Schrannenplatz, to raise awareness about the size of the project and its environmental impact.

organizers: DGB: German Trade Union Confederation; Government of Germany (2021-); Labor Group (Germany); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 14 January 2022, in the afternoon, between 2,000 (according to the police) and 3,000 (organizers) people gathered for a vigil at the Opernplatz in Hannover to protest against conspiracy theories and Querdenken supporters amid a protest movement against coronavirus-related measures in the country. The vigil, which saw the participation of Lower Saxony's SPD Prime Minister, the SPD Hanover Region president and Green party representatives, had been organized by the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Hanover, the Hanover Circle of Friends and DGB.

organizers: CSU: Christian Social Union in Bavaria; FW: Free Voters; Government of Germany (2021-); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 13 January 2022, in the evening, people associated with the action alliance 'Hip is colorful', including The Greens-, SPD-, CSU- and FW-affiliates members of the city council as well as the city's mayor, set up an installation in front of the town hall in Hilpoltstein to protest against weekly protest 'walks' of vaccination skeptics and opponents to coronavirus-related measures in the city, and denounce the alleged infiltration of right-wing activists in the protest movement. One of such 'walks' was ongoing when they protested.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 13 January 2022, in the evening, more than 300 people gathered, at the call of the Alliance #Fuldahaltzusammen (supported by The Greens, SPD and The Left) in Uniplatz in Fulda to protest against 'Monday Walks' against coronavirus-related measures in the city.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 12 January 2022, 375 people, including AFD affiliates, took to the streets in Kaltenkirchen to protest against coronavirus-related measures. About 100 counter-demonstrators, including an SPD candidate, gathered at the call of the 'Alliance for Democracy and Civil Courage Kaltenkirchen' near the town hall.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 12 January 2022, about 80 people, including Protestant pastors and politicians such as the SPD deputy mayor, took part in an open air assembly in downtown Kirchweyhe to protest against the alleged infiltration of 'Monday Walks' against coronavirus-related measures by coronavirus deniers and violent actors.

organizers: FFF: Fridays for Future; Government of Germany (2021-); Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany)
description: On 10 January 2022, around 100 people, including the town's Green deputy mayor, residents and a student and FFF activist, gathered under the banner 'Bad Nenndorf is Colorful' in front of the town hall of Bad Nenndorf to protest against 'Monday Walks', with one of them taking place simultaneously with under 30 participants, against coronavirus-related measures and promote solidarity amid the pandemic.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); The Left (Germany)
description: On 10 January 2022, in the evening, people, including a The Left State Parliament member, formed a human chain in Siegburg to protest against a simultaneous 'walk' of opponents to coronavirus measures happening simultaneously in the city. The Left official was chased by demonstrators but not caught.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, about 500 people gathered, at the call of the AFD, in Erfurt to protest against coronavirus-related measures. The meeting, unregistered, was dissolved due to police injunctions.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, in the evening, 850 people gathered in downtown Bitterfeld-Wolfen to protest against coronavirus-related measures. AFD affiliates were also present.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 10 January 2022, in the evening, around 300 people, including an AFD-affiliated state parliament member, gathered in Hoyerswerda to protest against coronavirus-related measures. Six demonstrators, including the state parliament member, were identified by the police on disorderly conduct charges.

organizers: Government of Germany (2021-); Protestant Christian Group (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 10 January 2022, about 150 people, including a pastor and a Culture Senator from The Left party, gathered, at the call of the Gethsemanekiez initiative, outside the Gethsemane Church in the Prenzlauer Berg area of Berlin - Pankow (Berlin, Berlin) to promote and protect democratic values, denounce science denial and conspiracy theories and lament the instrumentalization of the 1989 Peaceful Revolution by opponents to the campaign against coronavirus. It was intended as a counter-protest to demonstrations against coronavirus-related measures. A group of opponents to the measures gathered on the other side of the street, playing the accordion to disrupt the gathering in front of the church.

organizers: SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, between 6 pm and 7 pm, about 200 people, including a self-defined SPD affiliate, gathered for a 'walk' in Festplatz in downtown Roth (Roth, Bayern) to protest against coronavirus-related measures. Simultaneously, about 350 people, including the town's SPD-affiliated mayor, gathered under the motto 'Roth is colorful' to stage a counter-protest. Both groups remained separated by a police cordon.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, in the evening, 800 people from across the district, including AFD affiliates, took to the streets in Wolfratshausen to protest against coronavirus-related measures. 450 people gathered for a counter-protest at the call of the 'Wor Tolerant' Alliance, forming a human chain to promote solidarity amid the coronavirus pandemic. There was verbal tension between both groups.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, about 230 people, including an AFD affiliate, took to the streets in Bad Hersfeld (Hersfeld-Rotenburg, Hessen) to protest against coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 10 January 2022, around 70 people, including an AFD district council member from Bebra, took to the streets, gathering on the market square, in Rotenburg an der Fulda (Hersfeld-Rotenburg, Hessen) to protest against coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Querdenken
description: On 10 January 2022, in the evening, between 500 (according to the police) and 800 people (organizers), including neo-Nazis, Querdenken supporters, coronavirus deniers and an AFD affiliate, took to the streets in Rostock to oppose coronavirus-related measures. During the procession, some demonstrators tried to force their way through a police roadblock, prompting law enforcement officers to resort to pepper spray.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, a total of 1,250 people took to the streets, first gathering near the train station, in Merseburg to protest against coronavirus-related measures. The protest was supported by AFD.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, in the evening, about 140 people took to the streets in Coswig to protest against coronavirus-related measures. The protest was supported by AFD.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 10 January 2022, in the evening, between 300 and 400 people, including an AFD State Parliament member, took to the streets in Kothen to protest against coronavirus-related measures.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-)
description: On 10 January 2022, in the evening, between 600 (police) and 700 (organizers) people, including an AFD State Parliament member, gathered, at the call of the AFD, in downtown Querfurt to protest against coronavirus-related measures, specifically compulsory vaccination and mask requirements in elementary schools, blaming the media for the government's measures. A counter-demonstration was organized by the 'Querfurt Alliance for Cosmopolitanism' in the form of a vigil near the Querfurt market.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, about 215 people took part, at the call of AfD affiliates, in a protest 'walk' in downtown Lunen to protest against coronavirus-related measures. A counter-demonstration organized at Willy Brant square by the 'Lunen Action Group Against Right-Wing Extremism' gathered around 200 people, including an SPD State Parliament member.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 10 January 2022, 120 people, including AfD affiliates, took part in a protest 'walk' in downtown Northeim to oppose coronavirus-related measures. Three people were expelled from the protest for failing to comply with COVID gathering requirements. At Entenmarkt, there was a counter-protest of 14 people organized by a local 'Action Alliance' formed by the church district of Leine-Solling, the city and district of Northeim, and the Alliance Against Right-Wing Extremism, to protect a local monument to German Jewish WW2 victims.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 9 January 2022, about 30 people, including MLPD and Rebell affiliates, gathered, at the call of an MLPD district chairwoman, by the Lenin statue in Gelsenkirchen (Gelsenkirchen, Nordrhein-Westfalen) to demand better acknowledgment of Lenin, Luxemburg and Liebknecht's legacy in the fight against capitalism and denounce the alleged lack of press coverage usually received by their commemoration. The event was indeed part of an international day of commemoration of Lenin, Liebknecht and Luxemburg.

organizers: ATIK: Confederation of Workers from Turkey in Europe; IB: Internationalist Alliance; Labor Group (Germany); Labor Group (Turkey); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Denmark); Protesters (Greece); REBELL: Youth League Rebel; SDAJ: Socialist German Workers Youth
description: On 9 January 2022, 7,000 people, including MLPD and REBELL affiliates, members of migrant organizations, SDAJ, the Internationalist Alliance and ATIK, a German steelworker, and delegates from several European countries such as Greece and Denmark, took to the streets in Berlin - Spandau (Berlin, Berlin) to protest in favor of socialism and wealth monopolies. The event was part of an international day of commemoration of Lenin, Liebknecht and Luxemburg.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 8 January 2022, around 60 people gathered, at the call of AfD, for a 'March for Freedom' in Braunschweig (Braunschweig, Niedersachsen) to protest against-coronavirus related measures. About 350 people gathered for a counter-demonstration. An attack on a police officer (without injury) was reported, yet not attributed to a specific gathering.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany; Government of Germany (2021-); NPD: National Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 8 January 2022, about 1,200 people, including the AfD state group leader and an NPD politician, took to the streets in the Euren district of Trier (Trier, Rheinland-Pfalz) to protest against the federal government's latest measures against coronavirus, claiming they should not be associated with right-wing 'extremists'. Several participants were fined for failing to comply with COVID distancing and face requirements. About 100 people, including anti-fascist activists and The Greens affiliates, gathered for a counter-demonstration.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany
description: On 7 January 2022, between 1,900 (according to authorities) and 2,300 people (organizers), including MLPD affiliates, gathered in Dessau-Rosslau (Dessau-Rosslau, Sachsen-Anhalt) to commemorate the 17th anniversary of the controversial death of an asylum seeker who presumedly died in a fire in a police cell in Dessau. Protesters accused the police of having played a role in the asylum seeker's death and the police and the judiciary of covering up a murder, demanding answers and justice.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 4 January 2022, in the evening, people took part, at the call of two AfD representatives, in a march through the streets of Schwandorf (Schwandorf, Bayern) to protest against coronavirus-related measures. The city's mayor decided to protest against 'right-wing extremism' by turning the lights off in several squares where the demonstration was set to cross.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany

Protesters called on authorities to implement sustainable solutions against militarization, climate change, and for the protection of refugees, anti-racism, and the right to housing. 2 people who tried to tear down election placards were arrested.

The police later reported that the counter-protesters threw eggs and staged a 'sit-in'.

description: On 18 January 2020, about 500 people, including the SPD mayor of the city, the DGB, Die Partei, the Left Youth and the Greens, protested against the AfD on their party congress in Marl.

organizers: BUND: German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation; FFF: Fridays for Future; Students (Germany); The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); VCD: Traffic Club Germany
description: On 18 January 2020, about 200 people, including students, BUND activists, Left and Green party members, Parents for Future, and the VCD, protested in Reutlingen against the blocking of the pedestrian crossing and for the reintroduction of traffic lights.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Farmers (Germany); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany
description: On 18 January 2020, in a protest action over the agrarian policy, farmers, including SPD and CDU members, attempted to talk to customers about their current situation of farmers in front of a supermarket in Gifhorn.

organizers: PP: Pirate Party (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 17 January 2020, squatters of the group 'We occupy Dresden' occupied an old building in Dresden and protested with about 50 supporters of the Pirates of Dresden and the Left against the current real estate situation and the many abandoned properties.

organizers: IGM: Industrial Union of Metalworkers; Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; The Left (Germany)
description: On 16 January 2020, about 40 people, including labour unions, the IG metal, the MLPD, Left groups, and affiliates of Airbus and ICE, protested and stood in solidarity with a wagon master who litigated at the Hamburg (Hamburg) court a notice of termination pending a change of contract.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Christian Group (Germany); Government of Germany (2005-2021); SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany)
description: On 15 January 2020, about 400 people, including representatives of the Greens, the CDU and the SPD, the local mayor, and a pastor, held a protest event in Reinbek against hate and the AfD.

organizers: Alevi Muslim Group (Germany); Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel; Turkish Group (Germany); Ver.di: United Services Union; Women (Germany)
description: On 14 January 2020, at least 17 people (according to photo reportage), including MLPD and Rebell activists, women, Ver.di and Alevits, gathered in front of the court in Essen to show solidarity with a woman who survived a murder attempt.

organizers: Antifa; The Left (Germany)
description: On 12 January 2020, between 600 and 10,000 people, including The Left politicians and Antifa activists, protested against fascism in Berlin - Lichtenberg (Berlin), marching from the Frankfurter Tor towards the Socialist Memorial, and commemorated the murder of Socialists Karl Liebknecht and Rosa Luxemburg in in 1919 by fascist corps.

organizers: Antifa; Grannies Against the Right (Germany); Jusos: Young Socialists in the SPD; PARTEI: The Party; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 12 January 2020, about 300 people, including Die Partei members, SPD representatives, Jusos, The Greens, The Left, Antifa supporters, Grannies Against the Right and women, protested in Karlsruhe against an event held by the AfD. Later about 20 Antifa protesters took the streets in front of a shop in the city center, which was owned by an AfD politician.

organizers: Attac; Labor Group (Germany); Seebruecke; SPD: Social Democratic Party of Germany; The Greens (Germany); The Left (Germany)
description: On 11 January 2020, between 500 and 800 people, including theater actors, Seebruecke activists, Attac representatives, SPD, Greens and Left politicians, protested in Tubingen against the deportation of a Paksitani asylum seeker.

organizers: CDU: Christian Democratic Union of Germany; Jewish Group (Germany); Protesters (Iran); Refugees/IDPs (Iran); Women (Germany)
description: On 9 January 2020, about 60 people, including Iranian refugees, women, Jews, leftist groups and members of the CDU, protested against the Iranian regime in front of a mosque in Berlin - Neukolln, where a memorial for the killed Iranian General Soleimani was held.

organizers: Labor Group (Germany); MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Protesters (Turkey)
description: On 6 January 2020, about 200 people, including workers, MLPD members and Turkish nationals, protested in front of the Haniel mine in Bottrop against the layoff of workers.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; Students (Germany); Women (Germany)
description: On 6 January 2020, about 100 people, including MLPD supporters, women and students, protested in Darmstadt for more peace, against the Turkish military offensive in Rojava, and against the US military strategy in the Middle East.

organizers: AfD: Alternative for Germany
description: On 4 January 2020, several dozen protesters called together by the AfD protested in Baden-Baden against the public broadcasting corporation SWR following the disputed song #OmaUmweltsau. A counterprotest by a local Alliance against the Right and journalists (DJV) took place.

organizers: MLPD: Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany; REBELL: Youth League Rebel
description: On 2 January 2020, about 350 MLPD and Rebel activists protested in Essen-Steele against the local far right Steeler Boys.
